children.name: TG-PHY110016
children.project_abstract:
Magnetised turbulence plays a significant role in a variety of astrophysical and laboratory processes, ranging from the generation of large-scale magnetic fields in stellar interiors, to the transport of angular momentum in accretion discs and heating in the solar corona. Unfortunately, despite its wide-ranging applicability, magnetised turbulence has evaded a general physical understanding for many decades. The development of a firm theoretical foundation for magnetised turbulence remains one of the most important outstanding problems in astrophysics.

The development of the theory for magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) turbulence heavily relies on massively parallel numerical computations. The enormous increase in computational power over recent years has enabled high-resolution numerical simulations that have led to the discovery of an array of important new effects and a number of thought-provoking theoretical conjectures have been put forward. In particular, in the case of strong field-guided incompressible MHD turbulence it has been found that the turbulent domain spontaneously fragments into regions in which the velocity and magnetic fields are aligned within a small scale-dependent angle. The aligned structures have a number of important consequences, particularly on the efficiency of the energy cascade. Moreover, it has recently become apparent that our ability to measure the scale-dependence of the alignment angle, even at low Reynolds number where traditionally only a very short inertial range is detectable (thus making the identification of scaling laws difficult), may have uncovered a new result that could be related to a well-known phenomenon in isotropic hydrodynamic turbulence. The phenomenon is known as extended self-similarity, which refers to the empirical result that the universal region of self-similarity can be significantly extended if one plots a structure function versus a second structure function for which an exact expression is known, rather than naively plotting the structure function versus the increment. If this result can be extended to the anisotropic case of magnetised turbulence its implications will be widespread, as it will enable scaling laws to be determined from a statistical analysis of numerical or observational data sets of a much reduced resolution than would otherwise be necessary.

The aim is to investigate the phenomenon of extended self-similarity in the inertial range dynamics of strong incompressible MHD turbulence. We propose a series of high-resolution numerical simulations that will elucidate the character of this mechanism. The simulations will provide crucial information for developing a comprehensive phenomenological model of strong MHD
turbulence and will provide a useful tool for inferring the scaling properties of MHD turbulence from astrophysical observations.

children.name: TG-PHY090084
children.project_abstract:
This request for computational resources through XSEDE supports three
separate but complementary projects on the topic of turbulence in
laboratory, space, and astrophysical plasmas. The first project 1.1
(Turbulent Dissipation and Plasma Heating in the Near-Earth Solar
Wind) uses very large nonlinear gyrokinetic simulations to determine
the physical mechanisms responsible for the dissipation of turbulence
in the weakly collisional solar wind plasma and for the consequent
heating of each plasma species. The second project 1.2 (Laboratory
Experiments of Alfven Wave Collisions) seeks to improve our
understanding of the fundamental building blocks of plasma turbulence
by performing laboratory experiments to measure the nonlinear
evolution of Alfven wave collisions. A key element of project 1.2 is
the detailed theoretical guidance, in the design of the experiment and
in the interpretation of the experimental results, provided by
nonlinear kinetic simulations of Alfven wave collisions using the
Astrophysical Gyrokinetics code, AstroGK. The third project 1.3
(Dynamics of the Dissipation Range in Solar Wind Turbulence) uses
Vlasov-Maxwell kinetic theory to construct a suite of observational
measures aimed at distinguishing the characteristic wave modes
underlying the turbulence in dissipation range of the solar wind. The
next stage of project 1.3 involves testing of these measures using
nonlinear kinetic simulations of balanced and imbalanced strong
kinetic Alfven wave turbulence.

children.name: TG-MCA01S007
children.project_abstract:
We propose to compute quark propagators with the overlap fermion in order to carry out calculations of hadron spectroscopy, nucleon form factors, and glue content. These quark propagators will be calculated on the dynamical fermion gauge configurations from the $2+1$-flavor domain-wall fermion action which are generated by the Riken-Brookhaven-Columbia (RBC) collaboration and the UKQCD collaboration of the United Kingdom. Since both the valence and the realistic 2+1 flavor sea quarks are based on chiral fermion formalism and the overlap valence admits valence quark masses close to those in nature, these propagators would represent the state-of-the-art resources for us and the world lattice community to calculate physical observables to check with experiments and also for studying chiral behaviors of hadrons to confront chiral perturbation theory.

Our overall request is 14,000,000 SUs on TACC Ranger and 5,000,000 SUs on BigBen at PSC and 1,000 processor hours on DataStar at SDSC. We also request 400 TB of storage space.

children.name: strong_field_physics
children.project_abstract:
With construction of the European Union's Extreme Light Infrastructure (ELI) project, a new frontier will be reached in high-power laser-plasma physics. The ELI lasers are expected to create strong enough electromagnetic fields to access non-linear quantum electrodynamics (QED) processes usually only seen in particle physics. However, the microscopic QED processes in this case are inherently entwined with the full complexity of a macroscopic laser-plasma interaction and neither may be considered in isolation. Therefore, the standard particle-in-cell (PIC) simulation approach is inadequate for describing QED-plasmas and a new approach must be adopted. We plan to study QED-plasmas using an adaptive parallel numerical simulation code PSC suitable for simulating strong field QED processes in mean field approximation.

We plan to perform simulations of intense laser radiation interacting with foils. Our final goal is to carry out a 3D simulation at high resolution. During the preparatory phase of the project, smaller simulations will be done. The simulation code PSC is in place and preparatory work has recently been published in Phys. Rev. A, 87(042117), 2013.

children.name: A-meta
children.project_abstract: This project is funded by the Office of Naval Research. We will carry out an extensive theoretical and experimental investigation of three-dimensional infrared metamaterials, with the special emphasis on their applications to energy management problems that include solar thermal energy and solar thermophotovoltaics (TPV). Infrared metamaterials are uniquely positioned for such applications because they are capable of delivering spectral control of emissivity and absorptivity across the electromagnetic spectrum: from UV/visible light (in the form of which energy arrives from the Sun) to infrared (which corresponds to the predominant emission by heated objects). Spectral control of the surface emissivity is essential in applications pertaining to concentrated solar thermal (CST) systems and solar thermophotovoltaic (STPV) systems because it enables higher conversion efficiency of solar light into infrared photons that can be harvested with almost 100% efficiency and converted into electricity.

children.name: TG-PHY190035
children.project_abstract: Computational materials design of strongly correlated materials (SCM) has a broad interest in modern condensed matter physics but it is currently under great scrutiny through the development of more accurate methodologies. Though a great number of methods has been developed, the access to those is restricted to the theoretical groups involved or the code is rather complex and require an important experience from the user community. Among all, the most successful algorithm which treats the dynamical correlations accurately is the combination of dynamical mean-field theory (DMFT) and density functional theory (DFT). However, in the present research, we plan to develop a computational package that will allow electronic structure and lattice dynamic calculations with a minimal set of parameters, by oï¬?ering to the end user the possibility of using diï¬?erent methodologies to describe basic physics of SCM. To achieve this goal, we request computing time on XSEDE resources for development and application of methodologies for strongly correlated systems. This project is funded by the national science foundation (NSF), grant 1740112. We are planning to calculate the electronic, magnetic, optical, elastic, and vibrational properties of SCM, which can be easily compared with the experimental results. The proposed simulation include (a) development of an efficient method to compute the electronic, lattice dynamic and optical properties of the strongly correlated f-electron metals: a case study of Sm, Gd, and Dy, (b) force calculations and phonons in strongly correlated materials using DFT+DMFT approach, (c) effect of magnetic order on lattice vibrations and electronic properties of correlated metal LaNiO3: DFT vs DMFT, (d) electronic and energetic calculations of strongly correlated organic materials. We request a total of 4501.940 node-hours on TACCâ??s Stampede2 and 704.243K core-hours on PSC Bridges (regular memory). We also request an allocation of 315 GB of storage.

children.name: TG-PHY170049
children.project_abstract: In magnetized jet creation experiment using the Omega laser in Rochester NY, 20 Omega laser beams are used to irradiate a flat plastic target in a hollow-ring pattern. The on-axis electron/ion densities and temperatures are measured by Thomson scattering. The shape of the jet is imaged with X-ray framing camera. Proton radiography is used to measure the magnetic field. To study the creation and evolution of the magnetized jet, we use the 3D FLASH code from the University of Chicago, to carry out 3D magneto-hydrodynamics simulations. FLASH is a parallel, multi-physics, finite-volume Eulerian hydrodynamics and MHD code. FLASH uses a variety of parallelization techniques including domain decomposition, mesh replication, and threading to make optimal use of hardware resources. Visualization tools such as VisIt and ParaView are used to analyze and visualize FLASH data. We are requesting a Startup allocation to test and calibrate the performance of the FLASH simulation, data analysis and visualization tools on different XSEDE clusters. The computational resources will also support two additional research projects in Liangâ??s group: (1) Laboratory gamma-ray bursts using pattwatt laser, (2) Astrophysical applications of relativistic shear flows.

children.name: TG-PHY180013
children.project_abstract: The vast majority of observed planets and stars possess self-generated, large-scale magnetic fields. These magnetic fields are sustained through the motion of electrically conducting fluids within their interiors via the so-called dynamo mechanism, which converts the kinetic energy of fluid motion into electromagnetic energy. Understanding the physics of these systems remains a challenging task due to the extreme physical parameters that characterize these systems. For instance, natural dynamos are typically dominated by two or more forces; the remaining forces are relatively small and play a very subtle role that remains poorly understood. Moreover, rotation and magnetic fields introduce inhomogeneity and anisotropy into the flow field and a general understanding of their influence on the statistics of turbulence is lacking. This proposal seeks to overcome this limitation by performing one of the most detailed investigations to date of convection-driven magnetohydrodynamic turbulence, with a particular focus on understanding how magnetic waves influence the dynamics. We will use a combination of state-of-the-art asymptotic models and high resolution direct numerical simulation of the complete set of governing equations.

children.name: TG-PHY160032
children.project_abstract: We propose to perform a series of comprehensive, first-principles numerical simulations of driven turbulence in collisionless relativistic plasmas composed of electrons and positrons, with and without synchrotron radiative cooling. Many questions about turbulence in such plasmas exist, despite it being one of the simplest limits of the kinetic equations and being relevant for astrophysical environments such as pulsar wind nebulae, active galactic nuclei jets, and black hole accretion flows. Our primary goals are to understand (1) the statistical properties of turbulence in this setting, including the energy spectra of turbulent fields at scales above and below the kinetic scales, (2) the energy distribution of non-thermal particles, and (3) the consequences and observational signatures of synchrotron radiative cooling, which provides a physical energy sink relevant for the above mentioned systems. We ask for 3.5 million SUs and 5.0 TB of archival storage for performing and analyzing these large-scale simulations.

children.name: TG-PHY180030
children.project_abstract: We request 0.352 million SUs computing allocation on Stampede2 (SKX compute nodes), 2.688 million SUs compute allocation on Comet (standard compute nodes), 46,500 GBs storage allocation on Ranch and 12,500 GBs storage allocation on SDSC Data Oasis. This proposal is based on two main projects that have been previously approved and funded by NSF: Project A. Quantum Materials from geometric and dimensionality design, reviewed and accepted by NSF-DMR, project date June 15, 2018 â?? May 31, 2021, award number: 1724791; Project B. Predictive theory, synthesis and characterization of a new type of transparent conductor without doping, reviewed and accepted by NSF-DMR, project date July 1, 2018 â?? June 30, 2021, award number: 1806939. In project A, we propose to build upon our recent successful preliminary work on geometric and dimensionality design to obtain Quantum Materials with emergent properties that greatly supersede or are even qualitatively absent from those attainable from the individual compound building blocks. The main â??knobsâ?? involve a search for specific superstructure patterns (A)n/(B)m/(A)p/(B)nâ??/â?¦ (where n, m, p, nâ??... are the repeat periods of the building blocks compounds A, B), or polymorphs with specifically reduced symmetries that deliver unusual, emergent quantum properties. In project B, we realize that the current method of choice for discovering new transparent conductors have relied on heavily doping transparent insulators until they become conducting, while unfortunately, wide gap materials are intrinsically resistant to doping of charges because of the existence of â??doping bottlenecksâ??, thus consequently, the progress in finding and optimizing such technologically critical transparent conducting oxide materials has been frustratingly slow. We propose an opposite, and likely more fruitful alternative of designing transparency in metals by looking for compounds that obey a set of â??design principlesâ? with specific band structures. The design rules for our proposed intrinsic transparent conductors are: (i) identify a compound with metallic band structure; such that (ii) it has low plasma frequency and (iii) low inter-band optical absorption across the Fermi level, and (iv) apply synthesis and characterization to the â??best of classâ? compounds. The most visible advantage of metallic transparent conductors is that their conductivity comes from their high, indigenous carrier concentration. Such rare compounds could not have been identified by chance, and currently require a trial-and-error Edisonian method.

children.name: Electron-properties
children.project_abstract: In this project, we want to calculate the electron properties of some two-dimensional systems by applying semi-classical theory.

children.name: TG-MCA07S017
children.project_abstract: We request an allocation of 4.0 million service units on the Cray XT3 "bigben", 2.0 million service units on the BlueGene/L at the San Diego Supercomputer Center, and 6.0 million service units on the TACC "ranger" to continue generating lattice QCD gauge-field configurations for a broad program of study in high-energy and nuclear physics, and for evaluating the correlation matrices of hadron operators using these configurations. Our goal is to compute the low-lying baryon and meson resonance spectrum using newly developed group-theory methods at pion masses down to 200 MeV using ab initio Markov-chain Monte Carlo integrations on anisotropic space-time lattices.  The majority of the excited states to be studied have never before been investigated in lattice QCD.  These calculations are important to many experimental efforts, but especially to those at Jefferson Laboratory.  Exotic hybrid mesons, a new form of excited matter, will be studied, and the photocouplings between some of these meson resonances will be determined.  The configurations generated will be useful for many other applications, as well, such as for determinations of nucleon-nucleon and nucleon-hyperon scattering lengths.

children.name: TG-CTS090004
children.project_abstract: The goal of this research is twofold: (i) to understand the role of turbulence in the generation of sound in modern aircraft turbo-machinery, and (ii) to develop computational methods for controlling the sound.   It is well known that certain geometrical modifications to aircraft engines can reduce their radiated noise.  However, there is no manner to predict which modifications will actually reduce the noise, resulting in lengthy---and costly---experimental programs to parametrically study candidate design modifications.  This deficiency is due to the conceptual, experimental, and computational challenges associated with turbulence-generated sound and, hence, in developing effective control methods.  By solving the compressible Navier-Stokes equations directly, this research provides foundational descriptions of the sound-generating fluid motions and subsequent development of optimized control methodologies.  The PI's code is based on advanced finite difference techniques and scales at 90\% of perfect up to 1024 processors on TACC's Ranger.  This work follows up the previous DACs TG-CTS080019 (DJB) and TG-CTS080030N (JBF).  Financial support for this work is provided by three separate grants from NASA and the AeroAcoustics Research Consortium on which the current investigators are PI's or co-PI.  It builds upon large-scale aeroacoustic simulation work from past NASA and AFOSR grants.  Total requested allocation is 14,000K SUs.

children.name: TG-CTS130034
children.project_abstract: n/a

children.name: DNS-2phase-mixing
children.project_abstract:
The present project is to investigate spray formation in a two-phase mixing layer between parallel gas and liquid streams through direct numerical simulation. The two-phase mixing layer formed between parallel gas and liquid streams is an important fundamental problem in turbulent multiphase flows. The problem is relevant to many industrial application and natural phenomena, such as air-blast atomizers in fuel injection systems and breaking waves in the ocean. 

The open-source multiphase flow solver, PARIS-Simulator, which was developed by the PI and collaborators will be used for the simulation of the present project. The volume-of-fluid method is employed to capture the interface separating the gas and liquid. The mesh resolution is set to be sufficiently fine to fully resolve the interfacial dynamics and two-phase turbulence. 

The specific goal of the present project is to investigate the effect of the inlet turbulence intensity on development of two-phase mixing layer. A digital filter based approach is employed to introduce turbulent fluctuations at the inflow boundary. Parametric studies will be performed.

children.name: TG-CTS070018N
children.project_abstract:
The main objective of the proposed research is to develop, verify, and validate an integrated multiscale model for the
investigation of variable density two-phase flows in complex environments. A novel numerical technique based on combination of a particle-based method and standard continuum approach will be developed to study interfacial phenomena of inception, growth and bursting of vapor bubbles, breakup and coalescence of liquid droplets, and interactions of the fluid surface with complex solid boundaries encountered in cooling of electronic devices, hydro-mechanics of propulsion systems, and cavitation.

Numerical modeling of these flow features using traditional mesh-based finite-volume schemes necessitates use of a time-varying adaptive grid to capture the wide range of length and time scales. The increased complexity and associated costs related to the topological changes in the computational grid are absent in the pure mesh-free techniques. However, they suffer from issues related to efficient implementation of advanced multi-physics models. The hybrid computational approach merges the locally `adaptive' nature of the mesh-free approach for interface tracking with the relative `ease' of the Eulerian finite-volume formulation for complex configurations providing an efficient and accurate numerical technique. 

The proposed developments will be performed in an existing unstructured grid finite-volume solver capable of performing large-scale computations of turbulent flows in complex configurations.
This solver was developed under the Department of Energy's Advanced Scientific Computing (ASC) program at Stanford University. %The PI was part of this program from 2000-2005 and has demonstrated high efficiency and speedup of the solver. 
The basic algorithm will be further developed to address simulations of turbulent flows at high Reynolds numbers. A number of verification and validation studies on motion of single and multiple particles in turbulent flows is planned. Once completed, this formulation will be used to study particle-turbulence interactions using direct numerical simulation. Interactions of micro-bubbles with turbulent boundary layers is important for drag reduction,  whereas studying motion of solid particles in turbulent channels is necessary to understand the sediment transport process and their effect on landform changes and impact on shipping routes. 

The emphasis of this work will be on generating and analyzing a data set for particle-turbulence interactions to understand the multiscale energy cascade mechanisms. The potential impact of this work will be in the fundamental understanding of two-phase flows and interfacial phenomena in complex environments where it is difficult to obtain detailed experimental data.  This will be a major step forward in large-scale computations of multi-physics turbulent flows. The intellectual merit includes training of two graduate students resulting in significant scholarly articles and educating them in high-performance parallel computing. The PI has received Office of Naval Research (ONR) grant (N00014-06-1-0697) for the above developments.

children.name: TG-CTS070067N
children.project_abstract: This renewal proposal is a request for computational resources at the Indiana University IBM e1350 (Big Red), the TACC Sun Constellation cluster (Ranger), and the HPSS tape storage at SDSC, to be used in our ongoing studies of turbulent drag reduction by dilute polymer solutions. The studies planned for the upcoming year will focus on development of practical skin-friction drag reduction technologies for transportation inspired by the mechanisms observed in polymer drag reduction. A cornerstone of these studies is some recent preliminary DNS studies performed in our lab which show that in turbulent channel flow, MDR conditions can be achieved with the polymer force activated only in the viscous sub-layer and the buffer layer. This observation opens up new possibilities for developing practical drag reduction technologies for use in transportation. The simulations planned for the upcoming year will include: (i) more detailed simulations of turbulent channel flow with the polymer force activated only in the viscous sub-layer and the buffer layer; (ii) simulations of turbulent channel flow with a sharp viscosity gradient imposed in the viscous sub-layer and the buffer layer; (iii) simulations of turbulent channel flow with a wire mesh in the viscous sub-layer and the buffer layer; and (iv) simulations of turbulent channel flow with flexible fibers in the viscous sub-layer and the buffer layer. The principle action of all these drag reduction technologies is to redirect a small portion of turbulence kinetic energy at the location of the peak of turbulence production in the buffer layer into a path other than the normal turbulent energy cascade. This re-routing of the turbulence kinetic energy at a given turbulent scale results in a drop in the fluctuating strain rate at that scale which, in turn, inhibits the ability of turbulence to redistribute the kinetic energy at that scale from the streamwise to the cross-stream directions through the pressure-strain term.  This results in a pileup of kinetic energy in the streamwise direction and a drop of kinetic energy in the cross-stream directions, which leads to an overall drop in the Reynolds shear-stress and a concomitant drop turbulence production, thus leading to turbulence suppression and drag reduction. These are the principle mechanisms at work in drag reduction by dilute polymer solutions. A total of 400,000 SUs is requested for these studies. Because the IU BigRed will be decommissioned from Teragrid service in March 2010, the requested allocation is split between IU, which we plan to use up to March 2010, and TACC Ranger which we plan to use thereafter. The requested tape storage at SDSC HPSS is for existing data which we have stored at this facility over the past seven years.

children.name: Converge-CFD-for-Eng
children.project_abstract: We are developing a model to simulate  the spark ignition process in an engine.  We are using Converge CFD, a commercial code, to model the engine geometry and internal flows.

children.name: Turbulent-flow-over
children.project_abstract: Turbulent flow

children.name: TG-CTS100002
children.project_abstract: Heart disease is the single most consequential disease in the industrialized world and current trends point to a worsening outlook. The thesis of the current research is that transformative ideas in modeling, computation and analysis of cardiac blood flows and associated heart sound can enable highly effective and inexpensive simulation-guided therapies and diagnostic tools for heart diseases in the not-too-distant future. Understanding cardiac flows, especially inside the left ventricle, is an essential first step to diagnosing and treating several heart related diseases. Numerous efforts have been made in analyzing cardiac flows over the past two decades through in-vitro (e.g., laboratory PIV measurements), in-vivo (e.g., phase contrast MRI) experiments and computational methods. Though medical imaging techniques such as phase contrast MRI, CT, etc., provide details about the anatomy and some gross features of the flow, not much insight related to complex fluid behavior can be obtained using these approaches. Most of the computational and laboratory (in-vitro) studies have employed simplified geometries while attempting to match physiological values in terms of key hemodynamic parameters, and ignored pivotal interactions between heart flexible tissues, especially heart valves, and complex flow patterns inside heart chambers. The long-term goal of the current project is to develop image-based, biophysically-detailed, multi-scale, multi-physics models of the ventricular blood flows in health and disease that run efficiently on large-scale, CPU/GPU clusters, and to use these models to understand the biophysics of cardiac dysfunction. In this year, we will i) validate the computational modeling of cardiac flow against the in-vivo MRI measurements, ii) investigate the effect of structural dynamics of heart valve and its interaction with hemodynamics, and iii) biochemical process on the development of heart diseases.

children.name: Plasma_simulations
children.project_abstract: This project will develop and use a parallel computing software for simulations of plasma systems for aerospace engineering.
children.pi_institution: Department of Aerospace Engineering and Engineering Mechanics

children.name: TG-CTS160009
children.project_abstract:
The long-term research goal of the PIs group is to contribute to the fundamental understanding of flow and transport phenomena relevant to the design of sustainable urban environments, such that the uncertainty in computational predictions of these phenomena can be quantified and, where possible, reduced. The computational research that is the topic of the present proposal focuses on performing simulations that will contribute to the understanding of the uncertainty related to the use of Reynolds-averaged Navier-Stokes (RANS) turbulence and turbulent heat transfer models by using high-fidelity data sets obtained from large-eddy simulations (LES). The requested computational resources will be used to perform LES simulations required to generate data sets for two different applications of interest to the PIs research group: flow and pollutant dispersion in urban environments and heat transfer. 
In the context of pollutant dispersion we propose to perform LES of the flow and dispersion in downtown Oklahoma City. We previously published a turbulence model form uncertainty quantification study for RANS simulations of this geometry, showing very promising results. The availability of high-fidelity LES data has the potential to significantly increase the impact of this study, since the data will support a detailed investigation and validation of the methodology. The LES simulation results will demonstrate whether the turbulence model form uncertainty quantification method does effectively provide realistic bounds for the prediction of the flow field, and will also be used to guide further development of the method. 
The LES simulations with heat transfer will consider realistic heat exchanger geometries to obtain a high-fidelity data base of the Reynolds stresses and the turbulent heat fluxes. This database will be used to establish and validate a novel methodology to quantify uncertainty in turbulent heat flux models. The results will be analyzed to address two main questions, similar to those previously considered for development of the Reynolds stress model uncertainty quantification method: 1) define a marker that indicates in which regions of the flow the turbulent heat flux model plausibly fails and 2) define perturbations of the turbulent heat fluxes that result in the prediction of realistic upper and lower uncertainty bounds for the temperature field.

children.name: TG-CTS120005
children.project_abstract: This is a renewal request for the project originally titled "Direct Numerical Simulation of Bubble Dynamics in Deformable Vessels", supported through allocation TG-CTS120005. Following the success of the previous allocation, detailed in the Progress Report, we request the following resources to include two additional research efforts from our group. As part of our continuing investigations into the fundamental mechanics of complex fluid flows using numerical simulations, we request 4.95M SU on Kraken and 3.01M SU on the Gordon Compute Cluster, as well as 158.52 TB of disk space. Using Kraken resources, we propose to investigate the multiscale physics of droplet breakup for multiphase nozzle flow applications. In full three-dimensional simulations solving the Navier-Stokes equations, parametric studies will examine the effects of post-shock Mach number and viscosity on the droplet breakup process. The resources on the Gordon Compute Cluster will be used to study three-dimensional instabilities and vortical structures in complex wake flows. Using a novel immersed boundary method based on lattice Green's functions, we propose direct numerical simulations of separated flows at Reynolds numbers ranging from 1,000 to 50,000.

children.name: TG-CTS100012
children.project_abstract:
Problems in which fluid and solid interact dynamically occur in various engineering and biological applications. In such problems, the solid and fluid phases are tightly coupled requiring the simultaneous solution of both phases. In addition, the high spatial and temporal resolution required for such problems tends to make traditional numerical methods computationally expensive. A hybrid method, using the lattice-Boltzmann (LB) method and finite element (FE) analysis for modeling the fluid and solid phases, respectively, can provide a number of unique features making the solution of large problems in this field feasible. This study
consists of two different projects, and each project addresses important research questions in phenomena involving fluid-structure interaction.

children.name: TG-CTS130004
children.project_abstract: n/a

children.name: Large-scale-simulati
children.project_abstract: A novel type of real-time simulation/optimization technique is being developed  to capture the dynamic nature of trajectory of the released chemical using an integrated weather-forecasting-chemistry plume transport model (WRF-CHEM) that simultaneously simulates the emission, turbulent mixing, transport, transformation, and fate of trace gases and aerosols. We have developed cooperative control laws and an optimal model based estimation filter for coupled problems of cooperative  control and sensing coordination, scheduling and planning of sensing activities, and estimation and prediction of a mobile chemical plume.
children.pi_institution: University of Texas at San Antonio

children.name: TG-CTS190055
children.project_abstract: In the United States, about two-thirds of conventional crude oil in mature fields remains unproduced because of the physics of fluid flow.  At the pore scale, chemical enhanced oil recovery (EOR) is an advanced technique to overcome the physical forces holding hydrocarbons and to increase production. Conventional oil recovery approach often involves water injection into the underground reservoir to remove the oil drop from the pore. The challenge is that strong interfacial tension (small capillary number) always prevents oil drops from squeezing through complex geological microstructures. On the one hand, surfactant flooding is an effective approach by drastically decreasing surface tension. On the other hand, Marangoni stress may impede the motion of oil drops through the pore. To date, dynamic distribution of surfactant micelles interacting with oil drops in pore constrictions remains an open question, which impacts the design principals of flow pressure, surfactant blends and complex microstructure. Fundamental understanding of these very complex processes is impossible without rigorous pore-scale modeling. In this work, we study the surfactant effect on the deformable drop motion between two particles, a well-defined model for an emulsion in the granular porous material. We propose to solve this prototype problem by performing 3D direct numerical simulation, where the front-tracking method tracks the droplet motion, and the distributed Lagrangian multiplier approach resolves the interactions between flow and solid surfaces. The 3D numerical solver is Ardekaniâ??s in-house Fortran code, parallel with MPI using the domain decomposition approach. Initial tests with an allocation from the XSEDE Campus Champions program have shown the high parallel efficiency of MPI on Stampede2 (TACC) and Bridges (PSC). This startup proposal is to request 1,600 node-hours (Stampede2) and 50,000 (core-hours) for acquisition of preliminary results and further benchmarking of the computational cost/scaling of the in-house solver. The requested XSEDE allocations are necessary for our large-scale multi-drop/multi-particle simulations, which is beyond the tractable computational capabilities of our local resources.

children.name: Propulsors
children.project_abstract: Computational hydrodynamics for propulor design

children.name: TG-CTS150053
children.project_abstract:
This is a new proposal for an XSEDE research allocation. The allocation will support the group of
the principal investigator (PI), Prof. Eckart Meiburg, to investigate transport processes involving
strongly coupled fluid and particle phases. The interactions between the two phases play a crucial
role in a number of research areas, several among them at the center of petroleum science. Prime
examples concern hydraulic fracturing processes, in which a complex fluid containing small particles
is injected into hydraulically opened rock fractures, or sediment transport within the context of
deep-sea hydrocarbon exploration, which aims to identify large-scale sediment deposits containing
oil and gas reservoirs. In order to advance our fundamental understanding of the grain-scale
processes underlying the large-scale dynamics of such particulate flows, the PI has initiated a new
research direction aimed at performing three-dimensional, high-resolution and massively parallel
grain-resolving simulations of concentrated particulate suspensions. The availability of such a
simulation tool will allow the PIs group to initiate a multitude of new research avenues, ranging
from the optimization of oil/sand separation processes to the dynamics of marine snow, which forms
the basis of several geo-engineering concepts proposed for deep-ocean CO2-sequestration.
The present project will explore the interaction of particle-laden flows and sediment beds at the
microscopic scale of individual grains via grain-resolving simulations. One goal is the development
of accurate models for their erosional and depositional behavior, which can then be incorporated
into existing macroscopic simulation codes. This will enable the PIs group to analyze multi-
scale, realistic systems involving large numbers of individual, interacting particles.

children.name: ST-TTurbine
children.project_abstract:
The focus in this project is on multiscale space–time (ST) computational analysis of a turbocharger turbine and parametric design studies to improve the turbocharger performance. Computational challenges associated with reliable analysis include accurate representation of the multiscale flow patterns and turbulence, accurate representation of the turbine geometry, and accurate representation of the rotational motion. The key components of the computational technology we developed to address these challenges include the ST variational multiscale (ST-VMS) method [1] and the ST isogeometric analysis (ST-IGA) [2]. The ST-VMS method has superior spatial and temporal accuracy in representing the flow field, geometry and motion.  The ST-IGA further increases this accuracy, in both space and time.

Accurate flow analysis of a turbocharger turbine for a given set of design parameters requires 0.5-4.0 million computational points in space, with 5 unknowns for each point, and about 2000 time steps of computation. The ST representation at least doubles the number of unknowns at each computational point in space, and triples if higher-order temporal basis functions are used. At each time step, we solve a coupled nonlinear equation system with tens of millions of unknowns. Computations of this magnitude cannot be done without efficient parallel computing, requiring parallel computing platforms with thousands of cores or hundreds of thousands of threads. The ST methods achieve increased accuracy by increasing the number of unknowns for each computational point in space, rather than by increasing the number of time steps. This way of increasing the accuracy is very suitable for parallel efficiency because it allows using larger number of threads. The ST-IGA method achieves increased accuracy by increasing the number of operations per unknown, rather than by increasing the number of unknowns. This way of increasing the accuracy is also very suitable for parallel efficiency, because it decreases the share of the communication cost.

[1] K. Takizawa and T.E. Tezduyar, "Space-Time Fluid-Structure Interaction Methods", Mathematical Models and Methods in Applied Sciences, 22 (supp02) (2012) 1230001.

[2] K. Takizawa, T.E. Tezduyar, Y. Otoguro, T. Terahara, T. Kuraishi and H. Hattori, "Turbocharger Flow Computations with the Space-Time Isogeometric Analysis (ST-IGA)", Computers & Fluids, published online, DOI: 10.1016/j.compfluid.2016.02.021 (March 2016).

children.name: TG-CTS110025
children.project_abstract: We request computing time and storage space on TeraGrid resources, preferably the newly deployed Lonestar  or similar cluster systems, to produce a suite of simulations of the flow physics of insect flight which will support the research outlined in an NSF CAREER award to the PI, ``CAREER: Flapping in the Wind -- Passive Mechanisms in Insect Wings for Flight Stabilization'' (Grant No. CBET-0954381).  In the proposed simulations, we will apply computational fluid dynamics (CFD) to model the three-dimensional aerodynamics and aeroelasticity of the deformable insect wing and to evaluate the comprehensive role of the structural flexibility in the wing's aerodynamic performance.  The numerical method couples an immersed-boundary method for the flow solver and a finite-element method for the structural solver.  The specific studies include the following three model configurations: (1) a flapping/pitching plate in hovering flight, (2) a pitching plate in a uniform freestream, and (3) a dragonfly wing model with the simplified vein structure.  The code has been developed and tested on the previous Lonestar and other clusters.  Our request for 1.0M SUs will enable a fundamental investigation of the potential benefit brought by the wing flexibility for flapping-wing propelled biomimetic micro air vehicles.

children.name: Biochemistry and Molecular Structure and Function
TG-MCA06N060
children.project_abstract:
In this renewal application, we request time to continue our investigation of the mechanism of several membrane transporters and channels using simulation methodologies. Several active transporters that use various source of energy in a living cell for their function will be investigated. Furthermore, we will also continue our research on another membrane associated phenomenon, namely mechanism of membrane binding and activation of blood coagulation factors, which constitutes the most productive project over the past funding period, and a strong collaborative effort between 5 labs at UIUC.  In fact, all of the projects are conducted in close collaboration with leading experimental groups.   All Projects address rather slow processes, thus, requiring long simulations. Furthermore, due to the need of explicit representation of the lipid and water, which play role in the mechanism of transporters, and due to the complexity of the structure, large molecular assemblies need to be simulated. Such calculations can only be carried out with the advanced TeraGrid computational resources. The size and
complexity of the function of these proteins pose a great challenge for computational studies. Over the last funding period, however, we have demonstrated through several published papers reported in the Progress Report, that large scale MD simulations can indeed significantly advance our understanding of the molecular mechanisms of energy coupling and transport phenomena in these biomolecules. Due to limited space and the need to describe 6 projects, we have delegated the progress and discussion of our preliminary results
completely to the Progress Report. Our extensive use of the allocation over the past funding period is the strongest evidence for the computational demands of such biomolecular systems. We note, however, that we have used the allocated time extremely productively and produced a record number of publications (16; please see Progress Report) over the past funding cycle. We would like to give a general clarification with regard to the length of the proposed simulations, which might be perceived as an "unjustified" aspect. All of the projects address rather slow biomolecular processes (at least on the
order of microsecond). As such, even orders of magnitude longer simulations than those described in this application
can be easily justified from a technical point of view. However, we realize that such processes (e.g., complete transport cycle) cannot be currently described in their entirety, and we can only expect to cover some of the steps involved in such processes. Therefore, in order to provide a justification that will hopefully
be satisfactory, almost in all cases we will base the length of the proposed simulations on our existing benchmarks (mostly published) of the same or comparable systems/phenomena.

children.name: Project1
children.project_abstract: Large-scale conformational transitions in protein structures play an important role in a variety of cellular processes. Understanding such transitions is one of the central tasks of modern biophysics and structural biology. Among all the available structural and biophysical methods, computer simulation is a powerful method that allows one to model the motions of proteins in atomic details. The research projects primarily focus on  molecular simulation of protein folding, protein structure prediction and protein-protein interactions.

children.name: TG-MCB190046
children.project_abstract: Inwardly rectifying potassium (Kir) channels regulate cell excitability in multiple tissues and are key modulators of cardiac and vascular electrical activity and contractility1. They are ligand gated ion channels with membrane lipids being their primary regulators. Phosphoinositol-4,5-bisphosphate (PIP2) is the absolutely required agonist for all Kir channel subfamilies while cholesterol exhibits mixed effects depending on subfamily types, and bulk anionic lipids prevalent in cytosolic leaflet of the plasma membranes are positive allosteric effector for Kir2 subfamily2,3. Kir channels should adopt several different functional states depending on differential regulatory lipid binding as well as pore blocker binding. Although a few Kir channel crystal structures have been determined4-9, the three-dimensional structures in each functional state are yet to be elucidated and dynamic properties of the channels is almost absent, which limits our understanding of the molecular mechanisms of channel function and hence the opportunities to develop small molecules to access specific states. We aim to fill up these holes in our knowledge of Kir channel gating through combining experimental approaches (x-ray crystallography, single particle-EM, single molecule FRET, in vitro functional assays, and electrophysiology) and computational modeling (docking and molecular dynamics simulations), which will advance our knowledge of how these channels undergo various conformations as well as dynamic states throughout their functional cycles.

children.name: TG-MCB140226
children.project_abstract: Selective and robust adhesion between cells is essential for development of complex multicellular organs and tissues. Classical cadherin proteins are responsible for calcium-mediated cell-cell adhesion and have been implicated in various biologically relevant processes such as neuronal connectivity and prevention of tumor cell propagation. More recently, classical members of the cadherin family of proteins have been shown to be functional mechanosensors, while non-classical members have been suggested to form part of the ``fast" mechanotransduction apparatus of the inner ear. The main goal of the proposed research is to use large-scale all-atom molecular dynamics simulations to establish --in the context of the molecular mechanics of cellular adhesion and sound transduction-- the collective response of multi-cadherin adhesion complexes to mechanical force, the relative mechanical strength of cadherin bond complexes essential for hearing, and the dynamical and elastic properties of different cadherin molecules involved in human disease.

children.name: TG-MCB090159
children.project_abstract: Molecular simulation will be used to investigate the structure of the plant cell wall and the mechanisms by which cellulose-degrading enzymes convert highly recalcitrant plant cell walls into sugars.  Research conducted as part of this proposal will enable molecular-level understanding of the natural routes for cellulose conversion to sugar, thus facilitating rational design approaches for improved biofuels processes at the industrial scale.  Three groups of projects will be pursued concurrently:  1) modeling of the plant cell wall structure from the atomistic to the micrometer length scale with a multiscale simulation approach; 2) investigation of fungal cellulases interacting with cellulose; and 3) a study of bacterial enzymes that assemble to form huge protein complexes (cellulosomes) to degrade cellulose synergistically.

children.name: TG-MCB180055
children.project_abstract: This work will use molecular dynamics simulations and vibrational frequency calculations to quantitatively interpret experimental data from vibrational probe groups with unique frequencies.  Vibrational probe groups in proteins provide data in which the structural ensemble is in slow exchange and directly appears in the lineshape, unlike most other protein analytical techniques.  We have recently cemented an approach that can provide quantitatively interpretability from vibrational probe lineshapes and directly link those lineshapes to physical and structural changes in the protein.  This computational allocation will be used to predict structural ensembles (through replica exchange simulations), to run short trajectories on submembers of those ensembles with the probe groups included, and to calculate the vibrational frequencies throughout the MD trajectories to provide lineshapes which could connect our extensive experimental data to dynamic structural ensembles. Constituting such a connection would be highly significant for many different proteins; this allocation will focus on three proteins: calmodulin (our test system), viral replicative complexes from the Hendra and Nipah viruses, and acyl carrier proteins.

children.name: TG-MCB150054
children.project_abstract: We request XSEDE allocations to study the Ras family of surface-bound proteins that regulate a variety of cell signaling pathways and LAT proteins involved in TCR-mediated signaling.  Malfunction of Ras proteins leads to many forms of cancer and developmental disorders, and there is an urgent need for therapeutic agents to abrogate defective Ras signaling. As part of our broader effort toward developing effective anti-cancer therapeutics by directly targeting Ras, we propose to conduct large-scale molecular dynamics simulations to study the structure, dynamics and druggability of Ras monomers and oligomers in solution and membrane environments. We will also investigate the roles of trans-membrane length, palmitoylation and amino acid sequence in determining membrane domain preferences and dimerization of LAT.
children.pi_institution: University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston

children.name: TG-PHY120016
children.project_abstract:
This renewal proposal seeks the continuation of our EXEDE Resources Allocation in support of our numerical relativityeffort on simulations of compact objects and their impact on astrophysics and gravitational astronomy.  Numerical relativity has truly become a tool of discovery. For gravitational wave astrophysics, it has enabled a serious conversation between researchers modeling sources of gravitational radiation and scientists focussed on the intricacies of analyzing the
data collected by interferometric detectors.  The black hole binaries continues to be one of the most transformative challenges at the interface of gravitational wave physics, astrophysics, mathematical relativity and computational
science. The challenge resides in the complexities associated with solving Einstein's equations; in the many scales involved, from those comparable to the binary orbits or gravitational wavelengths to those in the vicinity of the black holes; in the resolutions needed to accurately extract gravitational waveforms; and in the inclusion of physics to model matter sources. 
The allocation requested will support  work on  binary  black holes systems organized in the following closely related project areas: 1) Binary black holes in vacuum to expand parameter space explored to include arbitrary black hole spin orientations and to enhance a bank of  hybrid gravitational waveforms.
2) Binary black holes in astrophysical environments to investigate whether electromagnetic observations are able to detect and characterize the presence of these binary systems. 
3)Binary black holes in alternative theories of gravity to study the late inspiral and merger of a binary coalescences and distinguish between scalar-tensor gravity and general relativity.

children.name: TG-PHY190020
children.project_abstract:
The LIGO-Virgo Scientific Collaborations have already detected gravitational wave signals from the inspiral and merger of ten binary black holes, and the inspiral of a binary neutron star (event GW170817). GW170817 was also observed across the electromagnetic
spectrum by over 70 observatories. These breakthroughs ushered in the era of gravitational wave and multimessenger astronomy, allowing us to probe gravity and matter in unprecedented regimes. Robust, first-principles theoretical modeling of multimessenger sources is necessary both to build templates for detecting gravitational wave signals in upcoming observations, and for the interpretation of existing and future multimessenger signals. Such modeling requires supercomputer simulations of gravitational wave sources by solving the Einstein equations coupled to matter, electromagnetic fields and radiation. Several groups are performing such simulations focusing on subsets of the vast parameter space of compact binaries that must be explored to achieve complete understanding of the problem; our group has substantial expertise studying compact binary mergers, circumbinary accretion onto binary black holes, and the nuclear equation of state. The simulations proposed here will advance the state-of-the-art on all these fronts. In particular, we propose to perform the first systematic studies of the effects of realistic, finite temperature component of the nuclear equation of state in binary neutron star mergers, and the impact of black hole spin in magnetized accretion disks onto binary black holes.

children.name: Pleiotropic-Effects
children.project_abstract:
Study Hypothesis: 
Ongoing exposure to lipid-lowering drugs, particularly statins, have a clinically relevant ‘pleiotropic effect’ on non-cardiovascular outcomes including all-cause mortality which will manifest itself as a delayed time to event after initial virologic suppression of HIV viremia. This will contrast with a lack of such findings for other preventative cardiovascular drugs.
Population / Dataset
23,267 US veterans who achieved virologic suppression (undetectable VL at any level) after HAART initiation from 1/1/96 to 12/31/2011. All patients will be censored on 1/1/2012 (non-informative censoring) or after 13 months without clinical encounter (informative censoring, n=3,402), whichever comes first. Median follow-up will be 5.2 (IQR 2.5-9.1) years. The compiled dataset with time-updated outcomes of interest, covariates, and cofactors is updated weekly. In weeks with events, the time distance of the event to the drug exposure of interest is calculated from the day of the event.
The first day of week 1 (begin of follow-up) is the day of the first undetectable HIV viral load measurement after starting HAART.
Statistical Analysis
4) Final Model
Cox Proportional Hazard Regression for each of the four outcomes of interest and each drug class applying stabilized and truncated inverse probability weights for each exposure pattern and each week of follow-up. 
Exposure Pattern 1 (remote use of preventative category) will be the reference category to address a common concern about immeasurable bias favoring receivers of statin prescriptions (higher socio-economic status and health literacy). Immortality bias is avoided by weekly updates of the exposure status.
The proportionality assumption will be verified with Schoenfeld residuals. As less than 1/1000 of the observations points in our data is subject to informational censoring we will not include inverse-probability of censoring weights.
children.pi_institution: University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center

children.name: TG-MCA94P017
children.project_abstract: An allocation is requested for large scale computer simulations of multiple and single proton transport (PT) in biomolecular systems, coarse-graining, and large multi-scale simulations of biological assemblies. In the case of PT, the interaction of the proton with the biomolecular environment is represented by the multi-state empirical valence bond (MS-EVB) method, and the potential of mean force (PMF) along the pathway of PT is calculated by averaging over highly parallel swarms of trajectories. A novel methodology to simulate multiple protons, based on the MS-EVB, has just been developed by our group and scales nearly linearly with proton number. Large atomistic simulations of biological assemblies will be performed in order to systematically parameterize coarse-grained mesoscopic models that will be employed to examine long time- and length-scale phenomena. Multi-scale coupled simulations of embedded proteins in lipid bilayers, as well as spectrin filaments will be employed to directly examine atomistic-level couplings with mesoscopic phenomena. These studies are extremely challenging and well suited to parallel supercomputing environments.

children.name: TG-CHE190055
children.project_abstract: Deep Eutectic Solvents (DESs) has recently escalated since the potential for various chemical engineering processes. While they share many characteristics and properties with ionic liquids, they usually consist of ionic salt and hydrogen bond donor (HBD). DESs show eutectic phase behavior, which stands for remarkably lower melting temperature compared to the original component materials. This feature enables DESs to be very useful chemical solvents with diversity of molecular design, especially in polymer synthesis. Polymer solutions can show temperature dependent phase behavior of mixing and de-mixing. However, the microscopic physical origin of such phase behaviors of polymer in DES is not systematically understood. Polymers in DESs can be accurately modeled by symmetry-adapted perturbation theory (SAPT) which provides physically-motivated ab-initio force field with polarizable model. Therefore, we will evaluate the polarizable SAPT force fields of polymer/DESs by obtaining phase equilibria of polymer/DESs. We are going to develop a framework of ML for phase equilibria with simple models and we will utilize ML techniques with MD simulation for polymer/DESs.

children.name: TG-CHE190010
children.project_abstract: One of the most significant challenges for the computational understanding of current materials and the design of new materials for energy storage and conversion is the limitation in accessible time scales. A direct simulation of atomic motion is limited to picoseconds when the forces and energies are based upon density functional theory (DFT) calculations. The relevant timescale for the function of batteries and fuel cells, however, are on a human timescale of second to minutes. In this proposal we will develop the adaptive kinetic Monte Carlo method for use with DFT codes to model novel materials that can function as electrolytes and electrodes in Li batteries and solid oxide fuel cells which can accelerate and select reactions of interest. The parallel resources offered by the XSEDE program will allow us to explore the potential energy surface around stable states and determine the mechanism and rates of possible reaction mechanisms. We have, and will continue over the duration of this project, to develop the EON code which manages the individual calculations that identify saddle points on the potential landscape which correspond to each possible reaction mechanism and collects the information to evolve the system over timescales set by the elementary reaction mechanisms. Importantly, this methodology does not require intuition from the user so that reaction pathways are determined automatically and can be surprising and complex, if that is the nature of the potential energy landscape. We show, in this proposal, that we will be able to efficiently use the XSEDE resources for these calculations. This project will also enable us to accomplish the goals set out in our NSF funded projects to improve the efficiency of our computational methods as well as model intercalation and diffusion in battery materials and the chemistry at catalytic surfaces.

children.name: TG-CHE160044
children.project_abstract:
This proposal requests a new research allocation of 250000 SUs, for Stampede
Comet and SuperMIC, to continue the development of software for
biochemical simulations and its application to investigate the DNA dealkylase
enzymes of the AlkB family. Our development efforts center around novel
classical polarizable potentials, GEM and AMOEBA, and their use for hybrid QM/MM
simulations. The applications portion of this proposal involves the investigation
of the structure, function and reaction mechanism of AlkB family enzymes by
hybrid QM/MM and classical simulations, as well as bioinformatics methods. This 
research is supported by R01GM108583 to the PI (G. Andres Cisneros) from the 
National Institute of General Medical Sciences (NIGMS). We previously received a 
starter allocation with resources granted on Stampede, Comet and SuperMIC. This 
initial allocation allowed us to port and begin tuning our parallel implementation of GEM 
(and AMOEBA), pmemd.gem. The purpose of this request is to continue the development
and improvement of pmemd.gem, as well as to perform classical MD simulations
required for our investigation of the AlkB enzymes.

children.name: TG-CHE140009
children.project_abstract: n/a

children.name: TG-CHE170085
children.project_abstract: Quantum mechanical methods are fundamentally important for understanding many complex physical phenomena. However, due to their poor scaling, these ab initio methods are often intractable for even moderately sized physical systems when high levels of theory are utilized. Thus, large-scale computational resources are needed in order to provide accurate descriptions and meaningful predictions using quantum mechanical methods. Additionally, in some cases, innovative computational strategies must be developed and implemented to overcome the scaling and sampling limitations. In the current proposal, we describe two computational projects using ab initio quantum mechanical methods and novel methodologies aimed at understanding complex chemical phenomena, including the interactions between carbon dioxide and hydrocarbons in the condensed phase, and the selective extraction of lanthanide metals using organic chelators.

children.name: TG-MCB170095
children.project_abstract: The human voltage gated potassium channel Kv11.1 encoded by the hERG gene is the key repolarizing K+ current in cardiomyocytes.  Many drugs are known to block IKr, which can lead to an acquired long QT syndrome, the standard clinical ECG-based indicator for an increased risk of ventricular arrhythmias such as Tosades de Pointes (TdP). In fact, hERG block is a common side effect for drugs and drug candidates, leading to their withdrawal from the market. However, hERG blockers have very different proclivities for arrhythmogenesis and thus cardiac safety profiles. We hypothesize that the fundamental mode of drug interaction, derived from the unique structure activity relationship of a drug, determines the resultant effects on cardiac electrical activity in cells and tissue. In addition, female sex has been shown to be an independent risk factor for an acquired LQTS and TdP, and while our recent work has shown that drugs and estrogen can coexist in the hERG pore, the molecular mechanisms of these interactions and their effects remain unknown. Multiple unbiased and restrained molecular dynamics (MD) simulations on XSEDE CPU and GPU resources reaching tens of microseconds in total are ideally suited to explore atomic-scale basis of these effects. Now is also the best time for these studies since high-resolution cryo-EM structures of an open state hERG and a closed state of a homologous rEAG channels have recently become available. We have already begun testing hERG open state stability through long unbiased MD simulations using our local resources and an active DE Shaw Anton 2 allocation. Also, we have been working on homology models of hERG inactivated state through structural modeling with ROSETTA supported by electrophysiological measurements on mutant channels by our experimental collaborators. Multiple MD simulations will be crucially important for the validation of those models by considering different applied voltages, as well as channel mutants that are known to preferentially stabilize hERG in distinct conformational states. Accurate empirical force field parameters for several cardiac-safe and pro-arrhythmic hERG-blocking drugs have been developed in our laboratory as well using both local resources and a startup XSEDE allocation on Comet at SDSC.  We will be validating those parameters and computing drug membrane partitioning thermodynamics and permeation rates using umbrella sampling MD simulations for drug/hydrated lipid membrane systems. This information will be used to perform multi-microsecond drug and hormone â??floodingâ? unbiased and umbrella sampling all-atom MD simulations with hERG in distinct conformational states. We will also investigate the effects of drug ionization states as well as applied voltage, which can all modulate drug binding affinities and thus their pro-arrhythmia proclivities in hope to obtain an accurate molecular picture of channel state-dependent drug binding and egress pathways along with corresponding energetics.  This information will allow us to predict pro-arrhythmia determinants at the molecular level and will help to develop new pharmaceuticals with improved cardiac safety profiles.

children.name: TG-MCA98N017
children.project_abstract: Theoretical studies of biological systems allow for structure-function relationships to be developed at an atomic-level of detail, including contributions associated with high-energy states difficult to study experimentally.  Such knowledge can lead to a better understanding of a variety of physiological processes, including those associated with disease states, ultimately leading to the development of treatments for such disease states.  The general objectives of the present proposal are 1) to extend the applicability and accuracy of empirical force field based theoretical studies of biological and pharmacological molecules, 2) apply theoretical methods to relate atomic details of the structural and dynamical properties of biomolecules to their biological activity and 3) apply computational methods for the identification and optimization of compounds with the potential to act as inhibitors for proteins of therapeutic interest.

children.name: TG-MCB100145
children.project_abstract: A new research allocation of 3.4M SU's is requested for the October 2010-September 2011 period on the AQSL (Abe, Queen Bee, Steele, and Lonestar) Teragrid clusters to perform large scale parallel replica exchange molecular dynamics simulations of macromolecular complexes. The research we plan to perform, which is funded by NIH grant GM30580 to RML, addresses forefront biophysical issues concerning basic mechanisms of molecular recognition in biological systems. The software infrastructure we propose to employ is optimized through parallelism at various levels of the calculation and can make efficient use of the hardware configuration of the AQSL Teragrid clusters. This request follows a start-up allocation of 50,000 SU's (no. MCB100089) which allowed us to port the necessary code and perform benchmarking tests.

children.name: Ion-permeation
children.project_abstract:
Lipid membranes are vital for all living organisms. They can provide a barrier to prevent exchange between the inner and outer parts of the cell. However, still some types of ions can permeate directly from that depending on the type and composition of the membrane.
The mechanism of this passive permeation of ions is still under debate and some aspects of it is unknown. For positively charged ions, like potassium, the interaction with the charged phosphate head groups plays an important role in the permeation. Computer simulation are one of the powerful tools to shed light on this phenomenon.

In this project, a new set of reaction coordinates will be introduced to consider the interaction of the potassium ion with phosphate groups. The complete pathway of the permeation will be found in the space of these new reaction coordinates by means of a well-known method called Milestoning in which the thermodynamics and kinetics of this permeation will be obtained. The results will be compared to the available experimental data. 

This start up project will be done on potassium. This allocation will be helpful to understand and test these set of reaction coordinate for a research plan for different types of ions with different charges and sizes which we expect to submit later as a research allocation project.

For this study NAMD software will be used which is available on Lonestar 5.

We need to cover a region of 35*35 Angstroms with resolution of 1 Angstrom to find the thermodynamics and kinetics of this permeation. To achieve our goal we need to set up 35*35=1225 short simulations of 0.5 nanosecond each. This is equivalent to ~0.6 microseconds in total. The benchmarks obtained for a similar system to be approximately 14-15ns/day  on Lonestar 5 if we use 2 node/day (48SU). So the whole project can be performed with a 2100SU startup project on Lonestar5.

All the analysis will be performed on the local computers after moving the files.
The result is expected to be published in a peer reviewed journal.
children.pi_institution: Institute for Computational Engineering and Science

children.name: TG-MCB100146
children.project_abstract:
Mechanical phenomena affect nearly every aspect of cellular biology and function, yet the underlying mechanisms of how mechanical forces and biochemical signals interact is not clearly understood. In this proposal, we request for TeraGrid computational facilities to approach cellular mechanotransduction from a computational viewpoint and shed light on two important sub-cellular phenomena in which the role of mechanical factors are decisive: focal adhesion formation and nucleocytoplasmic transport. Individual molecules are suggested to be molecular mechanosensors at focal adhesions. These molecules alter their binding activity upon exposure to external force. We will investigate the validity of this suggestion and evaluate the mechanisms by which single molecules at focal adhesions could act as molecular mechanosensors. 
While our main focus in this proposal will be investigation of focal adhesion formation, we also aim to shed light on nucleocytoplasmic transport across the nuclear pore complex (NPC) using two different approaches: (1) all atomic simulations and (2) coarse-grained modeling. It is suggested that NPC tpr proteins interact with transport factors crm1 and importin-β/α to facilitate the cargo-complex translocation across the NPC. The alleged hydrophobic binding sites, however, are not determined yet. We suggest a thorough molecular dynamic simulation to find those sites. Results from this project could reveal possible mechanisms for facilitated transport. Taking into account the results of all-atomic simulations, we also will develop a coarse-grained model of the whole structure of the NPC to provide a big picture of nucleocytoplasmic transport and find out the specific role of some important factors in active transport, such as FG-repeat density in the pore, active cargo-FG hydrophobic binding affinity, aspect ratio of active cargo, and existing of competing factors within the pore for FG-repeat binding sites. The 9,900,000 SUs we are requesting will let us proceed with these projects and reveal important aspects of each of them at different scales.

children.name: TG-MCB090163
children.project_abstract: n/a

children.name: TG-AST130007
children.project_abstract: We propose to run a set of hydrodynamic cosmological simulations that include a complete treatment of galaxy formation physics together with Self-Interacting Dark Matter (SIDM). With them we will search for a solution to the discrepancy between the observed dark matter central densities in galaxies and galaxy clusters, and those predicted by our standard model of cosmological structure formation. For this we will explore the phenomenological consequences of two qualitatively different classes of solutions: self-interacting dark matter and stellar feedback. Our work will contribute to our understanding on how baryons transform the central structure of dark matter halos, how self-interacting dark matter affects galaxy formation, and what are the resulting central densities of dark matter halos when self-interacting dark matter acts together with baryonic processes. We will provide the best constraints available on how strong can dark matter self-interact, and demonstrate if SIDM is a viable solution to the small scale problems that challenge our standard CDM paradigm.

children.name: Binary-Neutron-Star
children.project_abstract:
The Relativity group of the Theory Group at UT Austin has become a collaborator in the WhiskyTHC collaboration. WhiskyTHC is a state of the art General Relativistic (GR) hydrodynamics code which can provide simulations of neutron stars (NSs) with high fidelity. WhiskyTHC uses the Carpet infrastructure for AMR grid management. Carpet is widely used to support large-scale GR scientific codes.

This code will allow evolution of neutron star binaries, and the evolved gravitational radiation. The solution space is quite large, and we will sample it as efficiently as possible. (For a given equation of state, the NS collision parameter space is 8-dimensional: the two masses, and the three components of each of the spins of the incident NSs. For comparison, the BH parameter space is only seven dimensional: in the collision of BHs, only the mass ratio is significant (not both masses separately), since the BH problem scales straightforwardly with the total mass.)

children.name: TG-AST090005
children.project_abstract:
The first billion years of cosmic time witnessed the formation 
of the first galaxies and stars, whose UV radiation gradually 
burned through the surrounding intergalactic medium ("IGM"), 
transforming it from a cold, diffuse gas of neutral atoms to a 
10,000 K - hot gas of ions and electrons. This "epoch of reionization" 
("EOR") filled space with a patchwork quilt of giant ionized zones 
and neutral zones, until the ionized zones eventually grew to 
fill all of space. The EOR is one of the last unexplored 
windows of cosmic time subject to direct observation, and a 
crucial missing link in our astronomical confirmation of the 
current standard theory of cosmology, the Cold Dark Matter 
("CDM") model. Towards that end, we have pioneered the 
large-scale numerical simulation of this phenomenon, to 
predict a host of observable consequences with which to 
test the theory, ranging from the redshifted cosmic 
21cm background from hydrogen atoms in the neutral zones 
during the EOR, to the angular fluctuations of the 
cosmic microwave background introduced when those photons 
scatter off free electrons in the ionized zones, to the 
quenching of light from the earliest galaxies when their 
Lyman alpha emission lines resonantly scatter off the trace of 
neutral atoms left behind inside the ionized zones. EOR 
simulations involve two ingredients: (1) gravitational N-body 
simulation of large-scale structure formation in a volume 
large enough to provide a fair sample of the universe and 
the geometry of its patchy ionization, with a large enough 
particle number to resolve the formation of all the galactic 
halos that are important sources of reionization photons; and 
(2) a separate simulation to transport the ionizing radiation 
released by all those galactic sources, until the ionized 
patches created by these galaxies eventually grow to overlap. 
The N-body simulation provides the underlying gas density 
field of the IGM into which that radiation propagates, 
and identifies all the galactic halos that form over 
time to supply the reionization photons. The radiative transfer 
simulation performs ray-tracing from each source while 
solving the nonequilibrium ionization balance rate equations 
at each point in space, to determine the opacity. We have 
recently developed two, new, massively- parallel methods for 
these two ingredients, more powerful than those we previously 
used to simulate cosmic reionization, and we propose here to 
use them to advance the study of this subject to a new level, 
by utilizing the capabilities of the new Sun Constellation 
cluster at TACC (Ranger). For the N-body simulation, we will 
employ our new CUBEP3M method, a newly parallelized version 
of the Particle-Particle/Particle-Mesh code, to perform an 
unprecedented, extremely high-resolution study (with 165 billion 
particles) of an intermediate-sized volume, to show how the 
IGM gas is clumpy on very small scales, which greatly affects 
its recombination rate and the rate of large-scale reionization, 
and to resolve the smallest galactic halos -- the "minihalos" of 
mass below 100 million solar masses. What makes these high-resolution 
N-body results so special is that they will not only have extremely 
high mass resolution, they will have it in a large enough volume to 
show how this small-scale structure is modulated by longer-wavelength 
density fluctuations, of the kind responsible for the large-scale 
structure of the universe. This will then provide a spatially-varying, 
statistical subgrid model for IGM gas clumping and minihalos to use 
in a large-scale reionization simulation of a much larger volume, 
utilizing our newly parallelized radiative transfer code, C2-RAY 
("Conservative, Causal, Ray-Tracing"), to study the effect of gas 
clumping and minihalos on global reionization, as we transfer the 
radiation from the millions of galaxies within that volume. These 
two simulations, and two smaller-volume C2-Ray simulations that
