will use the new N-body results directly to test the subgrid model, 
will together require 7 million SUs requested here. They will 
reveal the critical impact of spatially-varying gas clumping and 
minihalos on cosmic reionization for the first time. 

[NEW PARAGRAPH]
Among the fundamental underpinings of the CDM universe cosmology which
our studies of cosmic reionization adopt as the "standard model" are
the following: (1) the primordial density fluctuations responsible for
structure formation were Gaussian random noise with a scale-invariant
power spectrum, as predicted by theories of cosmic inflation; and (2)
the total mass-energy density of the universe today is dominated by
dark energy that acts like Einstein's cosmological constant and has
caused cosmic expansion to accelerate. These underpinnings are
consistent with current observations but will be subject to
significantly improved test by upcoming, large-scale galaxy redshift
surveys of the epoch from the end of the EOR down to the present. For
this purpose, it is necessary to simulate the large-scale structure
formation in a very large volume, large enough to compare directly
with the entire volume of these future galaxy surveys. This must be as
large as ~100 cubic Gigaparsecs,to probe the shape of the primordial
density fluctuation power spectrum and constrain non-Gaussianity,
measure the Baryon Acoustic Oscillations ("BAO") and probe the nature
of dark energy. We propose to use the same CubeP3M N-body code we
described above for smaller-volume reionization simulations, also to
perform a series of very large-scale structure ("VLSS") simulations to
model these upcoming galaxy surveys. These latter simulations will
require an additional 2.5 million SUs, bringing the total requested
here to 9.5 million SUs.

children.name: TG-AST120025
children.project_abstract:
We request computing time on the XSEDE resources to perform high-resolution, cosmological simulations of galaxy formation which will resolve the interstellar medium (ISM) physics with un- precedented realism. In our new physical model, the ISM is explicitly resolved into dense molecular clouds. Star formation is confined to these high-density regions and, as it proceeds, injects large quantities of energy and momentum into the surrounding medium via stellar feedback. This stellar feedback is critical to produce realistic galaxies and to generate powerful galactic winds. These galactic winds also have important effects on the circum-galactic and intergalactic media (CGM, IGM), and understanding them is a key frontier.
For the first time, we incorporate all the important stellar feedback mechanisms (radiation pressure in the ultra-violet, optical, and infrared; stellar winds; supernova explosions of Types I & II; and photoionization heating in HII regions) in a self-consistent manner. The combination of resolved, clumpy ISM and positive reinforcement of different feedback mechanisms produce powerful galactic winds with properties consistent with observations without ad hoc prescriptions, which previous simulations typically have had to incorporate.
For this initial study, our proposed simulations concentrate on the high-redshift Universe. This regime, of intense observational focus, is less computational expensive and will therefore allow us to simulate a range of galaxies (from dwarfs to massive disks) to develop a systematic understanding of the scale-dependent physics.
Thanks to their novelty and realism, the proposed set of simulations will be analyzed to address a wide array of timely scientific questions. We will study the evolution of the galactic ISM, galaxy growth and its self-regulation via galactic winds, the interaction of infalling material with galactic outflows, metal dispersion in the CGM and IGM, as well as the thermal, kinematic, and ionizing effects of galaxies on their surroundings. XSEDE resources provide the computational power necessary to perform our simulations, which have outgrown our local computing resources. We will use the well-tested smooth particle hydrodynamics (SPH) code Gadget-3, which we significantly expanded to implement more realistic cooling, star formation, and feedback modules (also verified in a series of recent papers describing them).
We have successfully performed multiple medium-sized runs using the production version of the code on a university-based computing cluster and have successfully compiled and run basic scaling tests with the same version of the code on Ranger at TACC. This enabled us to estimate runtime requirements for our proposed simulations, totaling 1.76 million SUs.

children.name: Hobby-Eberly-Telesco
children.project_abstract: The Hobby-Eberly Telescope Dark Energy Experiment will measure the expansion rate of the universe as it was 9 billion years ago. This project includes a significant upgrade to the HET and a substantial observing program. It is one of the few premier observing programs in the world, and it is led by the University of Texas. The total amount of data it will generate is around 10 Pb. We hope to use TACC facilities to host and analyze the data. We will explore aspects for big data analysis from storage to access to new statistical and visualization tools.

children.name: TG-AST090040
children.project_abstract: The study of cosmological structure formation, particularly when baryonic effects are included, is a manifestly nonlinear task, requiring significant amounts of computational power.  To this end, we are requesting a total of 6.2 million CPU hours and 18 terabytes of persistent (non-purging) disk space on several NSF computational platforms.  This request is for a large, multi-investigator collaboration spanning half a dozen institutions, and will support five primary research threads:  i) Structure formation in the high-redshift universe; ii) The astrophysics of galaxy clusters; iii) The warm-hot intergalactic medium; iv) Galactic chemical evolution; and v) The hydrodynamic histories of elliptical galaxies. These research threads are all related by their use of a cutting-edge cosmological adaptive mesh refinement code, Enzo, and by the inclusion of advanced baryonic physics (including magnetic fields, cosmic rays, star formation and feedback, AGN feedback, and radiative cooling) into large simulations of cosmological structure formation and evolution.

children.name: TG-AST140023
children.project_abstract: n/a

children.name: TG-AST180036
children.project_abstract: The research presented in this proposal addresses a long-standing problem in extragalactic astrophysics, namely the mismatch between the ubiquity of fast moving, cold gas in and around various types of galaxies throughout cosmic time, and basic hydrodynamical theory which predicts that cold gas will be destroyed before it can be accelerated by ram pressure (such a provided by supernovae feedback in galaxies). Our recent results indicate that we can potentially solve that puzzle in a region of parameter space which allows for the re-formation of the cold gas faster than its destruction through hydrodynamical instabilities. However, thus far we could merely show that this parameter space exists. In the proposed research, we want to bridge the gap to observations, and extend our work to realistic setups which include a non-homogeneous wind model, magnetic fields, and anisotropic thermal conduction. Each of these processes are present in galactic environments and will influence the outcome substantially, and are thus crucial to include in order to assess if this effect can indeed solve the "entrainment problem", and to compare our findings to observations.

children.name: lensing2
children.project_abstract: The most intense star formation that ever occurred in the universe was hosted by galaxies in the first few billion years after the Big Bang, heavily obscured by cosmic "dust" which blocks direct viewing of the young, forming stars. Instead, astronomers observe these galaxies using radio telescopes such as the Very Large Array in New Mexico and the ALMA telescope in Chile. My work utilizes natural "cosmic microscopes" - taking advantage of intervening foreground galaxies between us and the more distant dusty galaxies, which magnify our view of the background galaxies in a process called gravitational lensing. In order to understand the intrinsic properties of the background galaxies, though, we must model the effects of this lensing. This is computationally difficult for data from the telescopes listed above, because they measure the Fourier transform of the sky instead of a direct image of it, and each observational dataset contains millions of observables. I have written advanced codes to do this modeling.  For the startup portion of this project over the past months, I got the codes to run on TACC's stampede2 system and ran some test analyses. I am now ready to continue this work under a standard research allocation.

children.name: STAR-Technip
children.project_abstract: Numerical wave tank simulations to validate of Euler-Overlay Method

children.name: TG-GEO170003
children.project_abstract:
Knowledge of the physical and chemical states of the Earthâ??s rocky mantle is crucial to our understanding of various geological processes, such as plate tectonics, global heat loss, geochemical cycling, and the processes that led to the development of our planetâ??s unique habitat. Seismological and geochemical observations provide insights into the physics and chemistry of the Earthâ??s interior. However, only by comparing mineral physics data (physical properties) with the seismological observations can we disentangle the thermal state of the deep Earth from its chemistry. Conventionally, as a first order approximation, the Earthâ??s mantle is thought to be composed of a homogenous pyrolite. But, in reality, this region is far from being homogeneous. The distinct trace element signatures in mid ocean ridge and ocean island basalts reveal the heterogeneity in the Earthâ??s mantle. Although the scale of the heterogeneity is unknown, it is likely that large regions of the mantle are composed of a depleted harzburgite and enriched crustal fractions. We have limited knowledge of the thermodynamics and physical properties of mineral phases in these subducted crusts at high pressures.
We propose to examine the elasticity of hollandite along a ternary system- [(K,Na)(1-x)CaxAl(1+x)Si(3-x)O8] where, 0<x<1. We will explore the pressure dependence (0-150 GPa) of the ferroelastic transition between hollandite I and hollandite-II. We will explore the effect of iron on the elasticity of hollandite. In particular, how iron spin pairing transition couples with the ferroelastic transition. Finally we will also explore the effect of hydrogen defect on the structure and elasticity of hollandite. We will integrate our understanding of elasticity of hollandite with other major phases such as stishovite and majorite garnet to constrain the elasticit signatures of the deeply subducted continental crust in the Earthâ??s mantle.

children.name: TG-DMR180040
children.project_abstract: We request computing time on XSEDE resources for computational screening of organic semiconductors. We will develop and apply the organic crystal structure prediction code to search for organic semiconductors with enhanced charge mobility. We will utilize a range of computational models to investigate the stability at both zero and finite temperatures, as well as the charge carrier mobilities. Based on the reviews which we received from the last quarter, we decided to scale down the efforts and request a total of 2.16 M hours on Stampede2 to perform crystal structure prediction and properties calculations on two model molecules for organic electronic applications.

children.name: TG-DMR140129
children.project_abstract: We request XSEDE resources to perform high performance, parallel GPU and CPU enabled Monte Carlo and molecular dynamics simulations of colloidal crystallization and self-assembly. 24.14M SUs are requested to investigate solid-solid phase transitions, complex crystal nucleation, binary mixtures, plastic-solid phase transitions, depletion-driven assembly, assembly of concave particles, driven systems of colloids, and other soft matter assembly systems, for the purposes of elucidating and engineering the thermodynamic-driven and non-equilibrium assembly of nanoparticle and colloidal systems. All projects described are funded by four grants from the National Science Foundation, two NSF graduate student fellowships, one grant from the U.S. Department of Energy, one grant from the Army Research Office, and a five-year grant from the Simons Foundation. Using our HOOMD-blue particle simulation code along with the HPMC plugin for hard particle Monte Carlo and the DEM plug in for molecular dynamics simulations of hard shapes, we will run simulations of anisotropic hard particles, point particles with interaction potentials and other interactions to sample equilibrium and dynamic properties of these systems. The SUs requested will support the PhD thesis research and postdoctoral research of 27 young computational physicists, materials scientists, chemical engineers, and macromolecular scientists in the Glotzer Group at the University of Michigan. Our request amounts to roughly 894,000 SUs per person.

children.name: TG-DMR090023
children.project_abstract: n/a

children.name: TG-DMR160007
children.project_abstract: We request computing time and storage space on the XSEDE network for carrying out first-principles density functional theory (DFT) calculations to study perovskite structure materials for energy applications. There are three specific projects for which the resources are being requested. The first project goal is to develop an atomic-scale understanding of the electronic structure of surfaces of Fe-based perovskite oxides and relate it to their oxygen electrocatalytic activity by carrying out DFT calculations in conjunction with aberration-corrected scanning transmission electron microscopy experiments.  The second project is on strain engineering of organic lead halides for photovoltaic applications. The third project is to perform a search for Bi-based organic-inorganic materials as a substitute for the carcinogenic organic-lead halides as photovoltaic materials.  We request a total of 2,531,000 service units (SU) distributed over Stampede (2,000,000 SU) and Comet (531,000 SU) along with 1 TB storage space each on Ranch and Oasis.

children.name: TG-DMR090006
children.project_abstract:
As part of an academic/industrial collaborative effort between the University of Illinois and General Motors R\&D through NSF's GOALI program, we are beginning a computational study of dislocation/solute interactions in HCP metals, specifically for the critical problem of building accurate deformation models for magnesium alloys.  We model pure Mg dislocation geometries and properties, as well as the effects of Al solutes via two main tasks: 1. determining the dislocation core for basal and non-basal dislocations in pure Mg at zero and finite stress using density-functional theory with flexible boundary conditions; 2. substituting Al at sites around the Mg dislocation cores to determine solute/dislocation interactions with density-functional theory.  Key to this work are high-performance computing resources to perform the study.

The objective of this study is to apply electronic-structure methods for the study of dislocations for Mg and Mg alloys and incorporate this data into finite-element constitutive models.  Connecting fundamental electronic structure studies of deformation at the atomistic scale to finite element modeling for new alloy design and direct incorporation in industrial usage is a potentially transformative concept in materials science and engineering.  It offers the promise to move beyond traditional trial-and-error approaches, and the combined talents of the academic-industrial collaboration is uniquely positioned to approach this problem.  Computational resources from TeraGrid combined with dedicated local resources are necessary to expand the work to enough dislocation types, stresses, and solute sites to provide meaningful data.

children.name: TG-DMR970008S
children.project_abstract: Our group studies the structural, thermodynamic, kinetic, electronic, and electrochemical properties of materials for energy technologies with a focus on the ab initio prediction for complex materials. Using our grant from last year, we accomplished most of what we outlined as a plan of research in last year's proposal, and submitted several papers based on that work: 1) we have determined the equilibrium particle shapes for olivine structure LiFePO4 and LiMnPO4 and calculated the energy barriers for lithium in the bulk region to diffuse out at the (010) surface. These factors control the morphology and performance of this important class of Li ion battery cathode materials. 2) We have calculated the bending strain energy, defect energy and interfacial energy in TiS2 nanotubes, and determined the optimal bending angle. These calculations permit a better understanding of the structure of inorganic nanotubes, which is crucial to accurate calculations of their electrochemical and other properties for Li ion battery applications. 3) We constructed the Pourbaix diagrams for both bulk and 0.5 to 2 nm diameter Pt nanoparticles, which helps us understand and improve the stability of Pt nanocatalysts. 4) We developed a method based on the cluster expansion formalism that makes highly accurate thermodynamic calculations of nano-structured materials computationally feasible, and applied it successfully to our test system of Au-Pd nanoparticles to predict ground state structures. This method allows us to extend our computational work to alloyed nanoparticles that are too large for the fully ab initio approach. We are requesting an allocation to allow us to advance our studies on several areas: in Li ion battery materials we will 1) continue the study of LiFePO4 nanoparticles with adsorbates to study how the equilibrium particle morphology is modified by different solution environments and predict optimal synthesis conditions, and 2) study lithiation reactions in alloyed metallic and oxide nanoparticles. 3) In fuel cell catalysis we will investigate the effects of alloying on Pt catalysts. 4) We will also evaluate different quantum mechanical, continuum and hybrid model in the study of electrochemical properties of room temperature ionic liquids for electrolyte and other applications. 5) We will evaluate the optical and transport properties of candidate materials for photovoltaic applications using the GW approximation. The amount of units we are requesting this year is higher than last year's allocation because of the fact that we are expanding our research program to include additional areas of energy technologies and also because of the increased complexity in our calculations.

children.name: TG-DMR130080
children.project_abstract: Heusler alloys are ternary metallic compounds with a number of technologically important properties. Initial attention to these materials was attributed to the discovery of the magnetic shape-memory effect in Ni2MnGa, which is now known as a prototypical "smart material". The magneto-structural coupling in Ni2MnGa allows a large external magnetic field to induce up to 10% reversible strain in this material, and vice versa, stress can cause up to 30% change in the magnetization. These properties gave rise to a number of new technologies, for example unique sensors and actuators. Search for better Heusler alloys becomes more intensive every year. Yet, microscopic understanding of what we are looking for in Heusler alloys is missing, because we have not identified the key physical observables that relate desired parameters of Heusler alloys with their chemical composition. The main objective of this project is to understand electronic origins of structural changes in Heusler alloys, and obtain theoretical phase diagrams, that would allow mapping of the physical properties of interest on the changes in stoichiometry of the material. It is proposed here to undertake a study of the electron-phonon interactions that should lead to a clearer connection between the electronic structure, phonon anomalies and chemical compositions. If the electron-phonon coupling is the key parameter that needs to be optimized, large-scale data based search in Heusler alloys can be undertaken.

children.name: TG-MCA94P030
children.project_abstract: Our group is engaged in research in the fields of theoretical condensed matter physics and materials science. Using computers as a primary tool a wide range of properties and materials are studied with the twin goals of understanding microscopic mechanisms and their relationship to experimental observations, and using this understanding to make predictions about real materials and devices. The materials and systems studied all either have important technological applications, address physical questions of fundamental importance, or provide a testing ground for new theoretical and computational techniques.

children.name: TG-DMR120025
children.project_abstract:
Next-generation energy systems, such as fuel cells, nuclear reactors, batteries, advanced oil and gas exploration systems will require materials that perform reliably under increasingly extreme conditions. Examples of extreme conditions encountered in energy systems include exposure to chemically reactive  corrosive  environments as aqueous fluids in fossil and nuclear plants, fuel cells, and water splitting; reactive and non-reactive gases at extreme temperatures and pressures as in solid oxide fuel cells, hydrogen transmission and storage, nuclear reactors; ionic liquids in fuel cells and batteries; steam, gases and hydrocarbons in oil shale processing, coal liquefaction. The chemical reactivity in these environments is further accelerated in the presence of mechanical loads and radiation fields. For the general infrastructure, it is not uncommon to quote 3-5% of the Gross National Product of any country as the corrosion bill to the society [1]. Overcoming the barriers caused by the inability of todays materials to function reliably in these extremes is a major challenge to enable secure, affordable energy with minimal adverse environmental impacts. Revolutionary advances are needed in reducing the degradation of materials due to reactivity in these aggressive conditions to meet the future energy challenges. For this purpose, a fundamental understanding of the thermodynamics and kinetics of unit processes that occur at the atomic level under such corrosive environments is needed (1).
The goal of this research is to quantitatively uncover the mechanisms that govern the corrosion kinetics in two energy-related contexts. The results of this research will ultimately lead to the development of physics-based predictive models for corrosion and guide the design of more durable material surfaces. The first context is the corrosion of zirconium alloys that are currently the canonical nuclear fuel cladding in water cooled nuclear reactors (the most commonly used nuclear plants in the world). The second is corrosion of low-chromium steels in oil fields containing hydrogen sulfide rich fluids. While these two systems look different in application, the scientific commonality we focus is on the stability of passive surface films that are critical in corrosion of both material systems - those are the zirconium oxide surface films in the former, and iron sulfide surface films in the latter. We will accomplish our goal through a multiscale computational approach linking first-principles electronic structure methods with atomistic simulations. In the rest of this section we describe the current state-of-knowledge of the mechanistic aspects of corrosion in the above mentioned energy-related systems. This description will allow us later on defining our Proposed Research and justifying the requested computational resources for this research.

children.name: A-ch5111
children.project_abstract:
This project aims at developing: (1) a deeper understanding of the fundamental behavior and properties of defect and dopant complexes in strained Si layers and their interfaces with a-SiO2 (with also some effort on high-k dielectrics); and (2) first principles-based kinetic models capable of predicting the evolution of dopant and defect profiles, which is needed for rational experimental designs to realize ultrashallow junctions for the 45-nm node or beyond. 
Continued scaling of CMOS devices down to the 45-nm design node or beyond will require the formation of ever shallower and more abrupt junctions with higher doping levels.  This also requires moving away from bulk CMOS in Si with SiO2 gate dielectrics.  It will probably involve the use of a buried strained Si layer for channel mobility enhancement and high-k dielectrics for gate leakage current reduction.  However, little is known about the fundamental behavior and properties of defects and dopants in strained Si layers and their interfaces with a-SiO2, (let alone high-k dielectrics). 
We perform first principles calculations to determine: structure, stability, and bonding of defect and dopant clusters in amorphous/strained Si layers; formation and diffusion of mobile defect and defect-dopant complexes in strained Si layers and in the vicinity of a-c Si interfaces; and defect annihilation and dopant precipitation at strained-Si/a-SiO2 interfaces. 
We perform first principles based classical molecular dynamics (or ab inito tight binding molecular dynamics, if necessary) simulations to examine complex dynamics occurring in amorphous Si.  Emphasis is placed on understanding: recrystallization of amorphous pockets in the presence of strain and defects; and dynamic behavior of defects in the vicinity of amorphous pockets.  The fundamental findings contribute to developing improved kinetic models for defect profiles during the early stages of post-implantation annealing.

children.name: Predictive-Multiscal
children.project_abstract:
The construction of next-generation nanocomposite materials with novel properties requires a fundamental understanding of the behavior of their nanoscale building blocks as well as their interaction with each other through a connecting matrix.  To scale up the superior mechanical properties of the individually confined nanometer-sized elements, load transfer and shear interactions must be optimized within the macroscopic material.  This great need has led to significant interest in the study of the fundamental deformation mechanisms of hierarchical layered materials composed of nanoscale elements. Designing such a class of layered materials draws its inspiration from Nature, who designs several strong and tough materials based on hierarchical structures, including bone, spider silk, and nacre from Red Abalone shell. For example, nacre is comprised of a hierarchical tablet-and-mortar structure of 95% brittle ceramic “tablets” (aragonite) and 5% organic polymer “mortar”.  This combination gives nacre a high modulus and a toughness that is ~3,000 times higher than the tablet material (aragonite) by means of a diffusive tablet sliding mechanisms, which is achieved by controlling material architecture, topology and interface properties. Here, we hypothesize that as in the case of natural materials, stiffness, strength, and toughness can be simultaneously optimized in novel composite materials, with hierarchical and discontinuous architectures, by selection of suitable building blocks, new interface chemistries, and constituent assembly with controlled geometrical overlap. The challenge is how does one identify the most promising combination of chemistry and geometrical overlaps, among the large number of possibilities available, for a particular combination of “tablet” and “mortar” building blocks?

Under the scope of the Materials Genome Initiative (MGI), we aim to accelerate the nanocomposite materials discovery and design, utilizing predictive computational models supported by highly selective experimental verification. While graphene has long been studied as a potential “brick” for “brick-and-mortar” nanocomposites, weak interfacial interactions between stacked sheets prevent effective scaling up. Graphene oxide (GO), a tunable, oxygen-functionalized derivative of graphene capable of strong interlayer hydrogen bonding, presents significant potential for overcoming this bottleneck.

The main objective for this project is the development of a predictive multiscale computational framework that accelerates the development of advanced materials. Specifically, the methodology proposed here focuses on the design of novel nanocomposites from multiple classes of materials, similar to computational alloys design, based on optimizing the materials selection, hierarchy and structure of the computationally predicted system. Inspired by natural materials such as nacre, we utilize GO and polymers as our building blocks. Through bottom-up computational modeling schemes, we aim to quickly assess the mechanical behavior of nanocomposites with different combinations of constituents as a function of hierarchy and structure of the system.
children.pi_institution: University of Texas at San Antonio

children.name: A-ch51
children.project_abstract:
Bimetallic materials have shown great promise for the development of superior catalysts.  The recent surge of new interest in catalysis by gold has led researchers to investigate the effects of adding gold to other metals. Alloying with palladium has been shown to form a bimetallic catalyst having superior activity, selectivity and stability towards various catalytic reactions such as carbon monoxide (CO) oxidation and hydrodesulfurization. In particular, palladium-gold (Pd-Au) alloy nanoclusters dispersed on titania (TiO2) often exhibit significantly improved efficiency for selective oxidation reactions, compared to Au/TiO2 and Pd/TiO2. Bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts have also recently received much attention for hydrogen fuel cell applications, because they are much less sensitive to CO poisoning than pure platinum or even platinum-ruthenium alloy catalysts. While mechanisms underlying the synergetic effect are ambiguous, recent evidence suggests that the reactivity of oxide-supported bimetallic metal nanocatalysts is determined by a complex combination of metal-metal interactions in metal clusters, metal-support interactions, and metal cluster sizes and shapes. However, little is known about the atomic structure and composition of Pd-Au nanoclusters, let alone their interfacial interactions with the TiO2 support.  
Using first principles calculations this research focuses on developing a better understanding of the alloying effects of supported bimetallic nanoclusters towards various catalytic reactions.  Special emphasis will be placed on understanding how the metal-metal and metal-support interactions determine the structure and composition of the supported metal alloys, and in turn their chemical reactivity.  For model systems, we will examine bimetallic Pd-Au thin films and TiO2-supported Pd-Au mixed nanoclusters, and their reactivity towards oxidation of CO and H2, relative to their pure counterparts.  The Pd-Au and Au-Pd/TiO2 systems will serve as excellent models for studying the nature of supported bimetallic nanocatalysts, particularly gold and palladium-group-metal alloys.  While current experimental techniques alone are limited to providing complementary real space information, the synergetic interplay between theory and experiment will contribute greatly to developing a better understanding of the structure, composition, and reactivity of oxide-supported Pd-Au nanoclusters.  Progress from this proposal will also offer an invaluable guide to the rational design and fabrication of bimetallic nanocluster-based materials for various catalytic applications.

children.name: TG-DMR190038
children.project_abstract: We request research allocation to deliver new fundamental insights on the role of hydrogen defects in tailoring electronic and magnetic properties of functional materials.  The project relies on a large-scale quantum chemical calculation using high performance computational facilities and a new research allocation of 25 363 SUs is requested on TACC Stampede2 cluster to carry out a set of Density-Functional-Theory (DFT) calculations in combination with Nudged Elastic Band (NEB) and Marcus Theory approaches.  In the following allocation period, we will (1) commence a systematic study of the effect of hydrogen insertion on magnetic properties of ferromagnet/heavy-metal heterostructures (e.g., Co/Pt, Co/Pd) and (2) investigate mechanism of resistive switching based on proton intercalation in functional oxides (e.g., WO3, V2O5).  We expect that atomistic information obtained using first-principles calculations is the key for proposing efficient strategies to improve properties of memory and logic devices such as ON/OFF ratio, response time and retention rate, and the requested XSEDE computational resources will play a critical role in achieving our research goals.

children.name: TG-DMR090026
children.project_abstract:
Important materials science applications are greatly facilitated by our ability to predict and understand the physical properties of materials, especially at the
nanoscale.  In order to predict such properties, we need extensive computational resources to solve complex quantum problems, whose solutions can yield accurate descriptions for a wide variety of electronic, magnetic, optical and structural properties.  
The research in this proposed work will be conducted within a broad, multidisciplinary framework, which includes contributions from material scientists, physicists, chemical engineers and computer scientists.  Our common research goals center on developing and applying numerical solutions for predicting such properties.  

We are particularly interested in applications involving electronic materials at the nanoscale.  We will investigate the intrinsic and extrinsic properties of nanocrystals, nanofilms and nanowires in order to elucidate the role of quantum confinement on a variety of properties.   Specifically, we plan to study the doping of nanostructures with both magnetic and non-magnetic impurity atoms, the formation of
surface islands, the diffusion of impurities and defects, the vibrational spectra of nanocrystals and  structural transformations on the nanoscale.

children.name: TG-DMR150034
children.project_abstract: The goal of this project is to use molecular dynamics, Monte Carlo, and field theoretic simulations to predict the properties of polymer nanocomposites. All of our work is motivated by ongoing experiments being performed by our collaborators. We will use molecular dynamics to study the dynamics of polymers as they infiltrate a disordered nanoparticle packing, and our results will be compared to analytic theories and ongoing experiments in our collaborator's lab. In addition, we will use an extensive set of field theoretic simulations to predict the equilibrium properties of polymer nanocomposites containing spherical and rod-like particles. We will examine these block copolymer composites in both bulk and thin film geometries. Finally, we have will predict the equilibrium morphology of side-chain liquid crystalline block copolymers using self-consistent field theory.

children.name: TG-DMR170006
children.project_abstract: Designing materials with superior properties is a challenging problem, both in terms of cost and time. We are using computational tools to understand the structures and properties of materials and develop advanced computational methods to reduce the costs of material design process. Currently we have multiple projects focused on computational materials design and understanding, which are founded by NSF, and require access to HPC resources to accomplish the proposed tasks. We have developed an efficient home-grown software called ï­-pro, which makes 3D simulation of microstructure evolution feasible and we will extend it for more complex problems such as nonlinear mechanics as part of this proposed effort. In summary, 3 postdocs and 7 graduate students are working on these projects, which require ~10.5 M SUs, ~7 TB of storage, and access to Comet and Bridges Regular Memory systems.

children.name: TG-DMR140125
children.project_abstract:
The over-arching focus of our research is to develop and utilize mesoscopic computational methods to design hybrid soft materials with specific structure-function relations by harnessing the multiscale dynamic coupling of the interactions between the molecular species, and the statistical thermodynamics of the system. Soft materials encompass solid composites or liquid dispersions whose molecular species form the nanoscopic building blocks which assemble into structures spanning large length scales (angstroms to microns.) In addition to molecular-scale interactions between nanoscopic elements, the kinetics and thermodynamics of the structure and dynamics of these materials is dictated by physical forces which are predominant in these length scales: friction, electrostatics and hydrodynamics. The complex interplay between these key forces determines the structure or composition of these materials, and their responses to changes in the external environment such as acidity, temperature or light radiation. Fundamental insight into the morphology and dynamics of these materials will require the development and utilization of a suite of modeling tools with each class of tools tuned to address physical phenomena over a specific spatio-temporal scale. These multiple modeling techniques have to be interfaced at the juncture of two scales to enable a multiscale resolution of the system behavior over large length and time scales (nano-seconds to micro-seconds.) We harness these methodologies to develop a fundamental understanding of the various mechanisms underlying the interaction between cells and surfaces, for applications in targeted drug delivery, cellular sensing and antifouling. We are interested in the conception and design of bio-inspired membranes, vesicles, suitable biocompatible delivery vehicles and functionalized surfaces with specific interactions, via the use of mesoscopic computational models and techniques. The outline of the proposed work is provided below:
1.	Designing bio-inspired membranes and vesicles 
2.	Mesoscopic implicit solvent models for bio-inspired bilayer vesicles 
3.	Designing sterically stable lipid-based delivery vehicles 
4.	Designing controlled-release delivery vehicles 
5.	Designing delivery vehicles via self-assembly of functionalized viral capsids 
6.	Removal of heavy metal ions using dendritic surfaces 
	The modeling and simulation techniques developed will require the utilization of state-of-the-art high-end fast-interconnect multi-core computing resources available at the Texas Advanced Computing Center (TACC). The simulations for all the projects will be carried out on TACC Stampede using an open source Molecular Dynamics (MD) code entitled Large-scale Atomic/Molecular Massively Parallel Simulator (LAMMPS) [1]. To compare the run time measurements for the different number of processors, we measure the run Time per number of Particles per number of Iterations (TPI) for different number of processors. All computational models will be rigorously tested and bench-marked prior to the production runs for system scales of interest on TACC Stampede.

children.name: TG-DMR160114
children.project_abstract: We request computing time on XSEDE resources for multiscale simulations to tackle grand challenges in materials science. We will use various approaches ranging from molecular dynamics with reactive force field (ReaxFF), to quantum-mechanical calculations. We request a total of 6.2 M hours (3.1 M on Stampede and 3.1 M on Comet). The proposed simulations include (1) structural engineering of perovskite solar cell material for optimal stability and bandgap; (2) mechanistic study of oxygen evolution reaction at IrO2 and RuO2 metal oxide surface; (3) studies of defects passivation in two-dimensional materials; (4) materials genomics to achieve high hardness high ductility alloy of boron carbide; (5) Pt nanowire for oxygen reduction reaction.

children.name: TG-DMR130145
children.project_abstract: This work is the modeling and simulation component of NSF-supported Grant No. CHE-1111500 which covers both experimental and modeling studies. The goal of this research work is to advance capabilities for predictive modeling and simulation of metal nanostructure formation and stability. The nanoclusters considered in this work are formed by deposition on single-component single-crystal metal substrates, on binary alloy substrates, and/or on graphene substrates supported on flat surfaces of certain metals. We develop realistic atomistic-level models which have predictive capability, and can thus elucidate and guide experiments. Our model requires very many precise energetic parameters (both for thermodynamics and kinetics) as input. These energies must be obtained from a large number of density functional theory calculations with high convergence standards and high precision. These NSF-supported studies are of fundamental importance to advance the understanding of the formation and relaxation of metal nanostructures on specific surfaces, and potentially of the interaction of those nanostructures with chemisorbed species.

children.name: RCPS14
children.project_abstract:
Functional amphiphilic semiconducting conjugated rod-coil block copolymers have attracted increasing interest for their applications in sustainable energy technologies such as polymer solar cells and batteries. Experimental studies have demonstrated that rod-coil block copolymers form novel supramolecular structures of nanowires in solvent environments. However, the molecular details and self-assembling mechanisms are still unknown. The goal of this project is to investigate rod-coil block polymers’ unique phase behavior under solvent effect so as to rationalize experimental design. The proposed molecular dynamics (MD) simulations will provide important insight into the complex phase driving forces, including microphase separation, anisotropic interactions and the solvent effect. The simulations will also elucidate the mechanisms of polymers self-assembling in the solvents environment. This project requires an exploration of multiple, long MD trajectories for ensembles of millions of atoms under different conditions: different solvents, polymer concentrations and polymer chemistry. In the mean time, drawing on atomistic MD simulations, we will develop polymer coarse-grained model and high efficient lattice simulation to study polymer supramolecular structures under solvent effect at mesoscopic scale.

The simulations will be performed using the software packages of Gromacs, Lammps and our own code. We have carried out preliminary simulations of the systems of 1.2 million atoms in shorter time (less than 100 ns) using atomistic MD simulations. In order to illustrate polymers’ self-assembling in solvent environments at larger time scale and larger dimensions, we are in need of additional computational resources.

children.name: TG-DMR180108
children.project_abstract: A sustainable energy future requires solutions to a number of diverse set of materials challenges and their chemistries such as the design of better catalysts for key processes such as electrochemical water-splitting and the nitrogen reduction reaction to produce ammonia, novel synthesis methods of â??intelligentâ?? catalyst materials, and the numerous problems posed by energy storage. This proposal request resources to support a major part of my groupâ??s research activities from October 2018 â?? September 2019. Our research interests span the chemistry of a diverse set of materials knowns as transition metal compounds ranging from oxides to carbides and nitrides. We have requested resources to perform simulations related to four topics: A) Structure-performance relationships in oxide-based catalysts for electrochemical water splitting B) Ion segregation and design of novel â??intelligentâ?? catalysts C) Nitrogen reduction chemistry to ammonia (NSF funded), and D) Interfacial thermodynamics and transport in Li-ion batteries. We use a combination of first-principles methods, including density functional theory for structure determination, thermodynamics, kinetics, and electronic structure analysis as well as investigate structure evolution using ab-initio molecular dynamics.

children.name: TG-DMR180068
children.project_abstract:
Secondary energy storage technologies based on sodium ions are an important emerging alternative to lithium ion batteries (LIBs). Sodium is less expensive than lithium, with its supplies being much wider and more democratically distributed throughout the globe. Therefore, there is the potential for significantly reduced system cost, as well as for increased energy security due to ease of obtaining sodium precursors as compared to lithium carbonate. Hybrid sodium ion capacitors (NICs) and dedicated high power sodium ion batteries (NIBs) are energy storage devices that are meant to bridge the power â?? cyclability â?? energy density gap of conventional secondary batteries and supercapacitors. Due to their electrode architecture these devices may operate at rates near or even above 60C (1C being one hour charge), i.e., single minute charge or discharge. Their enhanced energy as compared to supercapacitors is due to the electrodes that offer the potential for bulk Na storage, as well as due to the Na ion electrolyte that operates at higher voltages as compared to acetonitrile, etc. 

A survey of literature indicates that the most optimum negative (anode) electrodes for NICs consist of high surface area two-dimensional (2-D) carbons, such as various high surface area carbon nanosheets reported in literature. To date the intermediate and fast Na charge storage mechanisms in such carbons are poorly understood. The perception is that at rates such as 5C, 10C or even 60C, it is effectively â??business-as-usualâ?: For instance, carbon nanosheet electrodes that intercalate Na ions at C/3 are assumed to operate comparably at much higher rates. A wide survey of existing scientific literature shows minimal discussion regarding any transitions in dominant charge storage or capacity loss mechanisms as the charging rate is increased. Moreover, while there is a wide variability in the Coulombic efficiency and cycling lifetime values reported for 2-D carbons with Na, the origin of either is not understood. This combined experimental â?? simulation proposal seeks to provide new fundamental insight into these unexplored aspects of Na charge storage in 2-D carbons with a range of structure and chemistries. 

Our modeling effort will combine various state-of-the-art theoretical methods. It will address the fundamental issues regarding the Na ion storage behavior at the interface between electrolyte and the carbon. The role of graphene ordering, various carbon defects, and heteroatom chemistry will be considered in detail. We will systematically employ graphene-like carbon nanosheet electrodes as model anode structures containing nanopores, topological defects, heteroatoms (B, N, P, S), and combined dopant-defect complexes. This unique proposed work speaks to the core of the structure-properties relations in an emerging class of Na based energy storage systems (NICs and NIBs). It will answer the fundamental questions regarding how Na is reversibly and irreversibly stored within imperfect carbons. With the successful execution of this research, it is expected that many of the existing â??battery-inheritedâ? paradigms regarding high rate Na storage would be disrupted.

children.name: TG-DMR110090
children.project_abstract: n/a

children.name: TG-DMR100029
children.project_abstract: We request a renewal of XSEDE Resource Allocation to support the computational work in our group on different research projects funded by the NSF and DOE. The underlying scientific problems are described in separate grant proposals but ultimate objective pursued can be summed up as the modeling and understanding of nanomaterials and processes. The importance of a wide range of length and time scales is generic in complex materials. It is therefore clear that the theoretical description of such systems requires more than a single theoretical tool which entails more diverse methodological, software and hardware requirements. Within the requested computational resources research will focus on a subset of problems from the topics supported by NSF and DOE: I-- Novel low-dimensional boron chalcogenides; II-- First-principles theory of graphene growth; III-- Atomistic simulations of tensile failure of a basic structural unit in carbon fibers.

children.name: TG-DMR140063
children.project_abstract: This proposal is a request for the computing resources at XSEDE to perform first-principles calculations to investigate fundamental properties (diffusion coefficients, interfacial energies, finite temperature thermodynamic properties) of critical materials for energy and defense applications. This request is for 3,620k SUs on Stampede for a total of 5 PhD students and 3 postdocs. The research topics covered by this project are: 1. Study of advanced titanium-base alloys for next generation medical devices (280k SUs); 2. Ab-initio prediction of diffusion coefficients in Mg alloys (775k SUs); 3. Bulk and grain boundary diffusivities of oxygen in Ni-Al-Cr systems through first-principles and kinetic Monte Carlo approaches (517k SUs); 4. Prediction of mechanical and thermodynamic properties of Ni-base superalloys (400k SUs); 5. First-principle prediction of grain boundary energy in Fe alloys (449k SUs); 6. A first-principles study of stacking faults and long periodic stacking order structures in Mg and Mg alloys (240k SUs); 7. Thermodynamic properties of Li-Mn-Co-Ni-O system for battery applications (600k SUs); 8. First-principles calculation of thermodynamic and kinetic properties of CZTSSe solar absorber materials (360k SUs). Most of the projects are funded by National Science Foundation (NSF) with some funded by Department of Defense (DoD) Army Research Lab and Pratt-Whitney. The results obtained by first-principles calculations will be integrated with CALPHAD (CALculation of PHAse Diagrams) modeling to predict complex multi-component materials properties. The requested resources are for the proposed first-principles calculations, all of which will be performed using the VASP code, one of the most efficient and accurate density functional theory tools available. VASP is widely used on the XSEDE machines and runs efficiently on Stampede, which are where we are requesting SUs.

children.name: TG-DMR140093
children.project_abstract: Traditional alloys used in engineering applications, including steels and aluminum alloys, are formed of a primary constituent (solvent) element with other elements added in relatively small quantities to enhance material properties.  However, the inclusion of large quantities of alloying elements tends to lead to the formation of intermetallics, rather than a single solid solution, which can dramatically reduce ductility and mechanical processing ability. We are developing novel high entropy alloys (HEAs), which, unlike traditional alloys, have four or more elements in roughly equiatomic proportions. Examples of these alloys have demonstrated mechanical properties greatly exceeding those of conventional engineering metals. However, the mechanisms by which these complex alloys are formed and improved properties achieved are not well understood. Our overall goal is to develop an experimentally-validated, systematic model based on first-principles calculations to enable further development of HEA systems. This research is supported by NSF grant OISE-1261525. The PI and undergraduate students have implemented methods using the Vienna Ab Initio Simulation Package (VASP) to enable computation of partial phase diagrams of HEA alloy systems and the elastic constants of specific alloys. We are in the process of implementing methods to calculate stacking fault energy, Peierls stress, and flow stress as well. Several of these properties can be experimentally verified and are potentially predictive of high performance materials. We have already successfully used VASP to predict crystal structures, phase diagrams, and elastic properties for single elements and well-characterized binary alloys. As we move to simulating HEAs, we require more computational resources than are available to us at Harvey Mudd College. We request XSEDE resources to run our simulations on several alloy families of interest.

children.name: SAC
children.project_abstract: Rapid development of single-atom catalysts (SACs) in heterogeneous catalysis has attracted extensive attention since such concept realization at 2011.  The past studies show it has four main advantages: high selectivity, tunable stability, high mass activity and tunable activity. Currently SAC is still at infancy stage, there are still many important questions need to be explored both from scientific and industrial point of view: the micro structure environment of active site, and stability, the diversity of tuning activity, etc.  These questions has put a   grand challenge for the traditional experimental method.  DFT simulation is becoming a more powerful method and I will us the this method give a atomic explanation of the chemical process to study the energy related catalyst for the activation of small molecules, such as H2, O2, N2, H2O. The mechanistic study will help to design more efficient catalyst for various chemical process..

children.name: TG-DMR190007
children.project_abstract:
Abstract: Alloy 800H and Inconel 617 are promising structural materials for high temperature and very high temperature gas cooled reactors (HTGRs/VHTRs); they possess excellent high temperature thermo-mechanical properties and also offer environmental protection. The structural and in-core components of a VHTR are exposed to small amounts of carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide, hydrogen, water vapor and methane. The impurities will react with the alloys through three reactions â?? oxidation, carburization, and decarburization. The chromium phase in both alloys reacts with the oxygen to form a protective coating (Cr2O3) that helps as a corrosion-resistant environmental barrier across a range of temperatures. When the carbon potential in the alloy is lower than in the gas, carburization takes place. The carbides are susceptible to chemical disintegration depending on the carbon potential

The first objective of our work is to assess the structure and properties of stable chromia in the presence of the impurities. We will utilize Kohn-Sham density functional theory (DFT) as implemented in the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) and Quantum ESPRESSO with the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) method. The projected augmented wave (PAW) method will be used to describe the core and valence electron interactions. The exchange-correlation interactions will be described using Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) with the GGA functional. In order to accurately account for the strong correlations between the d electrons in transition metals (such as Cr, Fe), the DFT+U approach will be employed. To assess the entropic effects, we will also perform large scale classical molecular dynamics (MD) simulations at finite temperatures with empirical potentials using the LAMMPS software.
children.pi_institution: North Carolina State University at Raleigh

children.name: TG-DMR190032
children.project_abstract: This research request will support first-principles calculations in support of two NSF grants, DMR-1808011 and CBET-1803614. The first grant (DMR-1808011) seeks to understand interactions in hybrid materials composed of 2D semiconductors and functional polymers. The functional polymers are tailored to contain specific moieties that enable precise, spatially-targeted control over work-function and charge-carrier doping of the 2D material. The second grant (CBET-1803614) will study metal core-2D shell nanoparticles designed for stabilization of catalytically active phases of the 2D materials and optimal control of catalytic activity and selectivity. Both projects involve the application of first-principles modeling as a key step in informing rational selection and design of hybrid organic-inorganic materials and core-shell nanoparticles, elucidating their fundamental physico-chemical properties, and providing mechanistic understanding into complementary experiments. The primary electronic structure code to be used for these two projects is the Vienna Ab Initio Simulation Package (VASP). We are requesting resources on Stampede2 that has the most recent optimized binaries of this code and where we have run all of our reported benchmarks using our startup allocation.

children.name: TG-DMR150099
children.project_abstract:
This is a new proposal for an XSEDE research allocation, which will support the research on
computational modeling of advanced materials in the group of Prof. Anderson Janotti in the
Department of Materials Science and Engineering at the University of Delaware (UD). The
computational resources will be used to perform electronic structure calculations for a series
of functional materials which are the focus of research grants funded by the Department
of Energy, University of Delaware, and the National Science Foundation (a research
proposal is currently being prepared for submission to the Division of Materials Research).

First-principles calculations, based on the density functional theory, constitute a
powerful tool to investigate the structural, electronic, optical, and magnetic properties of
materials. These calculations have greatly contributed to fundamental understanding of
the electronic structure of materials and the response to mechanical, electric, magnetic, and
optical excitations. The materials that are the focus of this project are complex oxides, Heusler
and half-Heusler compounds, and layered chalcogenide materials. The goal is to understand
the fundamental relationship between chemical composition, structure, electronic,
and transport properties of these materials, in close connection to current experimental
work at UD and elsewhere.

These studies employ advanced algorithms that necessarily demand the use of highperformance
parallel computation. Prof. Janotti has demonstrated extensive experience in
the area of computational materials science, with emphasis on first-principles calculations,
and has established a strong record in the areas of doping and defects in oxide and nitride
semiconductors, semiconductor surfaces and interfaces, hydrogen impurities in materials,
and complex-oxide heterostructures.

children.name: TG-DMR130009
children.project_abstract: n/a

children.name: TG-DMR110088
children.project_abstract:
Nanoparticles are considered to be the building blocks for nanotechnology.  Use of nanomaterials in various industries is projected to increase dramatically an environmental contamination by these materials. Since it is still largely unknown how nanoparticles will impact the environment, nanotechnology could lead to serious environmental problems.  Moreover,  there is still a substantial need to comprehensively investigate all physicochemical and biological properties of nanoparticles to predict possible impact.

The goal of the NSF CREST Interdisciplinary Center for Nanotoxicity (ICN) at Jackson State University is to develop an understanding of the potentially complex interplay between properties of different  nanomaterials and the health of ecosystems (impact to environment) using computational and experimental approaches. The Center analyzes the basic properties of the investigated nanoparticles that will lead to the thorough understanding of their behavior in physical processes, environments, relationship between physicochemical properties and biological activity/toxicity. Detailed physicochemical and toxicological characterization of different nanomaterials will ultimately have numerous applications in the industry and environmental hazard assessments and certainly will lead to development of reliable risk and safety evaluations to ensure their safety for human health and the environment. The activity of the Center is focused on the following directions:

1. Physicochemical properties of nanoparticles. Computational and experimental prediction of  fundamental physicochemical properties, including quantum-chemical parameters, size-dependent parameters, composition-dependent parameters, and surface-dependent parameters that determine the intrinsic features of nanoparticles.

2. Interactions of nanoparticles with biological systems and small molecules. The studies are carried out by comprehensive ab initio quantum-chemical calculations at high level of theory for small systems and using hybrid molecular mechanics/quantum-mechanical, classical force files and docking methods for larger systems.

3. SAR studies, toxicity effects and environmental risks assessment of nanoparticles. The structure-activity paradigms applicable for nanoparticles are developed. According to this concept, the structure-property relationships and especially, the nanoparticle-toxicity relationships for different endpoints are being comprehensively investigated to reveal the mechanisms of nanoparticles toxicity and then to use such information to assess the environmental risks.

children.name: TG-DMR130077
children.project_abstract: This new research proposal requests 700,000 SUs on Stampede high performance computing system to explore effect of various impurities and oxide based light-scattering particles on optical properties of high energy density molecular materials using ab initio tools. We will also explore mechanisms of decomposition reactions of excited and ionized explosives in the gas phase and at free surfaces aiming to reveal the main tendencies of photo initiation processes. Results of our calculations are expected to provide important yet unknown details of the laser initiation of high energy materials opening up radically new opportunities not only in design and usage, but also in storage and safety of handling of energetic materials

children.name: TG-DMR110008
children.project_abstract: Computational research based on ab-initio density functional calculations for a number of transition metal oxide systems used in energy applications is proposed. The proposed research will investigate bulk and surface structural stability and activation barriers of cations in lithium transition metal oxide systems.  First principles calculations requiring 32 to 96 cores taking up to 48 hours each will be executed on the Ranger resource.

children.name: A-ch6
children.project_abstract:
This research project focuses on the development of a hybrid, multiscale simulation approach to predict the equilibrium and dynamical properties of polymer nanocomposites. Polymer nanocomposites are materials synthesized by the addition of a small weight fraction of anisotropic filler particles to polymeric matrices. There has been a recent surge of interest in these materials due to their unique materials properties such as modulus, fire retardency gas permeability and rheology. Many of these property enhancements are quite uncharacteristic of what one might expect in the addition of such small amounts of fillers to polymeric matrices. Consequently, an unresolved and an active area of current research is to try and unearth the fundamental mechanisms by which such fillers impact upon the structure and properties of polymers.  

We have undertaken a computational approach to address the above question. But, this approach is by no means trivial. On the one hand, the filler particles are highly anisotropic and has atleast one dimension of nanometers. On the other hand, the polymers need to be modeled at the scale of monomers which are in Angstroms. These disparate length scales suggest the development of a multiscale simulation approach. We have developed a preliminary version of a multiscale approach that combines the molecular dynamics simulation for the particles with a coarse-grained approach termed as dissipative particle dynamics for the polymers. This effectively addresses the above issues, and can potentially be used to map out the mechanistic details of the polymer nanocomposite system.

Despite the use of a multiscale simulation idea, the simulations necessitate extensive computational resources to get rid of system size effects and also to obtain good statistical sampling for the dynamical simulations. Currently, our research group resources have around 20 workstations which are shared between this project and two other computationally intensive projects. We are requesting these resources on TACC to enable fruition of this high impact project. This research also impact indirectly upon many experimental groups at UT Austin who are actively pursuing the synthesis and applications of polymeric nanocomposites. Those researches can also be expected to benefit from expedited results that can suggest rational strategies for designing such materials.

children.name: TG-DMR190027
children.project_abstract:
We request an XSEDE Research allocation for computational soft matter, and most especially guided towards molecular dynamics of bio-inspired materials and polymers.
Creating a resilient synthetic surface that would repel a wide range of liquids present numerous technological applications, ranging from biomedical devices and fuel transport to architecture. Recently, we have been developing new encapsulation processes using these liquid-repellent materials. Even though designing such surfaces has shown to be very challenging, we aim at accelerating the creation and the optimization of these materials by using computational tools. In recent years, as a result of an increasing computational power of both mainstream and cutting-edge hardware, it has become possible and easier to study classical systems of hundreds of thousands of atoms over a few nanoseconds with classical molecular dynamics. Our main objective is to support our experimental results with computational models (why a given material is "more" efficient than another material), which would provide us with a better understanding of the underlying physical and chemical mechanisms in our systems. The first part of our project would mostly consist of a computational study of our new encapsulating techniques, and the different diffusion mechanisms that occur within these systems. The second part of this project focuses more on the design of liquid-repellent surfaces in general, which would eventually clear the path toward high-throughput computations to accelerate material design of liquid-repellent coatings and bio-inspired encapsulation processes. 
Our workhorse will mainly lie in classical molecular dynamics (MD) methods, with a possible support coming from Grand Canonical Monte Carlo methods. Depending on the results of these methods, our systems might also require hybrid quantum-classical molecular dynamics methods for investigation of our materials behavior at molecular scale.

children.name: TG-DMR120073
children.project_abstract:
Our group studies the physical and chemical properties and interface phenomena
of nanoscale materials for photovoltaic and energy storage devices.
Simulation, using techniques such as finite element analysis and molecular
dynamics, forms a major part of our research program and allows us to
investigate new, multi-purpose materials, composites, and fabrication
techniques \textit{in silico}.  Our current focus is topological insulators,
layered composite systems (e.g. graphene, dichalcogenides, boron nitride),
silicon nanostructures, organic semiconductor devices (e.g. pentance, rubrene,
porphyrin, phthalocyanene) and point defects and impurities on semiconductor
and metallic surfaces.  In addition to using pre-existing codes, we develop
codes for first-principles simulation which provide a balance between accuracy and
efficiency.

To advance our current research program we request an allocation of 10M SUs,
split across four distinct projects.  Initial performance and scaling tests at
TACC, NCSA, and PSC have established the value of XSEDE resources for this
work, and allowed us to predict our computational requirements for the next
phase of our research, which far exceeds the capacity available from local
resources.

children.name: TG-DMR160106
children.project_abstract: We request computing time on XSEDE resources for first principle calculations on the effects of O vacancies on the electronic, optical and transport properties of complex oxides, specifically BiVO4. We propose to use a combination of state of the art approaches including Density Functional Theory (DFT) and many body perturbation theory (GW-BSE). We request a total of 1.0 M hours on Stampede. The proposed research will provide important insights to experimentalists on whether and how O vacancies will improve the efficiencies of metal oxide photoanodes in solar water splitting cells.

children.name: TG-ATM160026
children.project_abstract:
Accurate prediction of convective hazardous weather is critical from both meteorological and public service/societal impact perspectives, but remains a major challenge. The uncertainties in numerical weather prediction (NWP) models as well as the high nonlinearity of convective weather make probabilistic forecast information that can be provided by convection-allowing ensembles especially valuable to forecasters. Advanced data assimilation (DA) is needed to provide accurate initial conditions (IC) while optimized ensemble-based DA techniques such as the ensemble Kalman filter (EnKF) can provide theoretically the best possible estimate of the initial condition uncertainties what are needed to initialize ensemble forecasting systems.  
CAPS has since 2007 continued to push the envelope of high-performance computing, conducting highly successful realtime storm-scale ensemble forecast (SSEF) experiments utilizing XSEDE computing resources at PSC, NICS and TACC, in collaboration with the NOAA Hazardous Weather Testbed (HWT) Spring Forecasting Experiment (SFE), and since 2016 the NOAA Hydrometeorological Testbed (HMT) Flash Flood and Intensive Rainfall (FFaIR) Experiment. CAPS realtime experiments are designed to test and evaluate the most advanced data assimilation systems and ensemble forecasting techniques designed for predicting high-resolution convective-scale weather, and the data sets generated will be used by the CAPS scientists as well as collaborators to help answer many scientific questions related to the prediction of severe weather. Close collaborating organizations include the NOAA National Centers for Environmental Prediction (NCEP) operational centers (The Storm Prediction Center, Weather Prediction Center, and Environmental Modeling Center), research centers include the National Center for Atmospheric Research and the Developmental Testbed Center). The experiments are expected to lead to optimal designs and advanced capabilities that can be implemented at the NCEP Operational Centers, and thereby to improve forecasting of severe weather such as tornadoes, severe hail, damaging winds, and flash floods.  The CAPS forecast data sets generated on the TerGrid and Xsede resources have resulted in more than 40 referred journal publications. 
Through this proposal, scientists from CAPS seeks XSEDE resources on TACC Stampede and PSC Bridges to support its 2017 realtime storm-scale ensemble data assimilation and forecasting and related research in collaboration with the 2017 HWT SFE and HMT FFaIR forecast experiments. Such research has large-scale computing requirements that can only be satisfied by XSEDE. New scientific questions will be addressed by the experiments.

children.name: TG-ATM140042
children.project_abstract: n/a

children.name: TG-AST190019
children.project_abstract: We propose to use the Stampede2 supercomputer to run global galaxy simulations of thermally and cosmic ray driven outflows from dwarf galaxies, specifically the Large and Small Magellanic Clouds (LMC and SMC), two dwarf satellite galaxies of the Milky Way exhibiting large-scale supernova-driven outflows. This work builds off our pilot study (Bustard et al. 2018) run on Stampede2 under a previous start-up allocation (TG-AST170033; PI: Chad Bustard,Co-PI: Ellen Zweibel). In this work, we used the FLASH magnetohydrodynamics code to simulate outflows from the LMC during it's infall through the Milky Way halo, and we found the interaction between weak "fountain" flows and the headwind experienced by the LMC to be important in ultimately expelling gas. Our proposed work will probe the additional effects of magnetic fields and cosmic rays, some of the most highly energetic particles in the universe, including a novel implementation of the so-called cosmic ray streaming instability. This extremely sub-grid interaction between charged cosmic ray particles and plasma waves has been approximated in a fluid treatment and can have large-scale effects on galaxy evolution. With these additions to our model, we will undertake a study of cosmic ray and thermally driven outflows from the LMC and SMC, varying key parameters such as method of cosmic ray transport, initial magnetic field strength,  and  level  of  supernova  clustering.  We  will  then  create  synthetic  observations  using extensively tested visualization toolkits,  and we will compare these directly to the wealth of observational data on the Magellanic System. By using the Clouds, two of the most well-studied extra-galactic objects in the Universe, as test-beds for outflow launching, we can, for the first time, connect resolved star formation histories and detailed observations of galaxies to their supernova-driven expulsions. Using observational constraints on the magnetic field strength, cosmic ray population, star cluster masses, etc., we can probe what works and what doesn't to launch the observed outflows. This is of vital importance to understanding how galaxies self-regulate their star formation by transferring gas to the intergalactic medium, and it will provide a useful case-study for dwarf galaxy evolution in general.

children.name: TG-AST190001
children.project_abstract: Radiative transfer techniques in both cosmological simulations and for the purpose of making synthetic observations have recently become increasingly robust, leading to several predictions and new discoveries in a variety of fields.  Unfortunately, simulations run to the late Universe are forced to sacrifice physical and modeling detail due to computing limitations, which leaves the epoch fertile to observationally-constrained semi-analytic or empirical modeling efforts to bridge this gap. However, new phenomena and environments that lie on the edge of our observational frontier are less constrained and would benefit from a well-tested, first principles approach to numerical modeling. We propose to perform these tests by bringing full-physics ``zoom-in" cosmological simulations forward to the present day whereupon we will conduct a thorough Monte Carlo radiative transfer analysis on the resulting galaxies. After comparing and validating our techniques against observations, we will then proceed to produce detailed, high-resolution mock catalogs of both local galaxies and their higher-redshift progenitors. We will be able to provide predictions of light to mass ratios, half-light radii, emission line strengths, UV luminosity as well as other measures and correlate them directly to the composition, evolution history, and inclination of various types of galaxies. Our goal is to better account for micro physics in applications throughout galactic astronomy as well as facilitate tighter bounds and higher confidence for future novel observations.

children.name: TG-AST150042
children.project_abstract: We will perform radiation hydrodynamic and magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) simulations of two types of astrophysical systems.  The first set of simulations will build on our previous work to explore the interaction of radiation, dust, and gas in rapidly star forming environments.  These calculations will allow us to better understand the role small scale instabilities play in limiting the exchange of momentum between stellar radiation and interstellar gas. They will allow us to test simple analytic models and the sub grid prescriptions used in galaxy and cosmological scale simulations to model such interactions.  A second set of MHD simulations will examine the effects of realistic opacities on the structure and dynamics of accretion flows around supermassive black holes. Recent work has shown that ultraviolet line opacity can significantly alter the structure and thermal properties of the envelopes of massive stars. Supermassive black hole accretion disks are in a similar temperature and density regime, but there have been no attempts to account for such opacity in previous numerical or analytic models. These simulations will utilize recently developed radiation transfer modules for the Athena MHD code. Previous work has demonstrated that our radiative transfer algorithms yield more accurate and qualitatively different results from the diffusion approximation or M1 closure methods commonly employed in other codes.  Hence, we are uniquely well-placed to perform the calculations outlined below.

children.name: TG-AST190018
children.project_abstract:
Stars are the fundamental units of astrophysics and their formation is a key process that influences the evolution of galaxies, planets, and the development of life. Understanding how stars form is crucial even for seemingly unconnected fields of astronomy, Their formation includes a wide range of physical phenomena: both super- and subsonic turbulence, magnetic fields, weakly ionized plasmas, continuum and line radiative processes compounded by complex chemical processes and gravity, making the problem of star formation extremely complex. The difficulty is further compounded by the wide dynamic range of the problem: the process of star formation is initiated in giant molecular clouds (GMCs), which are 9 orders of magnitude larger than the protostars and stars that form in the end. 

Our goal is to understand the roles turbulence, magnetic fields, radiative feedback, outflows and the local environment play in star formation, on scales from individual stars and protostars to GMCs. The proposed simulations will be used to address the following questions:
1) What physical mechanisms are responsible for setting the masses of individual stars? 
2) How do different feedback mechanisms (e.g., radiation, outflows) interact to regulate star formation in GMCs? 
3) What determines the physical properties of star clusters that form in a given environment? How do the properties of the progenitor cloud affect the mass, size, and density profile of the resulting star clusters? 

Unlike previous studies that were confined to a small region of a GMC, the simulations we propose here will provide a self-consistent picture of a cloud disrupted by long-range feedback (e.g., winds and radiation from O-stars, supernovae).
