We propose a series of runs with progressively more complicated physics: starting from pure isothermal collapse, then adding magnetic fields, cooling physics, dust, protostellar heating and outflows and main sequence stellar feedback.This step-by-step approach will allow us to identify the role of each physical process in star formation in a self-consistent framework for the first time.

children.name: TG-MCA94P018
children.project_abstract:
With both a massively parallel gravity/SPH code and ``embarrassingly
parallel'' dynamical simulations, we will to study problems on vastly
different scales: from the formation of the Oort cloud of comets in
our solar system to the collapse of the largest gravitationally bound
structures in the Universe.  On cosmological scales, we will extend
our previous high resolution simulations of galaxy formation by
focusing on the spiral galaxy scaling relations (e.g. the Tully-Fisher
relation) between galaxy mass, as determined by rotation velocity, and
morphological properties of the galaxy such as disk scale lengths and
bulge to disk ratios.  We will take a multi pronged approach to this
problem.  First we will continue our campaign of high resolution
simulations of individual galaxies in their cosmological context using
a ``zoom-in'' technique.  Our focus here will be trying to understand
the origin of ``bulgeless galaxies'' which we have not been able to
simulate thus far.  Secondly we will perform a simulation of a
cosmological volume at moderate resolution in order to get a fair
sample in order to more directly compare with observational surveys.
Lastly, we will focus particular attention to our Local Group of
galaxies by performing a simulation with initial conditions
constrained by observations of the nearby large scale structure.  This
will be similar to our ``zoomed-in'' galaxies except the focus will be
on Andromeda, the Milky Way and the surrounding structure.

On galactic scales we will continue to study the formation of the
outer regions of disks via interactions with bars and spiral density
waves.  Our emphasis this year will be on including more cosmological
context in these studies.  We will be including local and cosmic UV
background flux, and will be including interactions with other
structure via mergers.  We will also be looking at this phenomenon in
lower mass galaxies.  Our study of the morphological transformation of
disks in clusters will continue by looking at a variety of galaxy
models as they fall into and interact with a galaxy cluster.

On planetary scales, we will study the formation of the Oort cloud as
a function of the galactic environment in of the early Solar System.
Whether the Sun was part of an open cluster in the early stages of
planet formation effects the distribution of the comet cloud, and
thereby determines the frequency and strength of subsequent comet
showers.

We will also be continue performing scaling tests of our recently publicly released parallel N-body code, ChaNGa.

children.name: TG-MCA08X016
children.project_abstract: We propose a multi-year effort to continue our research into the magnetohydrodynamics of the solar interior.  We use -local- domain, high resolution simulations of the processes found in the solar interior to try and understand the production of the magnetic activity observed at the solar surface.  These processes are complex and operate in the highly turbulent regime, and therefore demand enormous computing power to simulate the dynamics at sufficient resolution and for sufficient time to garner meaningful statistics from the turbulence.  We have made significant progress with LRAC resources on this long-term project over the last 10 years or more, and request continuing support to continue this program.

children.name: TG-AST140042
children.project_abstract: We will model the interaction of jets from accreting black holes with their environment. We will investigate feedback from supermassive black holes in the centers of galaxy clusters and its role in energizing the intergalactic gas, with an emphasis on high-resolution magneto-hydrodynamic simulations of jet propagation. We will also investigate the propagation of jets launched by accreting stellar mass black holes and neutron stars in high mass X-ray binaries with the powerful winds from their companion stars, with the aim of deriving robust diagnostics for the poorly understood properties of jets of these so-called microquasars. We ask for a total allocation of 1.8 million SUs on the XSEDE facility Stampede. The work will be part of graduate student DooSoo Yoon's Ph.D. thesis.

children.name: TG-AST140080
children.project_abstract:
We request computing time and storage space on XSEDE resources, principally
  Stampede or Gordon, to run a zoom-in cosmological simulation of the formation
  of the Local Group of galaxies using a stellar feedback model that has already
  been shown to produce realistic galaxies at both the dwarf and Galaxy scales.
  We aim to constrain the gas kinematics, which will allow for better detections
  of the CGM, in addition to detailed studies of both field and satellite dwarf
  galaxies, such as the resultant density profiles and requirements for the
  quenching of star formation.  We will create the initial conditions with
  MUSIC, which self-consistently samples the matter power spectrum in the early
  Universe, evolve the simulation with the TreePM+SPH code Gizmo, a version of
  the mature code Gadget that models the physics relevant to galaxy formation, 
  identify collapsed structures with Rockstar, a six-dimensional halo finder, 
  track them through time with consistent-trees, an advanced merger-tree algorithm, and 
  perform the final analysis using tools developed within the collaboration.  We 
  have extensively tested all of these software packages, both on our own 
  computational resources and XSEDE computers, and are confident that our request 
  of 3.99M SUs is an accurate estimate of that required to reach the scientific goals.

children.name: TG-AST120062
children.project_abstract: n/a

children.name: DesignSafe-SF_Fabric
children.project_abstract: In recent years there have been significant advances in the application of X-Ray computed tomography for 3-D imaging and characterization of granular media. To-date the various efforts have concentrated on characterizing grain shapes, packing, and triaxial tests on samples constructed in the laboratory. However, in a natural setting the depositional fabric depends on the mode of deposition and the shape, degree of rounding, orientation, and packing of the grains. The objective of our effort is to develop a technique for the characterization of the natural depositional fabric of sands by scanning and testing undisturbed samples obtained in routine geotechnical site investigations. To this end we obtained thin wall tube samples of sand collected during a site investigation at Treasure Island in the San Francisco Bay. We used small diameter plastic tubes to obtain undisturbed cylindrical samples for scanning and triaxial testing at the Laboratory 3SR at Université Grenoble Alpes. To date we scanned and obtained grain orientation data from 6 different samples, and we successfully performed two miniature triaxial tests and are scheduled to perform two more in the coming weeks.

children.name: TG-AST130002
children.project_abstract:
Our group requests a total of 6.5e6 SUs on the TACC machine Stampede to 
conduct global numerical simulations of astrophysical accretion disks.  
We will use the well-tested magnetohydrodynamic code  Athena to carry out these simulations. 
The project is separated into three parts:

We will carry out global MHD simulations to study dust particle dynamics in turbulent protoplanetary disks using our newly developed particle module in Athena. 
 We will study how dust concentrates in turbulence, which is crucial for planetesimal and planet formation.  This study will also make detailed observational predictions  for current telescopes. 

We will add planets in above simulations to study how planets interact with turbulent disks and dust particles in these disks, which is essential for understanding the survivability and growth of young planets.

We will study accretion disks around the white dwarf in interacting close binary system. By comparing with existing observations over past 20 years, such study will enable us to directly constrain accretion physics. 

We propose to run 5 calculations in total. We have already run low resolution studies to explore 
parameter space, and we request XSEDE resources only to run a small number of resolved models that will elucidate the physics of disks in each regime.
Finally, we request 2.5e3 GB of archival storage on the TACC Ranch system.
To visualize the data, we request 2e4 SUs on the TACC machine Maverick.

Funding for the proposed research will be provided by a NASA Hubble Fellowship (awarded to the PI),
the National Science Foundation (AST-0908269) and Princeton University. The time requested is essential for our proposed research since it is the only time requested from our accretion disk group at Princeton university this year.

children.name: TG-AST120060
children.project_abstract:
Supersonic collimated outflows have been observed emanating from Young Stel- lar Objects, Proto-Planetary Nebulae (PPN) and other astrophysical objects. Understanding the physics of these jets is a key challenge in plasma astro- physics, for they are a powerful natural mechanisms of energy transport.
One paradigm to explain the formation of jets in PPN, in particular, is that of a binary stellar system in which material from the wind of an AGB star is gravitationally pulled onto an intermediate-mass companion. A hot magnetized rapidly rotating plasma disk will be formed about the companion star. The rotational and magnetic energy of this disk will then lead to the launch and collimation of jets. Several fundamental questions remain open in this scenario however. In particular which kinds binaries, (i.e. for which separations and mass ratios), form stable accretion disks? Do all disks form jets? What affects the stability of disk driven jets?
Based on novel results obtained with our previous start-up XSEDE allocation (TG-AST120029) we propose to carry out a series of three-dimensional Adaptive Mesh Refinement parallel numerical simulations to study the formation, struc- ture and stability, and observational implications, of interacting stellar binaries. This will include (1) accretion from the primary AGB wind onto a secondary star and (2) launch and propagation of strongly magnetized jets. Our compu- tations will be performed with higher resolution and longer time-scales than attempted in previous studies and we will be using our locally developed, well tested code AstroBEAR 2.0 for the simulations. Binary-formed accretion disks will be investigated for stellar separations of 10, 20, 30, 40astronomical units and for mass ratios of 1.5. We will also study strongly magnetized jets in both adiabatic and cooling regimes using toroidal-to-poloidal magnetic component ratios of .1, 1, 10, 100.
While we are in full production mode with AstroBEAR 2.0 the numerical resources of the XSEDE that we are requesting are needed to make further progress on unraveling the fundamental questions concerning interacting bina- ries and their disks/outflows. To achieve this goal we request the support of 4 million SUs on Kraken at NICS and 4 million SUs on Ranger at TACC.

children.name: TG-AST150062
children.project_abstract: The complex interaction between a rotating star's dipole magnetic field and a surrounding accretion disk is central to the most important questions raised by neutron stars in X-ray binaries, and may be able to shed light on topics as disparate as the long-term spin evolution of accreting pulsars and the launching of relativistic jets by all varieties of compact astrophysical objects. This problem has never been self-consistently simulated in a relativistic framework, making it difficult to apply existing theory to the most energetic and extreme objects, the accreting millisecond X-ray pulsars, due to the large relativistic effects introduced by their rapid rotation. We propose to perform a set of five three-dimensional general relativistic magnetohydrodynamic simulations of disk accretion onto rapidly rotating, magnetized stars, in order to investigate the torques exerted on the star, the matter ejected from the disk by the rotating stellar field lines, and the jets produced by the star-disk system. These simulations are especially timely given the recent discovery of transitional millisecond pulsars, which have been observed in both accreting (X-ray) and isolated (radio) pulsar states, implying a cyclical invasion of an accretion disk into the pulsar magnetosphere.

children.name: TG-CHE140109
children.project_abstract:
Heterogeneous catalysts improve the efficiency of chemical transformations and are used for the production of fuels, chemicals, and the abatement of harmful emissions. Modern catalysis exists for about 100 years, but catalyst design and development remains by and large a time-consuming experimental trial-and-error process. The discovery of density functional theory (DFT) and the availability of large computational resources have already started to have a significant impact on our understanding of catalysis, and more importantly, they become increasingly applicable for the in silico design of new catalytic materials. The most successful approach for the identification of novel catalysts is known as computational catalyst screening, which encompasses three main steps: (i) the identification of the dominant reaction mechanism and the key reaction intermediates; (ii) the determination of a small set of catalytic reactivity descriptors that can predict reactivity and selectivity trends; and (iii) the calculation of these reactivity descriptors on new catalysts.
In the PIs group at the University of Houston (UH) we apply computational catalysis techniques, primarily DFT, to study catalytic process that enable the more efficient use of natural resources. This includes the utilization of abundant natural gas and biomass as fuel and feedstock for the production of valuable chemicals. The use of different fuels in vehicles, e.g. natural gas engines, also requires novel catalytic converters for emissions aftertreatment. Our group is very active in studying such catalysts and we collaborate closely with experimental groups at UH and elsewhere.

children.name: Hybridization-of-sel
children.project_abstract: The proposed project is to study nucleic acid fragments self-assembling and their hybridization processes, which are crucial for the design of cancer marker.  Our previous work related with this proposed project, which was performed with the old Stampede cluster, has been reported on TACC website. The proposed project needs 12480 SUs and 500 GB, which also help us prepare NSF and NIH proposals in 2018.

children.name: Effects-of-Nano-pore
children.project_abstract:
A significant portion of the light hydrocarbons produced from unconventional reservoirs can originate from connected intra-particle organic-matter (OM) pores, and a significant portion of those OM pores can be tens of nanometers or less. Important petro-physical quantities such as porosity, pore-size, fracture connectivity, and wettability of OM pores in organic-rich shale depend on the thermal maturity, kerogen type, chemical composition, and presence of surface functionalized groups. A better understanding of the hydrocarbon storage and fracture properties in nano-confined OM systems as a function of maturity, type, and composition could significantly improve the reservoir characterization, planning, and development of unconventional resource plays. Developing such an understanding is an outstanding challenge, and requires a comprehensive investigation into the chemistry and petrophysics of nano-confined OM systems. These challenges represent opportunities for fundamental research that can have a direct impact on an important and developing industrial process.

We propose to investigate the effects of nano-pore confinement on hydrocarbon storage and fracture properties of isolated kerogen using computational thermodynamics and simulations, integrated with low-field NMR (nuclear magnetic resonance), BET (gas adsorption), and SEM (scanning electron microscopy) measurements of saturated kerogen samples of various maturity, type, and composition. A saturating fluid with large affinity to the kerogen surface, such as methane or pentane, will serve as a probe of the phase behavior and storage of hydrocarbons in kerogen nano-pores. A saturating fluid with small affinity to the kerogen surface, such as a water-based hydraulic-fracture fluid, will serve as a probe for transport of fracture fluids and potential wettability alteration of kerogen. Besides addressing fundamental scientific and technological challenges in describing fluids under confinement, the proposed research will contribute science and technology that can aid  our quest to become self-reliant in energy  by increasing ultimate hydrocarbon recovery from these complex unconventional reservoirs.

children.name: TG-CTS160043
children.project_abstract: A theoretical investigation on the effects of transition metal dopants on different rare earth oxides (REOs) is proposed.  The proposed work is supported in conjunction with a National Science Foundation experimental grant (CHE 1464765) that focuses on preparing REO catalysts, and investigating their surface reactivity and selectivity under realistic conditions. More specifically we propose to investigate the effects of Ni, Pd, V and W on ceria, terbia and samaria.  The current proposal is a revised research allocation request for computing time on XSEDE resources to supersede a startup allocation (CTS160003) awarded in January 2016. During the startup allocation, preliminary calculations were completed on Stampede to create a reaction framework for pertinent chemical reaction pathways involved in the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM). This preliminary work focused on the undoped surface of ceria (CeO2) (111) in order to establish the framework involved for partial and complete oxidation of methane. The preliminary investigation has identified ~30 elementary reaction steps on the ceria surface and will facilitate future studies.  Performing calculation concurrently with experiments can help to identify key thermodynamic and kinetic reaction results that can reveal information about better catalytic materials to test under experimental conditions. While funds for theoretical calculations were not included in this NSF project, we feel that a computational study of the effects of dopants could add significant value to the overall experimental NSF project as well as to the expertise and skill set acquired by the students.

children.name: TG-CTS160041
children.project_abstract: Methanol to hydrocarbon (MTH) reactions are known to be catalyzed by proton form zeolites. Small pore zeolites (e.g. TON) exhibit higher selectivity towards lighter hydrocarbons, as well as lower rates than zeolites with larger cavities such as MFI, which are more selective towards gasoline-range hydrocarbons. Light alkenes (such as ethene, propene, and isobutene) are primarily formed via an aromatically co-catalyzed process. It is unknown, however, which aromatic species are most effective at co-catalyzing alkene formation, which alkene is the preferred product, and the exact mechanism for this co-catalyzed cycle. These aromatic co-catalysts can also react with alkenes to form polycyclic (e.g. naphthalene) coke precursors which lead to zeolite deactivation. The zeolite framework and location of the Brnsted acid site within the zeolite can have an effect on the reactivity, selectivity, and deactivation rates, because the diverse environments within the zeolite framework stabilize intermediates and transition states to different extents. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations will be used in this work to investigate three mechanisms of aromatically-co-catalyzed alkene (C2-C4) formation using a variety of aromatic co-catalysts at multiple acid-site locations within the MFI zeolite. These efforts will determine the critical steps which ultimately control the rate, selectivity, and deactivation of MFI during MTH reaction, which will enable the rapid evaluation of a wide range of frameworks.

children.name: TG-CTS190023
children.project_abstract: The nucleus of eukaryotic cells is a membrane-bound organelle which stores a near meter long genomic DNA within its micrometre-sized confines. Most of the nuclear space is taken up by the DNA in tight association with proteins which together form a complex and out of equilibrium nuclear material known as chromatin. The physical state of chromatin as defined by its architecture, dynamics and biochemical markings can directly influence and regulate many important genetic processes. The dense and slow diffusing regions of chromatin correspond to genetically silenced areas known as heterochromatin, while more mobile and diffuse regions are known as euchromatin. The fundamental principles and driving forces which govern the dynamics and spatial order of chromosomes, nuclear bodies and euchromatin-heterochromatin are poorly understood. Latest experiments, however, have been finding that on micrometre scales chromatin acts as a viscoelastic complex liquid-like material. Specifically, liquid-liquid phase separation of disordered proteins was found responsible for desegregation of heterochromatin and euchromatin territories very much like how oil droplets behave in water. The idea based on viscoelastic phase separation is rapidly emerging as a universal organization principle capable of explaining the subnuclear architecture and paving a way for predictive modelling of nuclear scale chromatin dynamics. To this end have embarked on developing a general computational framework based on phase-field methodology that captures the basic physics of liquid-liquid like phase separation of intra and inter-chromosomal euchromatin and heterochromatin. The computational framework is called MEsoscale Liquid mOdel of Nucleus (MELON) and is based on a finite element solution of reaction/diffusion equations. Simulations are carried out using C++ utilizing MOOSE numerical library which we have implemented and tested extensively using the startup and supplement allocations on Stampede2. Our preliminary work shows the success of using a liquid like models of chromatin dynamics in that we are able to capture several features of large scale nuclear architecture and dynamics. In particular, we are able to explain the experimentally observed long time and length scale nuclear reorganization processes accompanying phenotypic changes and nuclear architecture inversion by only using a minimal set of physical assumptions and parameters. Our long-term objective is to continue the development of mesoscale modelling techniques and making holistic models that can reconcile data from nuclear imaging and genomics experiment and provide means for predictively modelling salient features of nuclear reorganization starting from physics based principles.

children.name: TG-CTS090100
children.project_abstract: n/a

children.name: A-chgh
children.project_abstract: The focus of this project is to use computational methods to model the chemical kinetics that determine the function of existing materials and to design new materials for energy conversion and storage.  Many of the alternative energy sources being considered to reduce our dependence upon fossil fuels are limited by material properties.  Examples include photovoltaic materials for energy production from sunlight, catalysts for energy conversion to and from chemical fuels, and storage in the form of electrochemical energy in batteries.  The key to designing new materials is a good understanding of the relationship between the material structure and its function.  Theory and modeling are playing an increasingly important role in determining these structure-function relationships.  In the field of catalysis, for example, the binding energy of chemicals to a catalyst surface have been shown to be good descriptors of catalytic activity.  For Li-ion battery materials, the binding of Li determines the cell voltage and diffusion barriers determine the potential current density.  Enabled with reactivity descriptors, computational methods can be used to rapidly screen and search for new materials.  In this project, existing collaborations with synthetic and analytical chemists will be leveraged to validate reactivity descriptors on functional materials for energy conversion and storage.  Specifically, nanoparticle catalysts for oxygen reduction, high capacity cathode materials for Li batteries, and doped oxides for photovoltaic applications will be targeted. The use of computational screening and gradient-based optimization in chemical compound space will then be used to predict new materials with improved function.  Through a close collaboration between theory and experiment, this approach will reduce the slow trial-and-error process of materials discovery and move towards the goal of materials-by-design.

children.name: TG-CTS150057
children.project_abstract: The majority of chemical products we use, from consumer goods to fuels, undergo catalytic processes in their production.  An optimal catalytic material will be highly active for a desired reaction while selective against non-desired reactions that reduce process efficiency and create unwanted byproducts.  For heterogeneous catalytic processes, activity and selectivity are determined by the energetics of breaking and forming bonds on a solid surface, which are influenced by the catalyst composition, structure, as well as the reaction environment.  Quantum chemical calculations have become an essential tool in connecting catalyst and environment to the resulting activity and selectivity, guiding rational design of catalysts and catalytic processes.  I request an XSEDE research allocation to perform density functional theory (DFT) calculations that examine elementary reaction processes on catalytic surfaces, with the specific objectives detailed in the five funded NSF projects these resources will be used to complete.  These projects span a number of catalyst design challenges and applications, including 1)  the computationally guided design of multi-site cascade heterogeneous catalysts, 2) the discovery of new nanoscale oxide catalysts, 3) the development of approaches to determine activation barriers for elementary electrocatalytic reactions, and 4) the design of mixed metal oxysulfides for stable dry reforming of methane.  These resources will also be made available to trainees in our group participating in the NSF Research Traineeship (NRT) program,  NRT-DESE: Computational Materials Education and Training - Bridging Methods and Applications (COMET), as well as undergraduate researchers in our group.

children.name: Alloys
children.project_abstract: We are interested in developing a better understanding of the properties of bimetallic or trimetallic core-shell nanostructures as catalysts for the reduction of oxygen in acid medium. Under these conditions, the metal catalysts may undergo a side corrosion reaction where the metal particles may dissolve into the acid medium. We have recently developed a methodology for testing the durability of Pt-based alloys via computational determination of the electrochemical potential shift with respect to pure platinum. For this, we use the VASP program to compute the surface chemical potential of slab systems. The calculations are done with and without the presence of adsorbed atomic oxygen.

children.name: TG-CTS150005
children.project_abstract: We seek to improve the understanding of catalysis by oxides by a seamless coupling between experiment and theory via, (i) the use of Keggin polyoxometalate clusters as model catalysts, because such clusters are oxides with known and uniform structures that can be reliably simulated using computational tools, and (ii) rigorous comparison of measured thermodynamic and kinetic parameters for reactions on such clusters with energies of relevant reaction intermediates obtained from a range of suitable quantum chemical methods to ascertain the accuracy of calculations and consistency with experiments. The proposed research will use DFT and high-level quantum mechanical computations, as a part of our ongoing effort to extend the mechanistic studies for C-H activations in methanol ODH reactions to various small reactant molecules of relevance in industrial processes for production of energy, fuels and chemicals, and to probe the mechanism of O2 activation required for re-oxidizing the catalyst reduced in the C-H activation step. We anticipate that the proposed research involving comparisons at different levels of theory, together with experimental work being performed at the LSAC laboratory, will establish a new state of the art for computational studies of selective oxidations and advance our understanding of general trends of reactivity in these reactions with reactant and catalyst properties.  The O2 activation calculations will lead to improved understanding of re-oxidaiton mechanism reduced metal oxides; prevalent reactive species such as surface-peroxide-type electrophilic oxygen will potentially be determined from such calculations will help guide experiments that specifically scavenge these species via O-insertion reactions.

children.name: TG-ATM160014
children.project_abstract:
The Center for Analysis and Prediction of Storms (CAPS) at University of Oklahoma (OU) is a leader in the area of radar data assimilation for storm-scale weather prediction. CAPS also continues to expand its breadth of research, with new projects studying regional climate, boundary layer/urban meteorology.  XSEDE computing resources will enable CAPS to conduct high-resolution urban and regional climate simulations to address the following important issues.      

Cities are currently facing unprecedented challenge due to continued global urbanization and global warming.  Nowadays, more than half of population live in cities, and this fraction is expected to increase to two thirds in the following half century. The high dwelling intensity leads to a few urban environmental issues, such as urban heat island (UHI), urban air pollution, and urban water crisis. High-resolution numerical model simulations were proven very useful to investigate these issues [Hu and Xue, 2016; Hu et al., 2013]      

The Great Plains region is known for frequent hazardous convective weather and climate extremes.  Future climate in the Great Plains is projected to be more arid as temperature and evapotranspiration increase with an increased frequency of extreme precipitation events - essentially drought punctuated by flood.  Previous climate assessments in this region using coarse-resolution GCMs have largely avoided any conclusions regarding potential changes of hazardous convective weather due to their inability to simulate these small scale extreme processes. Probabilistic high-resolution dynamically downscaled climate projection is warranted to provide the information needed for key local decision-making at relevant (field-level) scales, especially for a region such as the south Great Plains [Sun et al., 2016].

children.name: TG-ATM130003
children.project_abstract: In response to the emerging research needs identified by National Research Council and Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, with support from NSF, we are developing an Integrated Technology-Driven Earth System Model (ITDEaSM) to link technology options, energy use, and policy choices and resultant emissions with Earth system processes that govern climate change, air quality, water quality, and ecosystem.  ITDEaSM will be developed by coupling and adding capability to a suite of community models to address grand challenges in decadal regional climate predictions and fill in major gaps in existing climate, Earth system, and ecosystem modeling.  Multi-decadal simulations will be performed using ITDEaSM to estimate the long-term impacts of global climate changes on the global-through-urban earth system, including air quality, water quality/supply, forest, and ecosystem.  Our ultimate goal is to quantify such impacts, reduce associated uncertainties, and identify technology choices for co-benefits of climate/Earth system mitigation. During this 1-year allocation time period, our work will focus on model improvement, testing, and initial applications, which will be conducted by 4 post-Ds and 8 graduate students in our project team.  A complex Earth system model like ITDEaSM requires significant high performance computing resources.  To achieve our goals, we request 5,000,000 SUs for computation (4,000,000 SUs on Kraken and 1,000,000 SUs on Ranger) and 50,000 SUs for Nautilus.
children.pi_institution: North Carolina State University at Raleigh

children.name: TG-MCA95C006
children.project_abstract: The Center for Analysis and Prediction of Storms CAPS), a graduated NSF S&T center, continues to maintain a vibrant program of basic and applied research in storm-scale data assimilation and numerical weather prediction (NWP).  CAPS leads the University of Oklahomas participation as a core research partner in an NSF Engineering Research Center (ERC) for Collaborative Adaptive Sensing of Atmosphere (CASA).  CAPS also leads an multi-institution NSF Large Information Technology Research (ITR) project, known as Linked Environments for Atmospheric Discovery (LEAD), that seeks to develop an infrastructure for mesoscale meteorology research and education. Other funded projects include storm-scale data assimilation centered around ensemble Kalman filter and variational data assimilation (DA), and those that seek the understanding of convective storm and tornado dynamics and of initial condition sensitivity through very-large-ensemble approach, the study on the impacts of special data sources. Extension will also be made to study hurricane track and intensity forecasts and their sensitivity to initial and boundary conditions. The grants that supported the research for which supercomputing time is sought in this proposal are listed in the cover page. As a continuation of the experiments of 2007, CAPS seeks resources to perform realtime storm-scale ensemble prediction with increased sophistication that is supported by LEAD and CSTAR grants, and to produce realtime numerical prediction of thunderstorms assimilating data from the CASA radar network. The latter is essential to fulfill the mission of NSF ERC CASA program. In addition, on-demand forecasts will be performed by LEAD across the Teragrid resources. A combined total of 2,576,200 service units (SUs) across LRAC computing platforms is requested.

children.name: TG-ATM170028
children.project_abstract:
Accurate prediction of wind farm performance under realistic conditions is the current challenge in wind energy research. Large-eddy simulations (LES) has been used for process-scale simulations under idealized conditions, such as fixed wind speed and direction, and constant static stability. It is difficult to compare results of such idealized simulations with observations because atmospheric conditions are dynamically evolving in time, due to the diurnal variation. Another source for dichotomy between observations and simulations is that computational studies are very often carried out for a single isolated turbine, or for infinitely-large wind farms leading to the fully-developed wind-turbine array boundary layer. Field observations, however, are for large but finite-sized wind farms, where the number of turbines is at most of the order of a few hundreds. 

The primary aim of this work is to study the performance of a large, finite-sized wind farm under realistic atmospheric forcing using LES. The Firewheel Wind Energy Complex (FWEC) will serve as the primary testbed. This wind farm which is currently under development on the Oklahoma-Texas border is projected to be one of the largest wind farms in the world with over 1200 horizontal axis wind turbines (HAWTs) and will serve as a primary energy source for the Plains and Eastern Clean Line, a new concept for long-distance, high-voltage DC transmission. Our partners in this project, Map Royalty, Inc. are leading the development at the FWEC, and have provided us with historical meteorological data from that site. A computational allocation to perform numerical simulations, informed by the available historical meteorological data, at unprecedented resolutions, would be a unique opportunity to study realistic flow physics of the atmospheric boundary layer (ABL) and the wind farm.

children.name: TG-ATM090042
children.project_abstract: n/a

children.name: TG-ATM190002
children.project_abstract:
Earthâ??s global temperature responds to changes in the balance between incoming solar radiation and outgoing longwave radiation. The largest uncertainty in quantifying the radiative impacts of human emissions on the present and historical climate is caused by the interaction of aerosols with clouds. From a computational modeling standpoint, the main challenge is the multi-scale nature of the problem. Conventional global climate models rely heavily on suboptimal parameterization of cloud-scale processes. On the other hand, global simulations that resolve cloud-scale processes are still prohibitively expensive. 
 
In this XRAC proposal, we address this problem by combining the strengths of a multi-scale model and machine learning techniques to better advance our understanding of aerosol-cloud interactions. We will run the multi-scale Ultra-Parameterized Community Atmosphere Model (UPCAM) that embeds large-eddy resolution cloud resolving models within larger domain climate model columns and train a neural network with the model output to leverage machine learning techniques to estimate the impact of aerosols on cloud radiative properties. First, we will catalogue present-day aerosol-cloud relationships using UPCAM simulations. Second, we will compare simulations with present-day and pre-industrial emissions of aerosols to quantify the impact of anthropogenic aerosol emissions on cloud properties. Third, a neural network will be trained on the output from the UPCAM simulations to test the viability of the neural network predicting the effect of anthropogenic aerosol emissions on cloud properties.

children.name: A-go3
children.project_abstract: A large number of numerical experiments will be conducted to understand global and regional changes of climate, water, ecosystems, and environment under global warming.

children.name: TG-CTS170045
children.project_abstract: Solvent molecules play a critical role in many processes relevant to soft and biological materials, but it is challenging to study the solvent structure and dynamics experimentally due to the fast timescales (picoseconds) and short lengthscales (nanometers) relevant to solvent behavior. Instead, molecular simulation methods can be employed to accurately characterize complex solvent environments, particularly in biomolecular systems. The Van Lehn group is developing and applying computational tools to study solvent behavior at biomolecular interfaces where competing substrate-solvent and solvent-solvent interactions, along with long timescales for phenomena of interest, pose significant challenges. We request XSEDE computational support for three projects that focus on: 1) modeling mixed-solvent effects in acid-catalyzed reactions, 2) predicting hydrophobic interactions at heterogeneous interfaces, and 3) understanding cooperative interactions during the translocation of charged protein elements across lipid bilayers. These projects are united in their shared goal of understanding the role of complex solvent interactions by applying cutting-edge computational tools to each problem, and will yield physical insight to guide the design of new synthetic systems. The proposed work is of broad relevance to the biophysics, biomaterials, and catalysis communities and will immediately contribute to ongoing experimental collaborations.

children.name: TG-CTS110039
children.project_abstract:
It is requested computing time and storage space on the TeraGrid resources to perform extensive solvent-explicit molecular dynamics simulations of concentrated suspensions of cuboidal particles under shear flow conditions. Specifically, ~750,000 SUs are requested in such clusters as Lonestar, Abe, and Steele.
Motivated by the growing ability to experimentally produce particles of almost any imaginable shape in the nano- to micro-size range, the goal of this proposal is to apply molecular simulation methods to study the dynamic properties of disordered and partially ordered phases (mesophases) of systems containing cuboidal particles. This goal lies within the scope of nanotechnology that seeks to achieve greater control of order innanoscale objects via the use of both self-assembly properties and external forces (like shear). The models used are coarse-grained representations of colloidal particles whose effective inter-particle interactions can be tuned by surface-functionalization or by the composition of the solvent media. 
Based on the results of past Monte Carlo equilibrium simulations, it is expected that many of the suspensionswill exhibit a liquid-crystalline phase in between the isotropic phase (at low concentrations) and crystal phase (at high concentrations). To elucidate how particles and defects move in such phases, molecular dynamic simulations will be performed to track and characterize their motion at equilibrium conditions and under steady shear-flow. The mesophases may exhibit unusual shear response like shear thickening and yield stress.  
This work is complementary to experimental efforts by collaborators who are trying to realize the predicted novel phases and test their mechanical and rheological properties.In the long term, our results could impact the ceramic, plastics, and semiconductor industries by helping broaden the approaches available to develop strong nanocomposites with high particle loadings, sieves with regular topology, liquid armors, colloid-based mesocrystals for light control in photonic materials, sensors and stress-sensitive lubricants sensitive and nanocrystal arrays for photovoltaics

children.name: TG-CTS130035
children.project_abstract: n/a

children.name: TG-CTS170020
children.project_abstract: In this anticipated project, XSEDE resources will be used to perform atomistic simulations for studying mass, momentum, and thermal transport in various nanoscale systems. Molecular dynamics (MD) and density functional theory (DFT) will be employed to directly examine physical atomic behaviors to enhance fundamental knowledge of transport phenomena. The proposed research includes (1) mass diffusion in joining of metallic nanostructures (Cu-Ni-Ag), (2) water behaviors (phase change, viscosity, and convective heat transfer) in nanochannels, (3) mass and thermal transport characteristics of aluminum alloys, (4) thermal transport control of novel two-dimensional materials, and (5) diffusion and oxidation in a chromia-containing scale. From utilization of MD simulations, we will analyze atomic structure evolution, displacement speed, thermal vibration, and potential energy of constituent atoms to ultimately assess various transport properties (mass: self-diffusivity and activation energy, momentum: viscosity, thermal: conductivity and heat transfer coefficient). Moreover, in the determination of thermal transport in metallic materials, electron-phonon coupling from DFT calculations will also be considered within Boltzmann transport equations for more effective rendering of accurate results. Based on preliminary simulations using XSEDE startup allocations, we estimate a total of 2,200,000 core-hours on Stampede, Bridges, and Comet will be required for this proposed research.

children.name: TG-DMR180118
children.project_abstract: Wide band-gap semiconductors are materials with a band gap larger than approximately 2 eV. These materials are of interest for a variety of applications, from blue to ultraviolet electro-optics, including sensors, light-emitting diodes and lasers, as well as high-power and high-temperature transistors. In our group we have carried out research on SiC, the group-III nitrides (e.g. GaN), a related family of II-IV-N2 nitrides (e.g. ZnGeN2), ZnO and most recently Ga2O3. Defects play a dominant role for the semiconducting, optical, and other properties of these materials. Our research has as goals to calculate the energies of formation of defects and from them the equilibrium position of the Fermi level in the gap and the defect concentrations, the transition levels of different charge states of the defects and the defect level positions involved in optical transitions.  Uniquely we also study the electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) parameters: the g-tensor and hyperfine interactions, which provide a powerful way to identify defects experimentally. We use the Gauge Including Projector Augmented Wave (GIPAW) method which is integrated with the Quantum Espresso (QE) software. The most recent version of QE has significantly improved with respect to parallel implementations and uses hybrid MPI/OpenMP parallelism with Eigenvalue Solvers for Petaflop-Applications (ELPA). This version of QE was tested in our group  and showed very efficient parallel performance. We are requesting a Startup account to further study various defects and defect complexes  of current interest in Ga2O3, LiGaO2, ZnGeN2 and ZnO. These calculations are computationally demanding because they require large supercell models and extremely good convergence to obtain the details of defect spin densities with sufficient accuracy for the EPR parameter determination.

children.name: CONTROL-LUB
children.project_abstract:
Self-lubricating coatings with lubricant species release have enormous potential for protection of surfaces subject to extreme working conditions. This project aims to significantly increase the service lifetime of such coatings for high temperature applications, by developing TiSiN coatings to control diffusion of the lubricant agent (Ag). 
An atomistic quantitative model of Ag diffusion and release will be developed, to predict the optimum nanocomposite structure, e.g,  SiNx matrix separation of TiN(Ag) nanograins, to produce long-term lubrication at high temperature.

children.name: TG-DMR100005
children.project_abstract:
Recent successful fabrication of graphene and few-layer graphene in experiment has ignited tremendous research interest. The unique electronic structure of graphene gives rise to many outstanding features and broad potential applications. However, the lack of a finite band gap is a big obstacle for the application of graphene on practical microelectronic devices because the intrinsic-graphene-based transistor cannot be switched off by the controlling voltage. Therefore, how to generate a finite band gap and, moreover, how to control the band gap are urgent and important research tasks.

Experimental and theoretical studies have shown a few approaches to modify the electronic structure and band gap of graphene and bilayer graphene. We will focus on two of them; one is the chemical adsorption of molecules onto the graphene sheet; the other one is applying electric field to induce a finite band gap in bilayer graphene. For the first research topic, we plan to carry out first-principles studies to reveal how the molecules are adsorbed by graphene at the quantum-mechanics level and discover what kind of patterns these molecules prefer to form. For the second research topic, we will perform the first-principles calculation to study how the applied electric field induces a finite band gap in bilayer graphene. Many-electron effects will be included for the first time. Through this study we expect to explain the discrepancy between the prior theoretical calculations and experimental measurements and explore how important many-electron effects are in the electronic structure of two-dimensional semimetals. Finally, the change of the electronic structure induced by above methods will definitely have impact on the optical response of graphene and bilayer graphene. We plan to study optical absorption spectra of bilayer graphene under an applied electric field with many-electron effects included. Through this study, we hope to understand how electron-hole interactions modify the infrared optical absorption spectra of bilayer graphene with a finite band gap.

In order to realize above research plans, a powerful and efficient parallelized computing platform is of importance. Therefore, we write this proposal to TeraGrid for necessary computing allocation. We believe that these proposed plans will not only improve our understanding of the electronic structure and optical response of graphene but also significantly contribute to practical applications of this novel material. Moreover, our research plans will benefit the computational condensed matter research community in Washington University and St. Louis region and provide excellent opportunities for researchers to learn attractive properties of graphene and many-electron effects on nanostructures.

children.name: FTA-Chen
children.project_abstract: Frontera Early Access.

children.name: battery
children.project_abstract:
The design of novel materials is critical for many potential new
and clean energy technologies. Whether it is hydrogen or solar, thermoelectrics
or energy storage, the effectiveness of these technologies is severely limited
by the available materials. Focused on energy storage in current Li-ion batteries,
the use of a cobalt oxide as the most common material in the cathode is approaching
to its end, due to the fact that the Co must be obtained from natural resources.
So, while the new generation of Li-air batteries are still been developed in the
labs, we must concentrate our efforts in the search of new materials to be used as cathode
in Li-ion batteries, to improve their efficiency and performance.
In this project, we are going to use first-principles calculations to compute
several properties (geometry, band gap, ionic conductivity,...) of some materials
we believe they are most likely suitable candidates for that purpose.

children.name: TG-OCE180010
children.project_abstract:
We request computing and storage capacity on the XSEDE Bridges cluster in order to per-
form high-resolution direct numerical simulation (DNS) of breaking waves in deep and shallow
water, a multiscale problem. The resource request is for an amount of 8 million CPU-hours,
or 167,000SUs on the Stampede2 SKX cluster. The purpose of the research is to obtain well-
resolved numerical data on spray and droplet formation, transport and entrainment into the
atmosphere resulting from the breaking action of the wave. This phenomenon, along with the
complementary process of bubble entrainment, constitutes an important but poorly understood
part of climate dynamics, and is responsible to a large degree for the energy transfer between
the ocean and the atmosphere. The simulations will be conducted using the Basilisk code to
solve the viscous incompressible Navier-Stokes equations in water and air, modelling surface
tension. Basilisk is the successor of the proven Gerris Flow Solver, which has previously been
used for problems of this kind to great eect. Scaling exercises have been performed by the PI on
an XSEDE startup grant on the requested cluster, among others, which informs the requested
amount of SUs. This project will be undertaken by the PI at the Mechanical & Aerospace
Engineering Department at Princeton University, in the research group led by L. Deike. The
personnel and incidental equipment are funded by the Princeton Environmental Institute.

children.name: TG-OCE160020
children.project_abstract:
This allocation request provides support for two NSF-funded projects: (i) NSF OCE-1538702 and (ii) NSF ANT-1543388, both related to simulating ocean mesoscale eddy dynamics. 

The goal of (i) is to adapt existing ocean eddy parametrizations to continental slopes, and thereby improve the fidelity of predictive ocean and climate models. We will develop a suite of eddy-resolving process simulations with steep bottom topography. These will be used to analyze various dynamical aspects of mesoscale turbulence over steep slopes, such as the inverse energy cascade and routes to dissipation of momentum and energy. We will use these simulations to develop and test a new parametrization of eddy transport and mixing over steep slopes.

The goal of (ii) is to develop a high-resolution regional ocean/sea ice model of the Weddell Sea, allowing us to analyze the relative influences of tides, eddies and larger- scale currents on water mass transport and transformation in a site that is critical for the global ocean overturning circulation. Specifically, we will use the model output identify the relative roles of tides and eddies in transporting water masses across the continental slope, in moving water masses around the continental shelf, and in mixing and entrainment between these water masses.

children.name: NCHRP-12-113
children.project_abstract: This project is focused on the loading and member stress ranges for the evaluate of the fatigue performance of bracing is steel bridges.  The program Abacus will be used to carry out parametric studies on the behavior of steel bridge systems.
children.pi_institution: Phil M Ferguson Structural Engineering Laboratory

children.name: TG-CTS190050
children.project_abstract: The overall objective of our research is to exploit shape flexibility of topology optimization and additive manufacturing to develop optimal heat sinks for high heat-flux removal. Topology optimization is a physics-based computational design method that can automatically generate structural layout for optimal performances. Topology optimization of conjugate heat transfer systems such as heat sinks is computationally expensive. The optimization process typically involves hundreds of iterations. In each iteration, it needs to solve coupled Navier-Stokes fluid equations and advection-diffusion thermal equations. Our preliminary implementation of our optimization package has been run on an 80-core node through our campus clusters. The goal of using XSEDE resource (Stampede2) is two-fold: 1) reducing discovery time, i.e. using super-computer resource to accelerate the computational process for discovering optimal shape and topology for best convective heat transfer, and 2) improving design resolutions and their thermofluid performances such as heat transfer rate and pressure drop. In topology optimization, minimal feature size of the resulting designs depends critically on the mesh resolution. Thus, higher mesh resolution enabled by XSEDE resource would result in finer features, which would in turn lead to structures with better heat transfer and less pressure drop.

children.name: TG-PHY170050
children.project_abstract: The Compact Muon Solenoid (CMS) is one of the two general-purpose particle physics detectors at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC). The CMS Collaboration co-discovered the Higgs boson in 2012, has provided constraints on many models of new physics, and has made many precise measurements of the properties of known particles. 661 scientific papers have been submitted to date. The collaboration is now actively analyzing data recorded in 2016 and 2017, with an emphasis on searches for dark matter and supersymmetric particles and measurements of the properties of the Higgs boson. The prompt delivery of scientific results depends on the availability of computing resources that are capable of performing extensive simulations of physics processes in short amounts of time. The full suite of CMS physics measurements requires the simulation of billions of proton-proton collision events, including both processes that would arise from new, speculative physics models and those that arise from standard model processes that would be the background to the new physics.  We propose to use XSEDE resources at Stampede2, Bridges and Comet for the simulation of one billion collision events during the first quarter of 2018.  Not only will this provide 10\% of the simulations needed during this quarter for the work of the global collaboration in performing dozens of physics measurements, it will also allow us to demonstrate the use of XSEDE resources at very large scales in preparation for meeting the needs of CMS at the planned High Luminosity LHC.

children.name: TG-IBN140002
children.project_abstract: Computational neuroscience has seen tremendous growth in the recent years. This is evident from the large number of publications, in prestigious neuroscience journals, that are more and more based on modeling in the field of neuroscience. This has motivated development of parallel simulation environments such as NEURON, GENESIS3, MOOSE, NEST, Brian and PyNN. During this same time there has been significant development of Cyberinfrastructure resources consisting of High Performance Computing (HPC) machines, fast networks, next generation data and storage technologies and software that can create and manage complex workflow, automatically run parallel simulations, and handle data/output retrieval/transfer. The more complex neuroscience problems, which involve network models, optimization or exploration of high dimensional parameter spaces etc., require access to HPC machines and data storage. Access to national scale CI/HPC can help broaden the base of students and researchers, who can attempt to learn and use computational neuroscience even if a first class HPC center does not exist at their own university or college. Yet accessing and using HPC resources remain difficult for neuro-scientists due to the need to (i) write convincing allocation proposals, (ii) understand complex HPC architectures, (iii) master complex OS/software environment, (iv) optimally install neuronal simulation software, (v) learn policies and batch system environments, (vi) manage data transfer and retrieval, and (vii) understand remote authentication process. This project involves building a Neuroscience Gateway (NSG) and providing it as a service which will simplify the CI/HPC environment and reduce the barrier to access and use HPC resources for neuro-scientists. Similar gateways have been successfully developed for other fields such as nano technology, phylogenetics, bioinformatics, chemistry, weather prediction etc. and allow utilization of XSEDE HPC resources extremely efficiently by large number of gateways users. The proposed NSG gateway will provide optimally installed parallel neuronal software (NEURON, GENESIS3, MOOSE, NEST, Brian and PyNN) on HPC resources of Trestles and Lonestar for which we request the allocation. We expect that, following the success of other science gateways, this NSG will allow large number of neuro-scientists easily and efficiently use these parallel neuronal software on XSEDE HPC resources and enable, enhance and broaden computational neuroscience research and education. The sited NSF Advances in Biological Informatics (ABI) grant, from the NSF Division of Biological Infrastructure (DBI), to the PI and one of the Co-PIs of this allocation proposal will be basis for the development of this NSG. Preliminary parallel scaling study has been done using the Startup and associated Supplemental allocation. And we have also analyzed the usage of the 300K (Startup and Supplemental) SUs by the NSG users and based on that requested allocation in this XRAC proposal. We are requesting allocation on both the Trestles and the Lonestar machines on which we also received the initial Startup allocation and all of that allocation was used up by the NSG users. Neuro-scientists will be simulating lot larger and more complex neuronal models than the ones which were run on the Triton and Lonestar cluster for benchmark purposes and hence we expect larger core count parallel jobs being run using the requested allocation.

children.name: TG-ASC140026
children.project_abstract: Computational Anatomy is a discipline focused on the quantitative analysis of the variability in biological shape. Large Deformation Diffeomorphic Metric Mapping (LDDMM) is the key algorithm, which assigns computable descriptors of anatomical shapes and a metric distance between them. This is achieved by describing populations of anatomy as a group of diffeomorphic transformations applied to a template, and using a metric on the space of diffeomorphisms. LDDMM is being used extensively in the neuroimaging (\url{www.mristudio.org}) and cardiovascular imaging (\url{www.cvrgrid.org}) communities. Modern high resolution scanners are producing images which require the computational power of multiple processing units. One of our goals is to analyze the high-resolution images on large memory (1TB memory) machines with the existing openMP implementation of LDDMM. The initial startup year was extremely successful in meeting our goals and a science gateway has been created. The Computational Anatomy Science Gateway (\url{https://www.xsede.org/gateways-listing}) is established to support neuroimaging community. In this year, we plan to continue with development and expansion of the science gateway role to support these two communities. The neuroimaging community (\url{www.mristudio.org}) that this gateway will support has 6000 users, who are beginning to transfer to our science gateway model, while we continue to expand our user base. Our local cluster has processed over 47K brains since 2009 which required 450K CPU-hrs on 8 core nodes with 32GB of memory. Over the past year we have begun to offload the majority of jobs from our local cluster to XSEDE resources. The gateway is enabling the processing of large populations in parallel on multiple cores. With these new data sets, innovations in software optimization, and algorithms that benefit from statistical knowledge of populations are being explored. Significant development with GPGPUs has occured, and we hope to further exploit the Xeon Phi co-processors in the same manner. In addition to the neuroimaging community, the cardiovascular community (\url{www.cvrgrid.org}) will also utilize the gateway for shape analysis (\url{http://cvrgrid.org/features/cardiac-c}) in the future if resources allow.

children.name: modRIPseq
children.project_abstract: The goal of this project is to identify RNA transcripts that are selectively oxidized under various oxidative stress models. Experimentally, we have generated large sequencing datasets >500 million that must be aligned and analyzed by various methods, for which we are requesting this project allocation.

children.name: TG-CHE140071
children.project_abstract: Enzyme Cytochrome P450 and coenzyme vitamin B12 have similar physical and bio-chemical features of their activation mechanisms due to their similar structures. Both molecules are activated by the influence of the substrate or by the influence of the electronic transfer. The special effect similar to Pseudo-Jahn-Teller effect is responsible for the activation of these bio-systems. DFT, MCSCF and single point CCSD(T) electronic structure methods are expected to identify both,  the structural mechanisms and the vibronic e. g. Pseudo-Jahn-Teller effect influence on coenzyme vitamin B12 coenzyme and enzyme porphyrin P450 activation in multiple biological processes.

children.name: A-ch511
children.project_abstract:
This research work is focus on investigation of the relationship between microstructure and physical properties of the porous materials, such as an oil bearing rock, a piece of paper, or a polymer composite. Discovering the accurate relationship is a long standing problem of theoretical and practical interest in many fields of technology: 1) Build virtual porous materials numerically on the computer. A detailed charateristics of the micriostructure can be obtained; 2) Develop the sophisticated algorithm to simulate the single phase flow through the porous materials, and calculate its transport properties; 3) Develop new algorithm to simulate 
the electrical conducticion of the materials.

children.name: NGS-DataAnalysis
children.project_abstract: We use an advanced set of state-of-the-art technologies, including high-performance computing, signaling network analysis and next-generation sequencing. To achieve systematic and significant insights in disease progression, this project focuses on systematic computational analysis of signaling networks in human cancer. We develop robust bioinformatics and computational algorithms to prioritize driver mutations from next-gen sequencing data.

children.name: iPlant-Collabs
children.project_abstract: The iPlant Collaborative is a successful partnership among UT and several other institutions to provide a comprehensive national cyberinfrastructure. It supports a community science gateway, a REST API, and several joint development, optimization, and scientific sub-projects. This project is intended to coordinate the development and optimization projects, leaving iPlant-Master as a home for the gateway and analysis activities.

children.name: Thompson_Replication
children.project_abstract:
In spite of continued strong interest in the epigenome, very little is known about the processes that transmit epigenetic marks through multiple rounds of DNA replication and cell division in plants and animals. Because cell-to-cell inheritance is crucial to the function of epigenetic marks, understanding their biology requires an intimate knowledge of DNA replication as well as tools to study events occurring in S phase. In the proposed project, the tools and knowledge of DNA replication developed in the previous PGRP project will be used to characterize epigenome dynamics during S phase in two important model systems – maize and Arabidopsis.
A combination of flow cytometry and in vivo labeling will be used to dissect multiple stages within S phase of cells in suspension culture and in planta. A genome-wide approach and deep sequencing technology will be used to address several fundamental questions about the interplay between DNA replication and epigenetic inheritance.

children.name: iPlant-Master
children.project_abstract: The iPlant Collaborative is an NSF funded initiative to build the Cyberinfrastructure to address the grand challenges in plant biology.   iPlant currently has developers and early adopters from more than 40 US institutions and collaborators around the world.

children.name: SD2E-Community
children.project_abstract: The Texas Advanced Computing Center (TACC) in Austin, TX, a world-leading provider of research computing infrastructure, will build and deliver a SD2 Data and Analysis Hub called SD2 Environment (SD2E). The SD2E will enable researchers with varied technical backgrounds to easily collaborate in developing and testing new computational workflows, visualizations, and methods. It will feature reconfigurable analytical interfaces combining Jupyter Notebooks and a web-based graphical workspace built using TACC's DesignSafe application framework, robust integration and access management based on TACC's Agave web service platform, metadata-aware search powered by ElasticSearch, support for low-latency data ingest over high-speed networking and dedicated transfer infrastructure, tiered storage capacity supporting adaptive data management powered by TACC's petascale storage resources, and virtually unlimited access to TACC's unrivaled collection of powerful, architecturally-diverse compute systems. The platform will be operated and supported by a deeply experienced team of computational science professionals who will collaborate actively with all other program performers, as well as provide high quality training, responsive user support, and intensive consulting.

children.name: TG-ATM140021
children.project_abstract:
Recent studies have revealed that among all the tropical oceans, the tropical Atlantic has experienced the most pronounced warming trend over the 20th century. Many extreme climate events affecting the US and other countries surrounding the Atlantic, such as hurricanes and severe flood and drought events, are influenced by conditions in the Atlantic Ocean. It is therefore imperative to have accurate simulations of the climatic mean and variability in the Atlantic region to be able to make credible projections of future climate change affecting the US and other countries adjoining the Atlantic Ocean. Unfortunately, current-generation IPCC-class climate models exhibit severe biases in their simulations of tropical Atlantic climate. An infamous symptom of the Atlantic biases is the persistent warm sea-surface temperature (SST) bias of more than 6C off the coast of Namibia and Angola, which severely hampers our ability to accurately simulate and project impacts of global climate change in the region. This research focuses on improving our current understanding of causes of the biases, leading to major improvements in simulation and projection of future climate change within the Atlantic sector and beyond. 

Intellectual Merit. The research outlined in this proposal will significantly extend previous understanding of tropical Atlantic biases in a number of ways: 1) oceanic contributions to the biases will be assessed and sources will be identified through a combined analysis of observations, ocean reanalysis products, Intergovernmental Panel for Climate Change (IPCC) model simulations and eddy-resolving regional ocean simulations; 2) atmospheric contributions to the biases will be evaluated by a comparative analysis of atmospheric reanalysis data and convection-resolving regional atmospheric model simulations; 3) the role of ocean-atmosphere interactions in amplifying the oceanic or atmospheric biases will be examined by conducting high-resolution coupled regional climate model (CRCM) simulations. The use of high-resolution (up to 3 km) regional climate models allows explicitly resolving oceanic mesoscale eddies, fronts and upwelling dynamics off the west coast of southern Africa, as well as atmospheric convection and steep orography effects, and thus minimizes model systematic errors due to uncertainties associated with parameterizations of subgrid-scale processes. This modeling approach also isolates sources of the biases from other ocean basins and helps to pinpoint the causes of the biases within the Atlantic basin. It further facilitates a better model-data comparison as recent intense observational programs within the Atlantic sector have together produced an array of fine temporal and spatial resolution data sets that require high-resolution model simulations to fully utilize their advantages. Furthermore, the proposal is timely, because it coincides with the launch of two major European research projects in the study region, i.e., the German project Southwest African Coastal Upwelling System and Benguela Nio (SACUS) led by Brandt and the EU project Enhancing prediction of tropical Atlantic climate and its impacts (PREFACE) led by Keenlyside, both of which are expected to generate new arrays of observations along the southern Africa coast. If funded, we anticipate close collaboration with the European colleagues throughout the project. Combining the new observations with the detailed modeling approach, we expect new breakthroughs in solving tropical Atlantic bias problems.

Broader Impacts.  The research will enhance our understanding of the uncertainties in projecting impacts of global climate change in the Atlantic region, which has enormous socio-economic implications for countries in the region. The CRCM is being developed within the framework of the Coupler (CPL7) software that is part of the NCAR Community Earth System Model (CESM). This framework allows us to easily port parameterizations between CESM and the CRCM, and potentially allow partial coupling between the CESM and the CRCM.  We envision that the CRCM will become a community-modeling tool and be made available to the broader climate research community. Findings from this study on reducing climate model biases will feedback to community model development activities. The project will support one graduate student and one postdoc at Texas A&M University (TAMU) and provide valuable professional development for all young scientists, including Co-PI Patricola, involved in the program.

children.name: TG-ATM170020
children.project_abstract:
The numerical simulations proposed here are aimed at calculating accurate Linear Response Functions (LRFs) of Global Climate Models (GCMs). Calculating accurate LRFs of GCMs has been actively pursued in the past four decades by the climate science community because of the broad applications of such LRFs. However, obtaining accurate LRFs has been found challenging, mainly because turbulence, which plays a key role in the dynamics of atmospheric and oceanic circulations, is poorly understood. The proposed research has two objectives:

Objective 1: To calculate accurate LRFs for several model setups of a widely used atmospheric GCM by employing a method recently developed by the PI. This method will be referred to as the Green's Function (GRF) method. The PI used the GRF method to accurately calculate the LRF of this GCM for one model setup. This accurate LRF has been used to study several problems related to extreme weather events and internal climate variability. Calculating the accurate LRFs for several model setups will allow us to study a wider range of important problems in climate dynamics.

Objective 2: The main drawback of the GRF method is that it is computationally demanding. The second objective is to investigate whether any data-driven method can produce the LRFs with accuracy comparable to that of the GRF method but at a lower computational cost. The performance of several data-driven methods has been found to be poor by various researchers in the past, but the reason(s) behind the poor performance (i.e., low accuracy) is unknown. Another application of the accurate LRFs calculated using the GRF method is that they can be used to identify the source(s) of the poor performance of data-driven methods, as recently demonstrated by PI.

children.name: TG-ATM140018
children.project_abstract: The Sahel is a diverse climatic region that includes a semi-arid tropical zone in the north and a humid tropical climate zone to the south. Understanding Sahelian climate seasonal, interannual, and decadal variability and anomaly has been recognized as a critical component in global climate studies by international programs, such as CLIVAR, GEWEX, and AMMA.  The more severe drought in the last century in the world, strong coupling between Sahel climate and external forcings, the controversy on the causes of the Sahel climate anomalies, especially the drought, and its significant social and economic implications make this region extremely important for the scientific community.   This project will contribute to identification of the attribution of Sahel rainfall changes to anthropogenic and natural drivers, and the effect of climate variability on its ecosystems and water resources

children.name: TG-ATM140004
children.project_abstract: There is ample evidence that dynamical models of the Earth's climate system have the potential to make skillful seasonal predictions of the Indian summer monsoon rainfall from May to September. Currently, however, there is still a major gap between the level of predictability and actual prediction skill, which can be attributed to both inadequate model physics and inaccurate initial state. This proposal requests computational resource to improve the seasonal monsoon prediction, using the version 2 of the Climate Forecast System (CFSv2), which is the current operational climate prediction model at the National Centers for Environmental Predictions. We concentrate on improving the ocean initialization of the forecast system, where most of the memory for seasonal predictability resides. For this purpose, we will conduct a set of 28-year (1979-2009) hindcast experiments, using our newly developed strategy of multiple analysis ensemble (MAE) initialization of ocean. It is expected that the MAE strategy will significantly reduce the effect of the inherent uncertainty in current ocean analyses and thus improve the seasonal prediction skill of the sea surface temperature (SST) in not only the tropical eastern Pacific, but also the western Pacific and Indian Oceans, which will further lead to improved Indian Monsoon prediction. A set of the idealized initialization experiments will also be conducted to help evaluate the effects of the model systematic bias. Furthermore, some sensitivity experiments will be conducted to examine the relative contributions to the monsoon prediction by the SST anomalies in the tropical Pacific, Indian and Atlantic basins respectively, as well as the influences of the atmospheric model resolution on the tropical air-sea interaction. The total requested computational allocation for these experiments is 4.30 million core-hours (su) on Stampede.

children.name: TG-MCA08X012
children.project_abstract:
Chip design faces a crisis  the 40 year process of transistor downscaling has led to atomic-scale features, making devices subject to unavoidable manufacturing irregularities at the atomic scale and to heat densities comparable to a nuclear reactor. A new approach to design that embraces the atomistic, quantum mechanical nature of the constituent materials is necessary to develop more powerful yet energy miserly devices. 

Electronic device engineering and material science must meet at the atomic scale to design new switching concepts. This demands the solution of quantum non-equilibrium statistical mechanics in systems in excess of 107 complex degrees of freedom. Computations of this magnitude have been impossible, due to the lack of sufficiently powerful computers. Petascale computing creates an opportunity to pursue a multi-scale design approach that fuses nano scale (atomic) to the macro scale (wire), which will make possible new kinds of device designs that were previously unimaginable. We propose to develop a general-purpose simulation engine. It will model out-of-equilibrium electron transport in realistically extended devices using fully quantum mechanical (QM) models in an atomistic material description containing millions of atoms. Using this new approach, designers can directly address questions of quantization and spin, tunneling, phonon interactions, and heat generation. 

It is widely accepted that the Non-Equilibrium Green Function Formalism (NEGF) QM statistical mechanics theory, in conjunction with an atomistic basis, can answer these questions. It is also widely perceived that the problem is too hard to solve. The PI Klimeck developed NEMO 1-D, the first NEGF-based commercial-grade device simulator, and NEMO 3-D, which calculates electronic structure (no NEGF) for systems larger than 52 million atoms. The codes have been shown to scale to more than 23,000 / 8,192 cores, respectively, on TOP500 machine numbers 2, 7, 8, 30, and 46.
