We propose to extend the NEGF capabilities of NEMO 1-D with the NEMO 3-D electronic structure description to form the next generation device and materials engineering toolkit OMEN. The necessary levels of parallelism to tackle the problem on 200,000+ CPUs have been designed and demonstrated to scale well. Computer scientists and HPC experts embedded in the team will guide the implementation and explore performance, execution reliability, and alternative hardware and algorithms. 

This research and development has been funded through a PetaApps award by NSF. This proposal highlights the scaling results we currently have available and indicates why we are requesting a large resource allocation from the TeraGrid.

children.name: TG-CCR180006
children.project_abstract: We propose to use the Stampede 2 cluster at TACC to study algorithms and evaluate performance of tensor algebra primitives, that are prevalent in high-performance computing applications. We describe two coupled lines of research (currently funded through the PIâ??s start-up allocation). The first is to evaluate and tune communication-avoiding matrix factorization algorithms. The second is to tune the Cyclops Tensor Framework library via its driver applications. The directions are coupled in that the study of parallel matrix factorization algorithms target improvement of library routines, while the library infrastructure will be used for prototypes of algorithm variants. We report on the parallel scaling on supercomputers with standard CPU architectures achieved by our existing codes for both research directions. In both cases, we show that it is timely and promising to conduct a detailed performance study (100,000 node hours) of these codes on the Knightâ??s Landing processors used on Stampede 2. The first (algorithmic) component of the project has potential to impact a wide range of basic distributed-memory matrix libraries. The second (library) component corresponds to an key developments and evaluation of a tensor library with a number of existing massively-parallel applications.
children.pi_institution: University of Illinois at Urbana Champaign

children.name: TG-CCR180052
children.project_abstract: This proposal focuses on the development of new sparse linear solver techniques in order to reduce runtime and improve energy efficiency while considering the importance of resilience on high performance systems. The solutions of sparse linear systems of equations dominate the execution time of many scientific simulation codes. As the number of cores and threads increase, many large distributed solvers will have larger domains that need to be solved concurrently. However, energy and resilience are becoming a larger concern as dynamic power approaches static power making the issue of building new solvers even more difficult, and our goal is to better understand these two factors in order to try to achieve a linear time solver by means of approximation.  To better understand resilience, energy, and performance, observation will be made to solve methods that use some kind of approximation, e.g., mixed precision or approximate cache loads.  Models are to be constructed from these observations to build a relationship between resilience, energy, and performance.  From the understanding gained, we will construct prototype solver packages that can be used by the high performance computing community to improve their simulation codes. In order to complete this work, we request access to varies different systems in order to make observation and build the prototype solver packages. This request amounts to 2000su on Stampede2, 40000su on Bridges Regular Memory, and 500su on Bridges GPU.  This amount would provide us enough time to continue this research for the PI and two undergraduate research students at a small liberal arts college devoted to student research.

children.name: TG-EAR180001
children.project_abstract: Deformation of Earth's tectonics plates inherently reflects the forces driving deformation and the rheological (constitutive) properties of the deforming material. At both short-term (e.g., seconds) and long-term (millions of years), a wide range of observations suggest the Earth's lithosphere undergoes deformation through a combination of highly non-linear brittle, viscoelastic and viscous deformation. Here, I propose to continue using state-of-the-art numerical simulations of 3D lithospheric deformation to constrain the impact of rheology on continental rifting (e.g., extension). Specifically, the first component of the proposed work will examine the impact of viscoelastic flexure on the evolution of 3D normal fault populations and individual fault growth. The remaining components of the proposed work will build directly on these models and examine the effects of pressure boundary conditions and extension obliquity. Significantly, the proposed simulations associated with these three topics are directly influenced either by previous 2D studies or detailed geologic observations in rifted margins. In all cases, the simulations will be run with open-source community software and made publicly available (software, model files, results) through journal archives or version control repositories. Combined, the results of the proposed simulations and their open availability to the community will advance our understanding of the key processes controlling continental rifting and allow the geodynamics to build directly on this work.

children.name: TG-EAR160027
children.project_abstract: We will develop and apply finite element models of viscous flow that allow us to better understand the underlying physics of plate tectonics and mantle convection. The computational models are closely linked to a wide variety of observations, including seismicity, the seismic structure of the earths interior, the kinematics of plates and the geological evolution of the continents. This allocation covers three science topics covered in three proposals funded by the NSF.  First, we use time-dependent, spherical models of mantle convection that are closely linked to plate kinematic models. A key objective of this work is to understand the long-term topographic evolution of continents and sea-level change. We will also be able to use the outputs of these global models to better understand the dynamics of the lowermost mantle. Second, we use a new finite element model with multi-physics to look at the detailed dynamics of a process called subduction (this is the process when a plate is returned to the earths interior). Third, we will look at the initiation of subduction, a major unknown in plate tectonics. We have requested 9.4M SUs on the TACC Stampede platform and have demonstrated good to excellent parallel scaling for the two software packages that well be using.

children.name: TG-EAR180025
children.project_abstract:
The hotspots that we observed on Earthâ??s surface, such as the Hawaii, are often suggested to be caused by partial melting of mantle plumes. Mantle plumes typically form at Earthâ??s thermal boundary layer, such as the core-mantle boundary (CMB). Being hot and buoyancy, mantle plumes could rise from the CMB to beneath the lithosphere. The impinging of mantle plumes on the lithosphere increases surface topography which is called dynamic topography. The density anomaly associated with the mantle plumes and the induced surface topography cause changes to the Earthâ??s gravity fields. 

Mantle plumes play a critical role in the Earthâ??s evolution, including the long-term climate change. However, the physical properties of mantle plumes (e.g., size, temperature, density, and viscosity) remain not well constrained, which is partly due to the relatively small size of plumes that make them difficult to be imaged by seismic observations. This project proposes to use numerical modeling to build the relationships between the physical properties of the mantle plumes and the lithosphere and the surface expressions of mantle plumes, namely, the melt production, dynamic topography and geoid anomaly. We have previous developed methods to compute these observables from mantle convection models using our Startup Allocation in the past year. We here request 110,550 SUs and 5,790 GB storage on Stempede2 to apply our methods to systematically explore how physical properties of plumes and the lithosphere are linked to the surface expressions of mantle plumes. As we explained in the section 6 â??Justification of resourcesâ? of the main document, these resources are essential to explore a reasonable scale of parameter space on our models.

children.name: TG-TRA150017
children.project_abstract: I will be using the allocation to help Duke researchers understand how to use XSEDE resources.

children.name: TG-TRA140025
children.project_abstract: I am a new Campus Champion for Georgia Tech with no prior XSEDE usage experience. I am hoping to get an allocation to test most scientific codes so I can help the researchers better. Thank you for your consideration!

children.name: A-ccvis
children.project_abstract: Visualization

children.name: Scattering-Propertie
children.project_abstract: We study the scattering properties of nanoscale systems,  including models of  small molecules and two dimensional condensed matter systems. This gives of information about quasibound states and decay processes in such systems.

children.name: COSC6365-Fall-2019
children.project_abstract: COSC6365 is an Intro to HPC course covering OpenMP, OpenACC/OpenMP and MPI and parallel algorithms at an introductory level and tools for developing efficient codes

children.name: TG-ASC160051
children.project_abstract: Enable staff assigned to WBS 2.2.2 Extended Support for Research Teams and 2.2.3 Novel and Innovative Projects to carry out their tasks.

children.name: COMPUTER AND INFORMATION SCIENCE AND ENGINEERING (CISE)
SC-ABM
children.project_abstract: Tumor associated angiogenesis is the development of new blood vessels in response to proteins secreted by tumor cells. These new blood vessels allow tumors to continue to grow beyond what the pre-existing vasculature could support. This project is aimed at developing a mathematical model to simulate tumor angiogenesis by considering each endothelial cell as an agent, allowing the fields of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) and nutrient to impact the dynamics and phenotypic transitions of each tumor and endothelial cell. We propose an approach to modeling the physical interaction between the vasculature and the tumor.
children.pi_institution: Institute for Computational Engineering and Science

children.name: Galois
children.project_abstract:
Until recently, most applications that required extreme-scale parallel computing
were concerned with simulations of physical systems, many of which are matrix computation based. However, new problem domains are giving rise to applications with very different algorithmic foundations: they require time-consuming computations on large graphs with millions of nodes. Complex
graph problems arise, for example, in computational biology (e.g., protein classification and modeling studies often build homology graphs in which nodes represent proteins and weighted edges represent similarity), in graphics and video processing (e.g., the effective graph cuts image segmentation algorithm
is based on max-flow computations in a graph), and even in traditional finite-element applications (e.g., the meshes are often expressed as graphs in which the nodes represent triangles or tetrahedra and the edges represent adjacencies).

The Galois project is building a system that exploits optimistic parallelization to execute these kinds of applications in parallel. The programming model is sequential Java augmented with two constructs called optimistic set iterators. Results from a first-cut shared-memory implementation of Galois on small-scale multicore processors are promising. Therefore, we would like to study scalability of the Galois system on a large-scale shared-memory system like Maverick.

children.name: JPL-PUB
children.project_abstract: This project encompasses public research that JPL will pursue at TACC

children.name: Machine-learning-app
children.project_abstract: The purpose of this work is to assess the use of machine learning approaches to analyze brain imaging data for diagnostic and treatment response purposes. Previous work has identified a complex neural system associated with attention bias and that attention bias has been tied to vulnerability and maintenance of mental illness. We are fortunate to have access to a large database of multimodal neuroimaging data in well characterized individuals. Examining these datasets using machine and deep learning approaches promises to reveal key neural networks that support and predict negative attention bias as well as eventual response to treatment.

children.name: TG-CCR140039
children.project_abstract: Campus Champion allocation
children.pi_institution: University of Puerto Rico at Mayagüez

children.name: TG-DEB190013
children.project_abstract: Much of our understanding of the mechanisms by which biotic interactions shape ecological communities has been constrained by the methods available to study the diverse secondary metabolites that drive plant relationships with other organisms.  However, chemical ecology is on the cusp of a revolution. Recent innovations in analytical chemistry and chemo- and bioinformatics make it possible to infer the molecular formulas and likely structures of thousands of unknown chemical compounds, and hence to study the chemical ecology of plants, and the organisms with which they interact, even in species-rich and understudied systems such as tropical forests.  As a beginning assistant professor in Integrative Biology at the University of Texas at Austin and soon-to-be research associate at the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute in Panama, my research program seeks to ride the cutting edge of these developments in chemistry to rest fundamental hypotheses concerning the role of plant secondary metabolites in community ecology and evolution. My students, postdocs, collaborators, and I will take advantage of XSEDE computing resources to process liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS) data to identify metabolites, infer molecular formulas, and predict molecular structures for compounds detected in plant tissue from >2000 tree species sampled in field sites around the world.  Many of our field sites are forest dynamics plots in the Smithsonian Forest Global Earth Observatory-Center for Tropical Forest Science (ForestGEO-CTFS) global network that range from subarctic boreal forest to hyperdiverse tropical rainforest.  Secondary metabolite data for these trees will be used to i) model the effect of secondary metabolites on performance and survival, and hence community dynamics, in forest dynamics plots spanning latitudinal, climatic, and diversity gradients, ii) infer the chemical variation that drives insect herbivore and microbial pathogen host-use patterns using statistical approaches based on genome-wide association studies (GWAS) and machine learning, and iii) model the relationship between chemical evolution and lineage diversification/speciation in plant phylogenies.  This research agenda will require the use of open-source software as well as custom, home-brewed models, primarily in R.

children.name: cfd-pah
children.project_abstract: In this project we wish to derive hemodynamic indices associated with the blood flow dynamics in patient-specific models of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) and correlate them with clinical metrics that are indicative of disease progression. The hemodynamic indices are calculated from computational fluid dynamics (CFD) simulations of the pulmonary arterial geometries under transient flow conditions. We wish to run these simulations using OpenFoam (an open-source CFD solver), for which user-defined functions will need to be created and compiled along with the source code. OpenFoam is highly parallelizable and scalable, so we would like to explore the feasibility of using this solver with a TACC startup allocation. We have generated approximately 30 patient-specific meshes of the aforementioned pulmonary arterial geometries. However, for startup resources we will use only one of the meshes to study the scalability of OpenFoam to solve this transient problem and evaluate the effects of time step size and number of periodic flow cycles needed to achieve time-independent results.
children.pi_institution: University of Texas at San Antonio

children.name: Nanopartile-interact
children.project_abstract: It remains a major challenge to develop, validate, and apply low-cost, rapid, and ultrasensitive diagnostic tests for infectious diseases. Plasmonic gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) present a clear pink to dark red color, and change to blue, purple or black when getting close to each other due to plasmonic coupling, referred to as the plasmonic coupling assay (PCA). Similar to other rapid diagnostic tests, PCA is simple, fast, low-cost, but lacks sufficient sensitivity. So far gold nanospheres have been predominantly used for PCA due to the ease of synthesis and visible colorimetric shift. Our preliminary result suggests a 10-fold higher virus binding effectiveness using AuNRs than spherical AuNPs. Furthermore, it has been shown that silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) have higher plasmonic absorption than AuNPs of same size and may give stronger plasmonic coupling. The overall goal of this study is to engineer nanoprobes with stronger plasmonic coupling strength and optimal coupling geometry, and test their diagnostic performance using digital nanobubble detection. We will design nanoprobes for optimal plasmonic coupling strength by systematically investigating various geometries and compositions through advance numerical modeling. Specifically, discrete dipole approximation (DDA) and Boundary element method (BEM) will be used to study the laser nanoparticle interaction. Then, Molecular dynamics (MD) simulation will be employed to investigate how laser energy is transferred to nanoparticle surrounding. These simulation need to be run on high performance computing facilities.

children.name: Sandia-Fracture-Chal
children.project_abstract: Over the past two decades, the peridynamic theory has shown great promise in modeling crack initiation and growth. The theory has been mostly applied to brittle fracture; its ability to predict ductile fracture has been mostly untested. Silling et al. (2007) introduced a correspondence modeling framework for incorporating classical constitutive theories into peridynamics. Shortcomings associated with the approach, such as the unphysical problem of matter interpenetration, were reported by Tupek and Radovitzky (2014). To address the issues, they extended the original theory by incorporating non-linear bond strain measures. Recently Foster and Xu (2018) generalized Tupek’s model and presented a constitutive correspondence framework with kinematic variables (e.g. a nonlocal right Cauchy-Green deformation tensor) that can be applied directly to finite deformation plasticity. Although the model is currently limited to isotropic materials, its suitability for very large deformations over the previous peridynamic models appear to outweigh the shortcoming. This Sandia Fracture Challenge provided us an opportunity to explore the new model’s performance.
children.pi_institution: Department of Petroleum and Geosystems Engineering

children.name: TG-CDA100010
children.project_abstract:
This proposal describes work on the multiscale simulation of complex realistic electrochemical systems where important physical phenomena span a wide range of length- and time-scales. The goals of the multi-year project have been to develop improved algorithms for multiscale simulation, to test their performance while quantifying uncertainty in physicochemical mechanisms and associated parameter values, and to utilize the simulations to design improved systems. To accomplish this goal, we have examined experimental data with sensitivity analysis, parameter estimation, and model selection tools. The initial physical application chosen for study was the copper electrodeposition processes for fabricating on-chip wiring interconnections between transistors, especially the role of trace amounts of additives that are critically important. In this proposal, new PIs are added that expand the range of numerical simulation methods as well as the physical applications.  The requested computational resources are for 1,966,860 SUs on the NCSA Xeon Linux Cluster (Abe/QueenBee). Support for the scientific research aspects of this work is sponsored by the National Science Foundation (ITR CISE-0428912, $976,825, 9/1/04 to 8/31/09; CBET-0828002; $163,558, 9/1/08 to 8/31/11; CBET-0828123, $100,000, 9/1/08 to 8/31/11; NRO-$682,000, 01/01/09 to 12/12/10; CISE/CCF-0810294, $300,000, 8/15/08 to 7/31/11; CBET-0852657, $300,000, 9/1/09 to 8/31/12; CISE/CCF-0915718, $450,000, 9/1/09 to 8/31/12; CISE/CNS-0941497, $2,016,000, 10/1/09 to 9/30/2013). The computational effort described in this request includes deterministic as well as stochastic techniques separately and, by linking them, enables multi-scale investigations of varying electrochemical interactions and applications.

We have pursued a multi-prong approach for accelerating the stochastic algorithms and the deterministic simulations, in addition to use of parallelization. Improved algorithms and code linkages developed during 2004-06 made it possible to tackle significantly more difficult applications which, during 2007-08, were targeted on early stages of electrochemical nucleation, growth, and coalescence of metal nanoclusters and thin films on various surfaces. Such phenomena occur at time and length scales that are hundreds of times smaller than the previous applications, giving rise to issues of numerical stiffness, mesh refinement, and need for accelerated methods. In addition during 2007-08, we created a new generation of algorithms along with a new generation of systems in which simulation predictions could be compared with experimental data for parameter estimation and model validation. Throughout these successive generations of studies, the overall strategy has been to use parameter sensitivity, parameter estimation, and model discrimination techniques to select the hypothesis that most likely describes experimentally-observed phenomena. Parameter sensitivity simulations, used for both parameter estimation and model selection techniques, focus on obtaining the key fundamental parameters from large sets of experimental data. In addition to the above studies, as part of this effort, we consider other electrochemical systems such as transport (electrical and chemical transport) through synthetic nanopores and electrochemical phenomena at solid-liquid interfaces. Our multiscale method development for these applications is based on (i) hierarchical integration of quantum, atomistic, mesoscale, and classical continuum theories and (ii) quasi-continuum theories where interatomic potentials are directly integrated into the continuum theories.

In this TRAC renewal proposal, we will focus on (i) improved coarse-graining methods for accurate and rapid parameter sensitivity and parameter estimation methods for electrochemical nucleation, growth, and other applications, (ii) optimization of entire complex systems composed of previously-developed multi-scale algorithms, and (iii) application of these methods to a different electrochemical systems ― lithium-ion batteries, supercapacitors, synthetic ion channels, and functional surfaces. The extension to new systems will demonstrate that the algorithm and simulation developments carried out to date are also characteristic of a large class of systems where controlled shape evolution is exploited to produce desired structures. Such characteristics are ubiquitous in nanotechnology, biotechnology, and materials ― where manufacturing processes must ensure quality control at the molecular scale. The algorithms and software are generic over a broad class of problems, and will contribute well beyond the applications used in their development. The availability of such computational tools will accelerate fundamental scientific research as well as engineering design.

children.name: DesignSafe-Lehman
children.project_abstract: Per DesignSafe's allocation policy, this project is being created by Tim Cockerill for Dr.Dawn Lehmans research group.

children.name: BHV-FSI-S
children.project_abstract: This project is to develop numerical methods for fluid-structure interaction (FSI) analysis of native and prosthetic heart valves. Our FSI framework must handle the coupling of complex fluid flows, large structural deformations, contact problems, and geometric variability inherent to heart valves. By using techniques of isogeometric analysis, we will be able to directly analyze spline-based representations of valves. Creating a robust, accurate, and dynamical simulation of valvular FSI will allow us to study the effects of leaflet geometry and material properties on blood flow patterns, and investigate time dependent phenomena such as fatigue damage of bioprosthetic heart valves, where the leaflet properties change over the course of many cycles. We plan to validate our FSI model by comparing computational results to experimental data.

children.name: TG-OCE110011
children.project_abstract: This three year plan for research focuses on the dynamics of oceanic double-diffusive convection, an important small-scale mixing process driven by the two orders of magnitude difference in diffusivities of heat and salt in seawater. The significance of double-diffusive mixing for water-mass transformation and determining the structure of the temperature-salinity relationship in all oceans has become increasingly clear over the last few years. One of the most intriguing aspects of double-diffusive convection is related to its ability to transform smooth vertical gradients into stepped structures consisting of mixed layers separated by thin, stratified interfaces. Recent field data from the tropical Atlantic has shown that vertical fluxes due to salt fingers, within thermohaline staircases, are significantly (by an order of magnitude) enhanced when compared to non-staircase regions with similar stratifications. Thus, it is vital to improve our understanding of thermohaline staircase formation, evolution and large-scale consequences. Double-diffusive mixing plays a fundamental role in the oceans ability to transport and sequester heat, salt, nutrients, pollutants and carbon dioxide. Yet, this small-scale process is not included in most large-scale oceanographic models, including operational Navy models, which severely limits their predictive capabilities. This research plan is aimed at quantifying the double-diffusive transport in both smooth gradients and thermohaline staircases, developing clear insight into the origin of staircases and specifying conditions for their formation. The proposed study will involve numerical process modeling using a pseudo-spectral code, which integrates the Navier-Stokes equations of motion (Boussinesq approximation). Inferences from the model runs will be used to interpret the oceanic fine- and microstructure data and the results of laboratory experiments. Advanced support is requested for collaboration with Dr. Gabriele Jost, who is familiar with the double-diffusive codes and has collaborated with the NPS computational fluid dynamics group in the past. This collaboration involves application of the advanced numerical methods to Double-Diffusion problems. The goal of this collaboration is to perform a series of Direct Numerical Simulations that will form the basis of a parameterization scheme for the General Circulation Models (GCMs). Prof Radko has developed code of his own to solve DDC problems for 2D (SF2D) and 3D (SF3D) problems. The parallelization in these codes is based on OpenMP. In order to handle realistic problem sizes, more computational power is needed than what the current OpenMP version delivers on general multi-core node clusters. SF3D lends itself to MPI parallelization. The 2D version (SF2D) may be a good candidate for running on GPGPU based nodes. Special support is requested for the port of SF2D to a GPGPU system, the development of an MPI based version of SF3D and for the evaluation of existing MPI-based codes and their suitability to the current project.

children.name: TG-CTS080043N
children.project_abstract: The goal of this project is to determine the power law decay exponent in homogeneous isotropic turbulence as a function of the turbulent Reynolds number.   The project will address the realistic numerical creation of isotropic turbulence, and its subsequent decay using sufficient statistical sample to produce definitive results.  Because of the size of resolution required for the desired results, we are requesting 320,000 roaming hours for this work.  This allocation size will allow for determination of the power law decay exponent over a range of Reynolds numbers, which will lead to the advancement of the state of turbulence modeling.

children.name: TG-CTS090025
children.project_abstract: n/a

children.name: WS2-band-gap-and-int
children.project_abstract: The band gap is one of the most important physical quantity in the semiconductors. The optical and electrical responses are the representative physical properties of semiconductors affected by the band gap size and directness. In our project, we investigate the effect of the defects to the WS2, the famous Transition metal dichalcogenides material. In the optical absorption experiment, we observed that the absorption is strongly enhanced when the thickness of WS2 film increases via longer W sputtering time. In the same sample, we also find that the interlayer spacing reduces in the deep region of the film. In the W-rich condition the S vacancy and W substitution vacancy is readily created, inducing the reduction of interlayer spacing and band gap at the same time. Using DFT calculation, we investigate the effect of the defect to WS2, explaining the experimental results and broadening the understanding of defect states in WS2.

children.name: Gsn2010
children.project_abstract:
Electron transport in 2D semiconductor systems

This study shall use NEGF (Non-Equilibrium Green's Function) and perturbative methods to study the electrical and transport properties in 2D semiconductor systems. Specifically, this project shall study the nature of single particle tunneling and many-body interactions in a system with two or more layers of 2D semiconductors separated by suitable tunnel barriers. Different 2D material systems shall be investigated to predict various device performance metrics that will useful to the semi conductor industry for making 2D tunnel devices. Our main focus is to find suitable materials and device geometry for implementing ITFETs (Interlayer Tunnel Field Effect Transistors) and BiSFETs (Bilayer pseudoSpin Field Effect Transistors).

children.name: Gupta
children.project_abstract: In our previous study presented at ISBS 2015, we found that hang-time can have potential benefits on performance of athletes but hang-time comes at a cost of lost peak height. In this study we wish to address this issue by checking if the trajectories of the non-performing segments (non-hitting arm and legs) can be modified to maximize the performance of the performing segment (hitting arm) without affecting the hang-time. The optimizer we designed was able to predict a modified trajectory of the non-performing segments that increases both the maximum height of the hitting arm and its sagittal plane velocity for a jump from the previous study. The TACC facilities will allow us to study the features of the optimizer more expediently and study the effect of specific interventions.

children.name: TG-DMR130078
children.project_abstract: A significant challenge in the 21st century is unquestionably energy conversion and storage. Electrochemical devices such as lithium ion batteries will gain importance moving towards a low-carbon economy, but innovative materials chemistry is crucial for making further progress in these technologies.  While materials in which electrons may easily be excited and transferred has facilitated the development and wide spread use of electronic devices in society, the design and fundamental understanding of materials that are pure ion conductors has lagged behind even though the benefit of their utilization in electrochemical devices is recognized. It is the general purpose of the proposed work to develop fundamental understanding of the connections between cationic transport with structure, morphology, associated counter anion, and the chemistry in polymeric electrolyte materials with first principles based simulations. The research described in this proposal will contribute to laying the foundations for the development of poly- and polymer electrolytes that are single ion conductors  broadly considered to be an essential milestone in battery technology.

children.name: TG-MCA05S027
children.project_abstract: Alzheimer's disease, one of the leading causes of dementia, is caused by the pathological self-assembly of the 40 to 42-long Alzheimer Amyloid-beta(Ab) peptide into aggregate species. Aggregation is believed to be nucleated at a turn region located in the 21-30 segment of this peptide and mutations of residues E22 and D23 have been shown to affect the ability of these peptides to aggregate. We propose to perform replica exchange molecular dynamics simulations on E22 and D23 mutants of the 21-30 fragment of the (Ab) peptide to investigate how these substitutions affect the folding mechanisms and conformations of these peptides and in turn their aggregation propensities.

children.name: TG-MCB190047
children.project_abstract: Atomistic molecular dynamics (MD) simulations are frequently used to evaluate the structure of intermediate (1-100 kDa) proteins, especially those exhibiting well-defined globular morphologies. However, validation of protein structures is often limited to global comparisons to static experimental structures, despite fluctuations in solution NMR that indicate that solvent-exposed amino acids interconvert between states in a thermodynamic ensemble. While it is well known that amino acids in globular cores remain tightly packed together, we recently identified a fixed percolation geometry in these regions that also persists in the presence of small mutations or thermal fluctuations. This key observation enables us to implement a novel technique that quickly validates physiological and pathological protein structures from MD, in addition to predicting putative structures based on the conservation of core residue percolation. Compared to traditional enhanced-sampling methods, where protein conformations are extracted from the most probable states, the use of side-chain percolation allows decoy states to be filtered out and discarded. As a result, simulations can focus on states that are thermodynamically consistent with known experimental ensembles, rather than on a singular protein fold. In order to develop this technique into a widely-utilized tool for efficient protein folding, we propose the following two projects: (1) to measure how often proteins implicated in physiological and pathological processes interconvert between known conformations as a result of MD fluctuations, and whether such fluctuations vary across popular force fields. (2) to identify how conformational mutations affect the interconversion between physiological and pathological states while conserving globular percolation, especially in the context of cancer and Alzheimerâ??s Disease. Taken as a whole, the ability to filter true protein structures from energy-minimized decoys will greatly reduce the need for very long protein folding simulations and can inform how proteins pathological misfold within their thermodynamic limitations.

children.name: TG-EAR140030
children.project_abstract: We are seeking to obtain a high-resolution 3D crustal model beneath the eastern margin of the Tibetan plateau. Compared with previous studies, we have two major advantages in obtaining more accurate seismic images: (1) an unprecedented station coverage in our study area with ambient noise data recorded by more than 800 stations and an inter-station spacing of a few to a few tens of kilometers; (2) an adjoint tomography technique based on highly accurate spectral-element method to simulate empirical Greens functions derived from ambient noise interferometry. Our main research objectives focus on providing a more refined 3D wavespeed crustal model to better understand the evolution history and current deformation mechanism of the study region. There are a few scientific questions to be answered with the new model: (1) What is the geometry of the low velocity zones (LVZs)? Are the LVZs horizontally pervasive or more complex? Are the LVZs spatially related to the fault zones and why? (2) Is there a correlation between major fault zones and regions with sharp wavespeed contrast? (3) Is there any robust seismological footprint (e.g. high wavespeed lower crust) to prove the existence of the mantle plume, which may have played an important role in generating the Emeishan basalts?

children.name: UTD-seismic-imaging
children.project_abstract: UTD seismo Lab focuses on developments of new technology for modeling, imaging and inversion of seismic wavefields, as well as applications of these technology to probe the interior structure of the Earth at both continental and reservoir scales.

children.name: Electromagnetic-Anal
children.project_abstract:
Electromagnetic Analysis of Electronic Packages

Electronic packages continue to pose challenges that are not met by current simulation tools. Advanced electromagnetic simulators are needed to characterize, analyze, design, and optimize full-scale packages. The goal of this project is to enable predictive and fast full-wave simulation of full-scale packages by exploiting the latest developments in computational electromagnetics. Specifically, the PI will (i) formulate layered-medium Green functions and generalized conductor loss models for packages to simplify modeling/meshing, to increase accuracy, and to reduce number of unknowns, (ii) develop FFT-accelerated iterative and direct integral-equation algorithms to reduce computational costs, (iii) devise parallel workload distribution methods to increase parallel efficiency and scalability of the methods, and (iv) deploy the resulting software and investigate its performance on massively parallel clusters of multi-core processors and many-integrated-core coprocessors on Lonestar and Stampede.
The requested SUs will be used for (i) code validation by solving reference problems, (ii) parallel scalability tests, and (iii) medium-scale simulations. It is expected that the results of these investigation will significantly extend our ability to quantify the elecrtical performance of electronic packages.

children.name: TG-CHE160037
children.project_abstract:
High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) uses high-pressure flows in columns of micron-scale manufactured particles to achieve rapid and efficient separation of analytes into identifiable compounds. Improvements in HPLC column efficiency have been 
driven by reductions in particle size. Non-spherical, superficially porous particles (SPP) are a possibility for improving separation efficiency without further reducing the particle length scale. This research will investigate the chromatographic efficiency of ellipsoidal and spherocylindrical particles in HPLC, using pore-scale simulation methods capable of resolving flow and transport in microporous SPP.  The methods include computer algorithms for three-dimensional particle packing, viscous flow through the pore spaces of the packing, and time-dependent hydrodynamic dispersion of solutes in the flowing solvent. The methods will be applied within a general experimental design that will consider the parameters of particle shape, superficial porosity, particle orientation with respect to flow, packing volume fraction, and applied pressure drop, focusing on parameter value ranges of likely industrial significance. The experimental outcomes of broadest 
significance include the chromatographic efficiency (plate height vs velocity) and impedence (plate height vs pressure drop).

children.name: Identify-Novel-Molec
children.project_abstract:
Spinal cord injury (SCI) is a devastating disease without effective treatment. The chronic SCI remains the most difficult to treat. The pathologic hallmarks in chronic SCI include increased astrogliosis and inhibitory molecules that hinder axonal regeneration.  However, the understanding of the detailed molecular pathways is still very limited. For example, how inhibitory molecules are regulated and maintained in the chronic phase remains unclear. Current therapeutics for gliosis is not ideal, and new molecular targets are urgently needed. Previous studies have usually focused on a small number of genes and pathways at a time, and thus did not provide a comprehensive view of the complex mechanisms underlying SCI pathophysiology. Although, during the last decade, microarray studies have provided valuable insights into SCI, microarray suffers from limitations in resolution, dynamic range and accuracy. Recent advances in RNA-Sequencing technology, make it possible to globally map transcribed regions and quantitatively analyze expression at an unprecedented level of sensitivity and specificity. Based on our preliminary studies of differential expression using RNA-Seq during acute and subacute SCI phases in mouse contusive injury models, we propose to investigate the intricate relationship of genes and pathways in the spinal cord tissue and the predominant component of the glial scar (purified astrocytes) in chronic SCI by using integrated RNA-Seq and network analyses. We hypothesize that novel genes and pathways that regulate or maintain inhibitory molecules in reactive astrocytes (chondroitin sulphate proteoglycans, tenascins, ephrin-B2 and Slit proteins etc.) are critical for the chronic SCI inhibitory environment associated with glial scar. Specifically, we propose to derive a better understanding of the progression of SCI pathophysiology by characterizing gene and splicing isoform changes in SCI subchronic/chronic phases at both temporal and spatial levels. Additionally, we will use an innovative strategy of integrated network analysis to identify novel genes of interest (GOIs) and pathways involved in gliosis as new molecular targets. We will also incorporate pharmacogenomic information into our analyses that will serve as a powerful tool for translation. Finally, we will test GOIs potentially involved in neuron inhibition of reactive astrocytes by loss- and gain-of-function assays in a glia scar model for their functional effects.
Our study is the first to propose that the mechanisms of chronic SCI and gliosis be investigated at the systems level using RNA-Seq, and key genes be identified via innovative pathway and network analyses and be tested by functional assays.  The advantage of the genome-wide analysis is that, as a de novo discovery approach, it can identify critical missing links in the disease processes that were not previously appreciated. Importantly, we will generate a comprehensive data resource of SCI gene expression which will be extremely valuable for the research community (jiaqianwulab.org/SCIbrowser/data). The successful completion of this project will lead to the discovery of novel molecular targets and shift the research and clinical paradigms.

children.name: TG-BCS130009
children.project_abstract: Hurricanes are one of the most costly natural disasters impacting the US coastal areas and the State of Virginia has historically faced severe impacts from these storms (e.g., Isabel [2003] and Sandy [2012]). Although coastal areas are predominantly at risk from storm surge flooding, areas along the Chesapeake Bay and its tributaries are also extremely vulnerable to hurricane flooding. It is believed that coastal wetlands, besides its ecological importance, might help to reduce the impact of storm surge, acting as a natural protection against hurricane flooding, especially for small hurricanes and tropical storms. Here, we propose to develop a novel framework integrating high performance computing of hurricane storm surge flooding, hydrodynamics characterization of flow through natural wetlands ecosystems and critical infrastructure inventory to investigate the potential of wetlands to reduce hurricane flooding, improving our basic understanding of natural hazards and our capability to expand the State resilience to such events. To improve our fundamental knowledge of tide and storm surge hydrodynamics in wetlands ecosystems, four study sites in the eastern shore will be equipped with sensors to thoroughly monitor water levels within wetlands ecosystems and field survey will be performed in these sites to measure vegetation structural characteristics contributing to flow resistance (i.e. height, diameter and stem density). The field campaigns information will support the development and calibration of computational models to simulate storm surge flow over wetlands specifically designed to represent Virginias aquatic vegetation. A multi-model, multi-scale, multi-resolution approach will be developed to integrate High Performance Computing (HPC) of large scale and high resolution hurricane storm surge modeling and small scale high fidelity models to evaluate the benefits of wetlands ecosystems to reduce storm surge and related damage to critical infrastructure quantified using geospatial analyses. Quantifying these benefits will provide sound scientific information to support planning and decision making.

children.name: A-ph9
children.project_abstract:
I lead a theoretical physics group consisting of typically four postdoctoral researchers and six to eight graduate students.
We work mainly on the electronic properties of solids and liquids. Our main current focus lies in several areas of nanoscale physics. One of the burgeoning areas of research we have been focusing our effort is in the electronic properties of two-dimensional crystals that includes a variety of materials including transition metal dichalcogenides (TMD), ultrathin layered oxides, graphene and boron nitride, and other combinations between group III to VI elements in the periodic table. This is one of the research areas that is being most actively pursued at the present worldwide and we are moving quickly to explain new observed phenomena and anticipate novel physics. Our theory group at UT Austin has been a world reference in this rapidly expanding area of research at the interface of solid state physics, electrical engineering, and information science.  TACC resources have been extremely helpful in keeping us at the top of this field.

children.name: TG-BCS190009
children.project_abstract: One of the most difficult aspects of seismic hazard analysis is the prediction of ground motion from potential earthquakes. Accurate simulation of ground motion requires extensive knowledge of the velocity structure, source type, and site conditions in a given region; these factors must be paired with a high-resolution model mesh to predict ground motion at frequencies relevant to engineering and hazard applications. Limitations in model size and data availability often make it such that finer details in the earth model are averaged out or removed altogether, despite the fact that they could have a significant effect on predicted ground motion. In this project, we propose to examine the contribution to ground motion of an often-neglected site condition: topography. Topography has been observed to more than double earthquake ground motion in certain situations, though because of its azimuthal dependence and need for high-resolution model meshes, it is not considered in seismic hazard analysis. We will build a high-resolution mesh covering a 60km x 60km region centered on Seattle, Washington, and using the spectral element code SPECFEM3D Cartesian, run multiple rupture scenarios for Mw6.5-7.0 earthquakes on the Seattle Fault. By using high-resolution topography and a detailed 3-D velocity model, we will have an unprecedented view into the contribution of topography on seismic site response. With these tests, we will answer the question of how sensitive topographic effects are to source variability in finite fault rupture, like hypocenter location, slip distribution, and event magnitude. Paired with results from earlier tests with smaller earthquakes (Mw3.0-4.0), we will also investigate how topographic effects vary between small and large earthquakes, which have distinctly different frequency content, source distribution, and shaking duration. The results of this testing will amount to a major benchmark for the inclusion of high-resolution site conditions like topography in seismic hazard analysis.

children.name: TG-DMS180042
children.project_abstract: Storm surge is the rise of the water level in the sea, an estuary or lake as result of strong wind driving the seawater towards the coast. It can lead to significant flooding in coastal areas and severe damages to the life and property from a hurricane. Quantifying the risk to storm surge hazard often relies on large number of simulated hurricanes from storm surge modeling systems due to lack of sufficient historical data. The Advanced Circulation (ADCIRC) model is one of the primary storm surge models in the United States, and has been used to predict storm surge and control the impact of storm damage. A single simulation run from the ADCIRC model requires five hours, which is too expensive for risk management. Statistical surrogate models have been widely used to approximate outputs from computer models. Our research goal is to develop a statistical surrogate model to approximate the outputs from the ADCIRC model. The ADCIRC model generate more than 130,000 outputs for a single run. To build the statistical surrogate model, we plan to run about 10,000 simulation runs. We requresting a Startup account so that we can perform statistical analysis based on these massive simulation outputs. We mainly write R code to perform statistical analysis. The computation in training our statistical model is very computational expensive and requires lots of memories (about 100GB). In addition, the ADCIRC model outputs are also generated by our collaborator as an independent PI using computing resources at the TACC. Once I am approved, I can directly perform statistical analysis on these computer model simulations at TACC without moving the massive amount of data (about 10 TB) elsewhere.
